Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-145
Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  March 1, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Walter M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Norma Patrick Hall was charged 
  with one count of homicide by child abuse, for which she entered a plea under 
  North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).Â  She appeals her sentence, 
  arguing the circuit court failed to consider her diminished capacity due to 
  drug use as a mitigating factor during sentencing.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In April 2002, Hall was indicted for one count 
  of homicide by child abuse in connection with the death of her six-month old 
  son, Harley Benjamin Hall.Â  She entered into an Alford plea agreement 
  and was sentenced to forty years in prison.Â  During sentencing, the circuit 
  court refused to consider Hallâ€™s diminished mental capacity resulting from drug 
  use, stating â€œThe mitigation that has been forwarded for the Courtâ€™s consideration 
  has been that of drug abuse.Â  As you all know, diminished capacity is no defense 
  in South Carolina, and in this instance I fail to find it is a mitigating circumstance.â€ 
  Â This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hall argues the circuit court erred as a matter 
  of law by failing to consider diminished capacity resulting from her drug use 
  during her sentencing phase.Â  In fact, the trial judge clearly considered that 
  diminished capacity resulting from drug abuse may be a mitigating factor, but 
  determined it was not so in the present case.Â  Moreover, Hall did not object 
  when the circuit court imposed its sentence.Â  Thus, the issue of the sentence 
  is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 462, 
  510 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1999) (stating that a challenge to sentencing must be raised 
  at trial, or the issue will not be preserved for appellate review).
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
KCI Management Corporation and Alexis Pierre
Kisteneff,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bara Post, Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate 
        of Malcolm Post, deceased,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-147
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  1, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James C. Parham, Jr. and William M. Wilson, both of Greenville; 
  and Laurence M. Johnson, of Boston, for Appellant.
Robert "Sam" Phillips and Richard R. Gleissner, 
  both of Columbia; and Robert C. Wilson, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  KCI Management Corporation 
  brought this declaratory judgment action to determine the rights of Malcolm 
  Post in properties that were part of real estate development projects. [1] Â  This action revolves around a dispute between 
  Post and his former business associate, Alexis Pierre Kisteneff, as to whether 
  Post held an interest in real property they had planned to develop.Â  The case 
  was tried to a jury before the Circuit Court of Greenville County on a special 
  interrogatory as to whether a partnership existed between Post and Kisteneff 
  relating to their real estate development plans.Â  The jury found they had not 
  entered into a partnership, thereby foreclosing Postâ€™s claim of an ownership 
  interest in the real estate in dispute.Â  Bara Post appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
At the center of this case is the business relationship 
  that developed between Kisteneff and Malcolm Post.Â  Several key facts are clear 
  and undisputed:Â  Both gentlemen had varying experiences in real estate speculation 
  and development prior to their association.Â  Both were interested in pursuing 
  some type of real estate venture together after they were introduced to each 
  other in 1995.Â  Only Kisteneff invested money in the projects; Post made no 
  financial contributions.Â  None of the potential projects the two men attempted 
  to develop together realized any profits during their association.Â  Beyond this 
  basic information, however, the precise nature of the business relationship 
  between the two is difficult to discern.Â  This task is complicated by the fact 
  that Post died prior to the commencement of this suit, leaving the parties to 
  rely primarily on the testimony of Kisteneff in its inquiry.
The record shows, in the spring of 1995, 
  Kisteneff â€œmetâ€ Post by telephone after John Canney, an associate of Kisteneffâ€™s, 
  told Kisteneff that Post was looking for someone with whom he could get back 
  into the real estate business.Â  At this time, the two discussed the possibility 
  of working together on some real estate development opportunities.Â  At the time, 
  Post had already identified a potential project in Quincy, Massachusetts.Â  The 
  Quincy project did not go through, but the two men subsequently met to discuss 
  another possible project in Broughton, Connecticut.Â  At this meeting, Kisteneff 
  claims he proposed forming a partnership with Post, but Post refused, claiming 
  he could not hold an ownership interest in any new venture because it would 
  be subject to liens due to outstanding taxes and judgments he owed.Â  Both men 
  then agreed that some type of arrangement would be reached among themselves 
  and Canney, whereby they would work together and each receive a third of any 
  profits from a successful project.Â  The fundamental principle behind their association 
  was that they would share equally in any profits, once the project was built 
  and succeeded in selling.Â  
In May 1995, Kisteneffâ€™s attorney drafted 
  a letter to John Canney, following a discussion with Post and his wife, concerning 
  the appropriate entity with whom the parties should contract.Â  The letter proposed 
  that Canney and Kisteneff prepare a letter on behalf of WAGA Investment Associates, 
  L.P., which would contain language whereby WAGA would agree to contract for 
  the services of Post.Â  The proposed language included that Post would â€œas WAGAâ€™s 
  Agent, negotiate the purchase and sale agreement and direct all permitting, 
  development and construction activities subject . . . to WAGAâ€™s supervision 
  and direction.â€Â  It further stated, â€œFor your [Postâ€™s] services, you will receive 
  one-third of cash flow arising from operations, sale or refinancing including, 
  without limitation, any development fee that is payable pursuant to the financing.â€Â  
  The WAGA partnership was never formed after plans for the Quincy construction 
  project fell through.Â  However, the three discussed the letter, and, according 
  to Kisteneff, they all agreed that â€œit laid a good foundation for our relationship.â€Â  
  Despite this false start, Kisteneff testified that:

[The letter] asserted the principle 
  that a partnership would be formed in the event that we did develop the property 
  together which would be between me and Mr. [Canney], and Mr. [Canney] and I 
  would then turn around and contract with Mr. Post for [his] services, and that 
  he would participate in one third of the profit of a successful project after 
  he did what he was supposed to do, which was supervise construction and also 
  sell the units.Â  

During cross-examination, Kisteneff was pressed 
  further about the agreement he had reached with Post.Â  Unable to recall precise 
  details, Kisteneff described their relationship after their initial personal 
  meeting in general terms:

I do not have a specific recollection 
  of what was talked about in the car.Â  We were getting acquainted, and talking 
  about the possibilities of doing the possible project in Broughton.
But I would think it logical 
  that at that meeting, possibly in the car when we were tooling around Broughton, 
  that we came to terms on what our roles would be and what our rewards would 
  be. 
What our roles and rewards would 
  be for discharging those roles, and the fundamental principle is basically only 
  one, sir.Â  The fundamental principle was that we would share equally in the 
  profits of the project.Â  

Kisteneff stated he â€œagreed to compensate [Post] 
  for [his] participation in the process.â€Â  Kisteneff further testified, he put 
  the seed money into the projects and was responsible for the ultimate financing 
  and that he â€œhad sole control of the deals because I was the only one at risk.â€Â  

After some investigation, and on advice of his 
  bank, Kisteneff decided he would not go forward on the Broughton deal.Â  Over 
  the next year, however, three other properties were considered for development:Â  
  one in Boston, Massachusetts, one in Cranston, Rhode Island and a third in Greenville, 
  South Carolina. Â In August 1995, Canney and Post contacted Kisteneff 
  about the Boston property, and the men discussed developing single-family housing 
  there.Â  Post indicated he believed they could acquire the necessary permits 
  and break ground by March 1996.Â  Kisteneff agreed with the proposal and â€œauthorized 
  [Post and Canney] to get goingâ€ on the project.Â  
In September 1995, Post called Kisteneff and requested 
  Kisteneff advance him money in order to â€œkeep the wolf away from the door.â€Â  
  Post told Kisteneff he would pay him back out of his share of the profits of 
  one of their deals.Â  Kisteneff arranged for his own company, KCI Management 
  Corporation, to advance Post $5,000 per month against his future share of any 
  profits realized in the Boston project.Â  These payments continued for a period 
  of fifteen months, through November 1996 when Kisteneff was required to turn 
  his financial resources toward purchase of the Boston property.Â  
Unfortunately, the Boston project encountered objections 
  from local residents, and the City of Boston responded by drawing out the permitting 
  process.Â  The City ultimately denied the necessary building permits in March 
  1997.Â  By this time, Kisteneff had purchased the property, and he felt it necessary 
  to bring a lawsuit against the City of Boston for wrongful denial of the permits.Â  
  Although the court ruled in Kisteneffâ€™s favor and ordered the City to issue 
  the permits, the City filed an appeal, preventing any further development of 
  the Boston property.Â  
In late 1995, Post brought to Kisteneffâ€™s attention 
  the property located in Cranston, Rhode Island.Â  In January 1996, Kisteneff 
  authorized Post to execute a purchase and sale memorandum on behalf of KCI Management 
  Corporation setting out a formula for the purchase of the land.Â  Post executed 
  the document as Vice President of KCI.Â  Although Canney, Post and Kisteneff 
  attempted to secure financing for the project throughout 1996, by the end of 
  the year, they were unable to locate the two million dollars they needed for 
  the project.Â  In late 1996 and early 1997, Post informed Kisteneff that the 
  owner of the Cranston property intended to withdraw the property from sale, 
  and their open-ended contract on the property was most likely unenforceable.Â  
  Several months later, Post called Kisteneff and told him he planned to â€œreinsertâ€ 
  himself into the Cranston deal without Kisteneff.Â  After objection from Kisteneff, 
  Post told him he would â€œsee what [he could] do about letting [Kisteneff] into 
  the deal.â€Â  Apparently, Post did not include Kisteneff in the deal but had already 
  begun to work with someone else on the development of the property.Â  Kisteneff 
  testified Post went into business with this other person in January 1997, and 
  negotiated a $450,000 payment for the work Post had performed on the project 
  prior to his association with this other person.Â  According to Kisteneff, Post 
  also negotiated salaries for himself and his wife, along with a forty percent 
  share in profits on the project.Â  
In February, 1996, Post traveled to South Carolina, 
  at which time Kisteneff showed Post some Greenville property he was interested 
  in them developing together.Â  Kisteneff had been working on the Greenville property 
  for over a year at that time.Â  Within a week of Postâ€™s visit, Kisteneff placed 
  a deposit on the property.Â  
By the end of 1996, Kisteneff had spent in excess 
  of $600,000 and had gone into debt for $300,000, for a total of $900,000 contributed 
  toward the potential projects.Â  Post, however, had contributed no money to any 
  of the land purchases. Â 
Kisteneff testified, as he believed they were closer 
  to getting the Boston project underway, he sought to formalize his working relationship 
  with Post.Â  Accordingly, Kisteneff proposed that he and Post form a corporation 
  named ALMA.Â  Post would not personally be a stockholder in the corporation because 
  he did not want his creditors to be able to â€œget at him,â€ so they discussed 
  that the corporation would formally employ Post as he worked on the various 
  projects.Â  In August 1996, Kisteneff had his attorney draft a series of documents 
  to put his proposed arrangement with Post in writing.Â  After sending those documents 
  to Post and his attorney in late August 1996, Post did not initially respond.Â  
  After a few months, Postâ€™s attorney returned the documents with notations indicating 
  they would not be executed.Â  According to Kisteneff, Postâ€™s only response was 
  a counter-offer communicated through Postâ€™s attorney for a single project in 
  â€œAlma, South Carolinaâ€â€” a place that Kisteneff knew did not exist.Â  Kisteneff 
  questioned Post and Postâ€™s attorney regarding the proposed change in their deal, 
  but each responded they were merely acting on the instruction of the other.Â  
  According to Kisteneff, with the exception of a March 1997 communication, Post 
  barely spoke to him after December 1996, shortly after he sent him the last 
  monthly $5,000 check.Â  Post did not call or suggest any new deals or bring Kisteneff 
  any new prospects.Â  At this time, Kisteneff concluded Post no longer wanted 
  to do business with him.Â  
Kisteneff testified he did not hear from Post again 
  until March or April 1998, when Kisteneff received a favorable ruling on the 
  permits issue in Boston, and â€œall of a sudden, [Post] reappeared.â€Â  On April 
  1, 1998, Kisteneff wrote Post a letter asking him not to interfere with Kisteneffâ€™s 
  negotiations of settlement with the City of Boston.Â  Post, however, would not 
  agree to the request.Â  By letter dated April 20, 1998 Kisteneff referred to 
  an April 3, 1998 conversation he had with Post, and informed Post he was â€œstunnedâ€ 
  to hear Post describe his version of their deal.Â  Kisterneff stated that after 
  loaning Post $5,000 a month for fifteen months, when â€œthe well ran dry,â€ Post 
  virtually dropped out of sight.Â  He then notified Post, that any relationship 
  between Post and KCI was terminated by Postâ€™s refusal to negotiate and define 
  a written agreement with KCI, despite KCIâ€™s efforts to do so.Â Â  Kisteneff further 
  asked Post to execute an enclosed promissory note for the repayment of the $75,000 
  that had been advanced to Post, and to submit an estimate for the services Post 
  rendered to KCI for the Boston project.Â  
In June 1998, KCI initiated the present 
  declaratory judgment action in response to claims by Post that he possessed 
  an equitable interest in the Greenville and Boston properties.Â  While various 
  other causes of action were subsequently added by the parties, the only issue 
  submitted to the jury was whether Kisteneff and Post entered into a partnership 
  agreement regarding development of the real estate in question.Â  Appellant now 
  appeals the juryâ€™s verdict finding no partnership existed, as well as two rulings 
  by the trial court regarding the trial judgeâ€™s instructions to the jury.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Trial Courtâ€™s Jury Instructions
Appellant first argues the trial court 
  erred on two occasions in instructing the jury on the law.Â  We find no reversible 
  error.Â  
The trial judge is required to charge the current 
  and correct law.Â  McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 
  603, 606 (1995).Â  When reviewing jury charges for error, an appellate court 
  must consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and 
  issues presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 
  334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 575 (1999).Â  A jury charge is correct if, 
  when read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and adequately charges 
  the law.Â  Id. at 495-96, 514 S.E.2d at 574.Â  If the charges given, as 
  a whole, are reasonably free from error, isolated portions which might be misleading 
  do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id. at 497, 514 S.E.2d at 575.Â  
  Further, refusal to give a properly requested charge is not error if the general 
  instructions are sufficiently broad to enable the jury to understand the law 
  and the issues involved.Â  McCourt, 318 S.C. at 306, 457 S.E.2d at 606.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Jury Instruction on Contract LawÂ  

Appellant takes exception to the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision to instruct the jury on the elements of contract formation.Â  She argues 
  this instruction was wholly irrelevant to the question of partnership formation 
  and thereby served to sow seeds of confusion in the jurorsâ€™ minds.Â  We disagree.
A partnership is an association of two or more 
  persons, to carry on as co-owners a business for profit.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-210 
  (Supp. 2003); Buffkin v. Strickland, 280 S.C. 343, 345, 312 S.E.2d 579, 
  580 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  A partnership agreement may rest in parole.Â  It may also 
  be implied and without express intention.Â  Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 
  S.C. 97, 101, 394 S.E.2d 7, 10 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  A partnership is a relation 
  arising out of contract, and a partnership between parties arises only out of 
  the contract of the parties, as expressed in their agreement or implied from 
  their dealings with each other and others.Â  Stephens v. Stephens, 213 
  S.C. 525, 531, 50 S.E.2d 577, 579 (1948).Â  One of the most important tests as 
  to the existence of a partnership is the intention of the parties.Â  Id. 
  at 530, 50 S.E.2d at 579.Â  If parties intend to and do enter into a contract 
  as in the eye of the law constitutes a partnership, they thereby become partners 
  whether they are designated as such or not in their contract.Â  Id. at 
  530-31, 50 S.E.2d at 579.Â  Thus, â€œwhere the parties to a contract, by their 
  acts, conduct, or agreement show that they intended to combine their 
  property, labor, skill and experience, or some of these elements on one side 
  and some on the other, to carry on as principals or co-owners, a common 
  business, trade, or venture as a commercial enterprise, and to share, either 
  expressly or by implication, the profits and losses or expenses that may be 
  incurred, such parties are partners.â€Â  Id. at 531-32, 50 S.E.2d at 580 
  (emphasis added).Â  Where there is no express contract, either written or verbal, 
  common tests used in determining whether a partnership exists are:Â  (1) the 
  sharing of profits and losses; (2) community of interest in capital or property; 
  and (3) community of interest in control and management.Â  Halbersberg, 
  302 S.C. at 101, 394 S.E.2d at 10;Â  Stephens, 213 S.C. at 532, 50 S.E.2d 
  at 580. 
The threshold question for the jury in this case 
  was whether the parties entered a contract whereby they intended to carry on 
  a business as principals and co-owners.Â  While it is not necessary there be 
  an express agreement between the parties to enter a partnership before such 
  a partnership can be found, there must be an intent of the parties to enter 
  into a contract that would, in the eyes of the law, constitute a partnership, 
  before such a finding can be made.Â  Thus, the law of contract was not wholly 
  irrelevant to the issues at hand.Â  Further, in looking at the various tests 
  applicable to the question of whether a partnership existed, a critical aspect 
  of the juryâ€™s determination in this case rested on whether the partiesâ€™ proposed 
  agreements as to compensation, ownership, and management were ever entered into 
  and finalized between and among the principals involved.Â  In light of this, 
  the contract formation elements of offer, acceptance, and consideration that 
  were included in the trial judgeâ€™s instructions to the jury were more likely 
  to help rather than hinder the juryâ€™s deliberations.Â  At any rate, we find, 
  when considered as a whole, the charges were reasonably free from error, and 
  any isolated portions which might have been misleading do not constitute reversible 
  error. 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Sufficiency of Instruction in Response to Jury Question
Appellant also takes exception to the 
  sufficiency of the trial judgeâ€™s response to a request for clarification the 
  jury submitted to the court during deliberations.Â  On this point, too, we find 
  no error.
During deliberations, the jury requested 
  clarification of the elements that had to be shown to prove a partnership existed.Â  
  In its initial instructions, the trial court charged the jury on the statutory 
  and common law rules and tests for determining the existence of a partnership.Â  
  Specifically, the court charged S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-210 (Supp. 2003), defining 
  a partnership as an association of two or more persons to carry on as co-owners 
  a business for profit, as well as S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-220 (1990), which provides 
  as follows:

In determining whether a partnership exists, these rules shall 
  apply:
(1) Except as provided by Â§ 33-41-380 persons who are not 
  partners as to each other are not partners as to third persons;
(2) Joint tenancy, tenancy in common, tenancy by the entireties, 
  joint property, common property or part ownership does not of itself establish 
  a partnership, whether such co-owners do or do not share any profit made by 
  the use of the property;
(3) The sharing of gross returns does not of itself establish 
  a partnership, whether or not the persons sharing them have a joint or common 
  right or interest in any property from which the returns are derived; and
(4) The receipt by a person of a share of the profits of a 
  business is prima facie evidence that he is a partner in the business, but no 
  such inference shall be drawn if such profits were received in payment
  
(a) as a debt by installments or otherwise,
(b) as wages of an employee or rent to a landlord,
(c) as an annuity to a widow or representative of a deceased 
  partner,
(d) as interest on a loan, though the amount of payment vary 
  with the profits of the business or
(e) as the consideration for the sale of the good will of 
  a business or other property by installments or otherwise.
  
The court also charged under the common law as follows:
In South Carolina a partnership does not have to be in writing.Â  
  A partnership may be formed by oral agreement and may even be implied to exist 
  by conduct of the parties without any evidence of expressed intent to form a 
  partnership.Â  The following tests are appropriate in determining whether a partnership 
  exists:Â  the sharing of profits and losses, community of interest in capital 
  or property, and community of interest in control or management.

The jury was apparently confused, however, as to 
  whether all of the elements under these tests had to be proven for a partnership 
  to exist, sending a note to the trial judge asking:Â  â€œRequirements/clarification 
  of the law re: existence of a partnership.Â  Do all the requirements have to 
  exist?â€Â  Unclear as to whether the jury was referring to the statutory rules 
  or common law tests, the trial judge asked them to elaborate.Â  The jury responded:Â  
  â€œRequirements or elements that make a partnership; example, one, oral agreement; 
  two, actions of each party, etc.Â  Please give complete list and tell us how 
  many or all of these components exist.â€Â  Concerned that the jury was asking 
  the court to make a factual finding, it asked the jury foreman for further elaboration 
  when the jury returned to the courtroom.Â  The foreman responded:Â  â€œWhat I meant 
  was not for you to tell us which things exist, but how many are necessary to 
  exist in order to make it --.â€Â  Satisfied with the foremanâ€™s clarification, 
  the trial court recharged the jury with the substance of Â§Â§ 33-41-210 and 33-41-220, 
  as well as the common law as to the manner in which a partnership may be formed 
  and the common law tests, as initially charged by the court.Â  The court further 
  instructed:

These rules and the tests I stated 
  earlier are simply factors to be considered by you in determining whether or 
  not a partnership exists as I have defined partnership, which, again, is an 
  association of two or more persons to carry on as co-owners a business for profit.

Appellant contends the trial courtâ€™s supplemental 
  instructions did not adequately answer the juryâ€™s question and the court erred 
  in failing to instruct the jury that no particular number of statutory factors 
  under Â§ 33-41-220 need be proven in order to permit the finding of a partnership.Â  
  We disagree.Â  By admonishing the jury that the rules and tests described were 
  â€œsimply factors to be consideredâ€ by the jury in making its determination, we 
  find the juryâ€™s concern about applying one or all of the elements was adequately 
  addressed.Â  This instruction from the trial judge sufficiently advised the jury 
  that no particular number of statutory factors were necessary.Â  The general 
  instructions given by the court were sufficiently broad to enable the jury to 
  understand the law and the issues involved.Â  Accordingly, we find no error with 
  the trial judgeâ€™s response to the juryâ€™s question.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Entitlement to New Trial Based on the Evidence
Finally, Appellant argues the record contains no 
  evidence to reasonably support the juryâ€™s findings. She therefore asserts she 
  is entitled to a new trial.Â  We disagree.
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried 
  by a jury, the appellate court will correct errors of law, but will not disturb 
  a factual finding of the jury unless a review of the record discloses no evidence 
  to reasonably support the juryâ€™s findings.Â  York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 
  325 S.C. 170, 174, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997).Â  This court has no power to review 
  matters of fact in an action at law, except to determine if a verdict is wholly 
  unsupported by the evidence.Â  Id.
South Carolinaâ€™s Uniform Partnership Act defines 
  a â€œpartnershipâ€ as â€œan association of two or more persons to carry on as co-owners 
  a business for profit. . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-210 (Supp. 2003).Â  In applying 
  this definition, our courts have held:Â  â€œThe following tests are appropriate 
  in determining whether a partnership exists:Â  (1) the sharing of profits and 
  losses; (2) community of interest in capital or property; and (3) community 
  of interest in control and management.â€Â  Halbersberg v. Berry, 302 S.C. 
  97, 101, 394 S.E.2d 7, 10 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In the present case, we find the 
  evidence regarding the intended ownership structure, treatment of profits and 
  losses, and control and management over the ventures was sufficient for the 
  jury to reasonably conclude a partnership did not exist.
Specifically, there is evidence from which the 
  jury could conclude that Post was not a â€œco-ownerâ€ in the venture and did not 
  hold any â€œcommunity of interestâ€ in the capital or property at issue.Â  As noted 
  above, Kisteneff testified that when he proposed that he and Post enter into 
  a partnership, Post expressly declined, citing his inability to hold an ownership 
  interest in any new venture due to the personal liens and judgments that had 
  been entered against him.Â  Moreover, it is undisputed that Post never invested 
  any capital toward the real estate projects in question.
Further, there is evidence from which the jury 
  could determine Post did not hold any â€œcommunity of interest in control and 
  managementâ€ of the projects.Â  The WAGA letter, which Kisteneff testified they 
  all agreed laid the foundation to their relationship, clearly contemplated an 
  association whereby Post would be an agent of the partnership between Kisteneff 
  and Canney, but would not, himself, be a partner.Â  Kisteneff also testified 
  to instances where he â€œauthorizedâ€ Post to begin work on a project or to execute 
  a contract on behalf of KCI, thereby evincing Kisteneffâ€™s control and management 
  over the projects.Â  Kisteneff further maintained, because he was the only one 
  investing money and was the only one at risk in the ventures, he had â€œsole controlâ€ 
  over the projects. 
Finally, the jury could reasonably find that a 
  partnership was not implied from the sharing of profits and losses.Â  When examining 
  profit-sharing arrangements for the purpose of determining the existence of 
  a partnership, the Act provides that:

The receipt by a person of a 
  share of the profits of a business is prima facie evidence that he is a partner 
  in the business, but no such inference shall be drawn if such profits were received 
  in payment
(a) as a debt by installments 
  or otherwise,
(b) as wages of an employee or 
  rent to a landlord,
(c) as an annuity to a widow 
  or representative of a deceased partner,
(d) as interest on a loan, though 
  the amount of payment vary with the profits of the business or
(e) as the consideration for 
  the sale of the good will of a business or other property by installments or 
  otherwise.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-220(4) (Supp. 2003).Â  
Although there is evidence KCI advanced 
  Post a total of $75,000 against his future share of profits in the Boston project, 
  it is undisputed that no profits were ever actually realized from this project 
  or any other.Â  The testimony from Kisteneff shows their agreement was that Post 
  was to share in the profits if and only if the projects were successful enough 
  to produce profits.Â  Thus, Post did not actually receive â€œa share of the profits,â€ 
  but only an advance toward the monies the parties contemplated he would realize 
  from his association in the ventures.Â  As discussed above, there was substantial 
  evidence that Kisteneff and Canney intended to structure their relationship 
  with Post so that Post would be employed as an agent, and the distribution of 
  any profits to him would be classified as compensation, or wages, for work performed 
  on the venture.Â  Accordingly, there is evidence from which the jury could have 
  determined, pursuant to Â§ 33-41-220(4)(b), no inference should be drawn as to 
  a partnership based on the $75,000 advance.Â  Finally, one of the appropriate 
  tests in determining the existence of a partnership is not simply consideration 
  of the sharing of profits, but also the sharing of losses.Â  The evidence here 
  shows no attendant sharing in losses by Post.
For these reasons, we find sufficient evidence 
  of record to reasonably support the juryâ€™s finding that no partnership existed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  

CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we find 
  no error with the trial judgeâ€™s instructions to the jury.Â  We further find the 
  evidence adduced at trial reasonably supports the juryâ€™s verdict, and appellant 
  is therefore not entitled to a new trial.Â  The ruling of the trial court is
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, STILWELL, and CURETON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Ultimately, 
    Alexis Pierre Kisteneff was added as a plaintiff andBara Post, individually 
    and as the personal representative of her late husband, Malcolm Post, was 
    substituted as defendant after Malcolmâ€™s death.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Augusta S. Lawson,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Karen Irby,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-148
Submitted November 19, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  March 2, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Edward D. Sullivan and Katherine Carruth Link, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Andrew M. Jones, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Augusta Lawson appeals from 
  an order decreeing that a certain structure is a modular home and not a trailer. 
  We affirm.
FACTSÂ Â Â Â  
Karen Irby bought a lot in the Green Acres subdivision 
  in 1999. That lot was subject to certain covenants and restrictions, one of 
  which stated â€œ[n]o structure of a temporary character (trailer, basement, tent, 
  shack, garage, barn, or other out-building) shall be used on any lot at any 
  time as a residence, either temporarily or permanently.â€ In 2001, Irby attempted 
  to move a structure onto her lot. The structure was â€œhauled into the Subdivision 
  in two pieces on transport trailers.â€ Augusta Lawson, a homeowner in the same 
  subdivision, obtained a temporary restraining order against Irby. About a week 
  later, Lawson moved for a temporary injunction. The court granted the motion, 
  enjoining Irby from â€œplacing, constructing, and/or erectingâ€ her structure on 
  her lot. Following a non-jury trial, the court found â€œas a matter of law, that 
  [Irbyâ€™s] house is a modular home and that it is not temporary in nature.â€ The 
  trial court vacated its previous order and denied Lawsonâ€™s motion for a permanent 
  injunction. 
Â ISSUES 

  (1)   Did the trial court err in finding 
  that the structure was not temporary and therefore not prohibited by the covenants? 
(2) Did the trial court err in admitting some of 
  Irbyâ€™s exhibits?
(3) Did the trial court err in finding certain 
  facts?

ANALYSISÂ Â  
â€œA suit seeking an injunction to enforce restrictive 
  covenants is an action in equity.â€ Arnoti v. Lukie, 350 S.C. 177, 179, 
  564 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2002). Therefore, â€œthis Court may take its own 
  view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€ Id.
Lawson argues that the structure is a trailer because 
  it was carried to the subdivision in two parts, joinable in the middle; it can 
  easily be separated and moved again; and it looks like a trailer. Lawson also 
  points to Irbyâ€™s purchase agreement that lists the structure as a â€œMobile/Manufactured 
  Homeâ€ and cites the UCC as the law governing the transaction. 
  [1]  For her part, Irby admits that her home was moved in two pieces and 
  has vinyl siding, but contends that such is not prohibited by Green Acresâ€™ covenants. 
  Irby points to two houses in the subdivision that were moved there after being 
  erected elsewhere. More importantly, Irby testified that the State of South 
  Carolina had certified her home as modular.  
  [2]   
The South Carolina Modular Buildings Construction 
  Act provides, in part

Modular building units bearing evidence of approval 
  must be acceptable in all localities as meeting the requirements of this chapter 
  and must be considered and accepted equivalent to a site-built structure as 
  meeting the requirements of safety to life, health, and property imposed by 
  any ordinance of any local government if the units are erected or installed 
  in accordance with all conditions of the approval.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-43-130 (Supp. 2001).
The Act has been interpreted to define 
  a modular home. See Henry v. Chambron, 304 S.C. 351, 352, 404 
  S.E.2d 518, 519 (Ct. App. 1991) (ruling that a modular home is one â€œbuilt off 
  site â€¦ transported to its intended location in as many as twenty sections â€¦ 
  affixed permanently to the propertyâ€ that has been certified by the South Carolina 
  Building Code Council as a modular home). In contrast, a mobile home â€œdoes not 
  undergo the same certification process as a modular home and it need not comply 
  with the standard building code applicable to site built homes. Furthermore, 
  there is no requirement that a mobile home be permanently affixed to the property.â€ 
  Id. at 353, 404 S.E.2d 519.
Green Acresâ€™ restrictions prohibit the 
  use of any â€œstructure of temporary character (trailer, basement, tent, 
  shack, garage, barn, or other out-building,)â€ but they do not prohibit the use 
  of modular homes. Lawsonâ€™s expert witness admitted that â€œ[b]ased on the Stateâ€™s 
  criteria for what a modular home is, [Irbyâ€™s house] would be a modular home.â€ 
  Based on that testimony and other evidence, the trial court found that Irbyâ€™s 
  home was not a trailer, but a modular home and was therefore permissible. That 
  conclusion is well supported by the record. See Taylor v. Lindsey, 
  322 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1998) (explaining that words used in restrictive 
  covenants are to be given their â€œcommon, ordinary meaningâ€ and that â€œrestrictions 
  as to the use of real estate should be strictly construed and all doubts resolved 
  in favor of free use of the propertyâ€). We therefore decline to find otherwise.
The trial courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
Huff, Stilwell, and Beatty, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  It is unclear that Lawson presented that argument 
    at trial, though she introduced the document itself into evidence.

 
   [2]  Irbyâ€™s counsel tried to introduce an â€œinspectorâ€™s 
    certificateâ€ while cross-examining Lawsonâ€™s expert witness, but Lawson objected 
    to the introduction of the document and the trial court sustained the objection. 
    Counsel then showed â€œa documentâ€ to Irby while she was on direct examination 
    purported to be a state certificate from her home, showing that the home was 
    modular. That document was not introduced into evidence. Lawson did not object 
    to the testimony, however.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kristin W. Hook,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Stephen P. Bishop and Sarah A. Bishop and Southtrust Mortgage Company, 
        Defendants, Of Whom Stephen P. Bishop and Sarah A. Bishop are,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-149
Submitted November 3, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Randall Davis and Patrick J. Frawley, both of Lexington, for Appellants.
Jean Perrin Derrick, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Kristin W. Hook brought this 
  action against Stephen P. Bishop and Sarah A. Bishop (the â€œBishopsâ€) seeking 
  enforcement of a restrictive covenant.Â  The master-in-equity issued a mandatory 
  injunction requiring the Bishops to remove all structures within the twenty-foot 
  side setback adjacent to Hookâ€™s property.Â  The Bishops appeal, claiming: 1) 
  Hook failed to prove she had the right to enforce the restrictive covenants; 
  2) the assignment to Hook of the right to enforce the restrictive covenants 
  was not valid; 3) the restrictive covenants are ambiguous and unenforceable; 
  4) the suit to enjoin construction was not timely commenced; 5) the court failed 
  to properly balance the equities between the parties; and 6) the award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs was improper.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Spence Plantation is a residential subdivision 
  developed by RPW Development and its president, Robert P. Wilkins, Jr., (collectively, 
  â€œDeveloperâ€).Â  Each lot within the subdivision is subject to detailed and extensive 
  covenants as set forth in every deed.Â  The covenants require approval by Developer 
  and the Architectural Review Committee (â€œARCâ€) of all building and landscaping 
  plans prior to construction.Â  To insure compliance, the covenants reserve to 
  â€œGrantor or Grantorâ€™s nomineeâ€ authority to enforce the restrictive covenants. 
  [1] Â  Wilkins is named in each deed as Grantorâ€™s nominee.Â  
In anticipation of building their home, the Bishops 
  submitted building and landscaping plans to Developer and ARC.Â  Although the 
  plans were approved, the Bishops began to erect a retaining wall that was not 
  included on the submitted plans. [2] 
  Â  When Hook, the adjoining landowner, discovered the retaining wall, she 
  immediately contacted the Bishops to protest the construction.Â  However, the 
  Bishops continued to build the wall and also began construction of a swimming 
  pool without submitting plans to Developer or ARC for approval. [3] Â  
As a result, Hook initiated this action seeking 
  an injunction to stop further construction within the twenty-foot side setback 
  line adjacent to her property and requesting removal of all structures within 
  this area.Â  A temporary restraining order halted construction on the wall and 
  pool on April 20, 2001.Â  
At trial, the master-in-equity issued a mandatory 
  injunction, ordering the Bishops to remove all structures within the twenty-foot 
  side setback line of Hookâ€™s property, restore the land to its natural condition, 
  and conduct all further construction in accordance with plans approved by Developer 
  and ARC.Â  The master further awarded Hook $10,071.14 in attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  costs.Â  
On appeal, the Bishops argue Hook did not have 
  the right to enforce the covenants because the document purporting to assign 
  this right to Hook was never introduced or admitted into evidence.Â  Furthermore, 
  they claim this right can not be assigned to Hook because the covenants designate 
  the succession of individuals that may act as Grantorâ€™s nominee.Â  The Bishops 
  also contend: 1) the restrictive covenants are ambiguous, and thus, unenforceable; 
  2) suit was not timely commenced because the wall was completed before an action 
  to enjoin them was initiated; 3) in balancing the equities between the parties, 
  the harm caused by having to move the retaining wall outweighs any damage suffered 
  by Hook as a result of the wall; and 4) the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs 
  was improper.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Assignment of the Right to Enforce the Restrictive Covenants
Restrictive covenants are imposed as 
  a voluntary contract between parties. Houck v. Rivers, 316 S.C. 414, 416, 450 S.E.2d 106, 108, (Ct. 
  App. 1994); see also Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Pelzer, 
  292 S.C. 343, 347, 356 S.E.2d 411, 414 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œRestrictive covenants 
  are contractual in nature and bind the parties thereto in the same manner as 
  any other contract.â€).Â  The rules applicable to the construction of contracts 
  are applicable to the construction of restrictive covenants contained in deeds.Â  
  Houck, 316 S.C. at 416, 450 S.E.2d at 108.Â  
An action to interpret a contract is 
  an action at law.Â  Pruitt v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint 
  Underwriting Assâ€™n, 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001) (â€œAn action 
  to construe a contract is an action at law reviewable under an any evidence 
  standard.â€).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, 
  our scope of review extends merely to the correction of errors of law; factual 
  findings of the trial judge will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review 
  of the record discloses that there is no evidence which reasonably supports 
  the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Crary v. Djebelli, 329 S.C. 385, 388, 496 S.E.2d 
  21, 23 (1998).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Proof of Assignment
The Bishops argue the master erred by 
  finding Hook was assigned the right to act as grantorâ€™s nominee.Â  Specifically, 
  the Bishops argue the document purporting to assign the right to enforce the 
  covenants was never introduced or admitted into evidence.Â  Thus, they claim 
  Hook failed to prove the assignment.Â  We disagree.
â€œJudicial notice is a substitute for formal 
  proof of a matter by evidence.â€Â  29 Am. Jur. 2d Evidence Â§ 24 (2003).Â  
  Judicial notice is the means by which the court will admit into evidence and 
  consider, without proof, â€œmatters of common and general knowledge or those that 
  are easily capable of immediate verification.â€Â  Id.Â  The effect of judicial 
  notice of an adjudicative fact is to conclusively establish the fact.Â  Moss 
  v. Aetna Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 370, 377, 228 S.E.2d 108, 112 (1976). 
The restrictive covenants of Spence Plantation 
  allow â€œGrantor or Grantorâ€™s nomineeâ€ to enjoin or take other legal steps to 
  prevent a violation of the restrictive covenants.Â  By document dated April 20, 
  2001, signed by Wilkins as Grantorâ€™s nominee, Hook was assigned the right to 
  enforce the restrictive covenants pertaining to this litigation.Â  This document 
  was filed with Hookâ€™s initial pleadings, and Wilkinsâ€™ trial testimony confirmed 
  the intent to make this assignment. 
The record indicates the master took judicial 
  notice of the assignment document, without objection.Â  As judicial notice of 
  the document was not objected to at trial, this issue is not preserved for appellate 
  review. Â See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge 
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  By taking judicial notice of the executed 
  assignment document, the existence and content of the document was established 
  as a fact.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Validity of Assignment
The Bishops argue the master erred by 
  finding the assignment to Hook was valid because the covenants designate the 
  succession of individuals that may act as Grantorâ€™s nominee, and whose authority 
  must be revoked prior to designating another individual to act as nominee.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
â€œWords of a restrictive covenant will 
  be given the common, ordinary meaning attributed to them at the time of their 
  execution.â€Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 863 (1998).Â  
  However, â€œ[g]reater regard should be given to the intention of the parties, 
  as ascertained from the language used and the surrounding circumstances, than 
  to the exact words used in attempting to express that intention.â€Â  Richard R. 
  Powell, Powell on Real Property Â§60.05 at 60-75 (2000); see also 
  Palmetto Dunes Resort v. Brown, 287 S.C. 1, 6, 336 S.E.2d 15, 18 (Ct. 
  App. 1985) (holding because restrictive covenants are contractual in nature, 
  the paramount rule of construction, to ascertain and give effect to the intent 
  of the parties as determined from the whole document, is applied to restrictive 
  covenants).Â  
The restrictive covenants provide:

Grantor hereby names Robert P. Wilkins, Jr. as Grantorâ€™s 
  nominee.Â  If for any reason he is unable or unwilling to serve, the following 
  are named as substitutes in the order named:Â  Robert P. Wilkins, Anne Wilkins 
  Brooks, Rose T. Wilkins, and Sarah W. Weiss.Â  Grantor further reserves the right 
  to revoke its designation and to name some other person or persons in writing. 


The covenants delineate the order of 
  substitutes to serve as Grantorâ€™s nominee in the event Wilkins â€œis unable 
  or unwilling to serve.â€Â  However, Wilkins has never been â€œunable or unwilling 
  to serveâ€ as Grantorâ€™s nominee, nor does a partial assignment of his right to 
  enforce the covenants make him â€œunable or unwilling to serve.â€Â  See Oâ€™Shea 
  v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 15, 416 S.E.2d 629, 632 (1992) (holding the right 
  to enforce a restrictive covenant is not fiduciary and may be assigned to another).Â  

As Wilkins has continuously acted as 
  Grantorâ€™s nominee and has never been â€œunable or unwilling to serve,â€ the covenant 
  delineating the order of succession to serve as Grantorâ€™s nominee is not applicable.Â  
  Thus, the evidence within the record supports the masterâ€™s finding the assignment 
  to Hook was valid. [4] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Enforceability of the Restrictive Covenants
The Bishops argue the master erred by failing to 
  find the restrictive covenants ambiguous.Â  Specifically, they contend the Minimum 
  Architectural Standards read with the covenants create ambiguity between the 
  documents causing the covenants to be unenforceable.Â  We disagree.
The rules applicable to the construction 
  of contracts are applicable to the construction of restrictive covenants contained 
  in deeds.Â  Houck, 316 S.C. at 416, 450 S.E.2d at 108.Â  â€œAn action to 
  construe a contract is an action at law reviewable under an any evidence standard.â€Â  
  Pruitt, 343 S.C. at 339, 540 S.E.2d at 845.Â  Restrictions on the free 
  use of land are not favored in the law and any ambiguity within a covenant should 
  be construed strictly against the grantor and persons seeking to enforce it.Â  
  Hamilton v. CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 158, 263 S.E.2d 378, 381 (1980); 
  Taylor, 332 S.C. at 4, 498 S.E.2d at 864.Â  Conversely, this rule of strict 
  construction will not be used to defeat the clear and express language of a 
  restrictive covenant.Â  Sea Pines Plantation Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C. 266, 
  270, 363 S.E.2d 891, 894 (1987).
The Bishops contend the covenants are ambiguous 
  because they require a twenty-foot side setback for â€œbuildings, other structure[s] 
  or any improvement[s],â€ while the Minimum Architectural Standards provide fences 
  â€œmay run along the property lines.â€Â  The Bishops argue because the terms â€œbuilding,â€ 
  â€œstructure,â€ â€œimprovement,â€ â€œfence,â€ and â€œwallâ€ are not defined or differentiated 
  from one another, the documents are ambiguous and thus unenforceable.Â  
The restrictive covenants provide, â€œ[n]o 
  building, or other structure or any improvement shall be located on said lot 
  within twenty (20') feet of the front line, within Twenty (20') feet of the 
  side lines, and within Fifty (50') feet of the rear line.â€Â  Providing additional 
  guidance, the Minimum Architectural Standards state, â€œ[f]ence[s] must start 
  at the back corners of the house and may run along the property lines.Â  Brick, 
  wrought iron, stucco and wooden fences (with approval) are allowed. . 
  . . [f]ence will be no higher than 5 feet.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  
Although we do not see any ambiguity in these 
  two documents, the first restrictive covenant, as contained in every deed in 
  Spence Plantation, mandates:

NO BUILDING, FENCE, . . . OR ANY OTHER STRUCTURE OF ANY 
  KIND SHALL BE BEGUN, ERECTED OR PLACED ON THE LOT UNTIL THE BUILDING PLANS, 
  SPECIFICATIONS, DESIGN AND PLOT PLAN SHOWING THE LOCATION OF SUCH BUILDING, 
  FENCE, . . . OR STRUCTURE ON THE LOT IN QUESTION HAVE FIRST BEEN APPROVED BY 
  GRANTOR OR GRANTORâ€™S NOMINEE . . . .

(emphasis in original).
In submitting building and landscaping plans, the 
  Bishops did not depict any structure within the twenty-foot side setback area.Â  
  Subsequently, they constructed a retaining wall and a swimming pool within this 
  area.Â  Even if the retaining wall constituted a fence, the Bishops failed to 
  comply with the covenant requiring owners to obtain approval prior to construction.Â  
  Moreover, the covenants prohibit any fence to exceed five feet in height.Â  The 
  Bishopsâ€™ wall ranges in height from 6.7 feet to 11.7 feet, clearly outside of 
  the permissible limits.Â  
As the Bishops failed to obtain approval prior 
  to building, and the structure exceeds all permissible limits for construction 
  of a fence, ample evidence exists within the record to support the masterâ€™s 
  finding that this structure violates the restrictive covenants.Â  Thus, the master 
  did not err by enforcing the covenants and ordering removal of the wall and 
  all structures within the twenty-foot side setback adjacent to Hookâ€™s property.
III.Â Â Â  Failure to Timely Commence Suit
The Bishops argue the master erred by finding suit 
  was timely commenced because they completed the wall before an action to enjoin 
  them was initiated.Â  Thus, they contend their wall should be deemed conforming.Â  
  We disagree.
â€œA suit seeking an injunction to enforce restrictive 
  covenants is an action in equity.â€Â  Arnoti v. Lukie, 350 S.C. 177, 179, 
  564 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Although equitable remedies are ordinarily 
  left to the sound discretion of the trial court, on appeal of an equitable action 
  tried by the master alone, an appellate court may find facts in accordance with 
  its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Id.; County of 
  Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).
The restrictive covenant at issue provides:

In the event the Grantor, or his nominee shall fail to approve 
  or disapprove within thirty (30) days after plans and specifications have been 
  submitted to the Grantor, or in any event, if no suit to enjoin the construction 
  has been commenced prior to the completion thereof, approval will not be required 
  and the related covenants shall be deemed to have been fully complied with.Â Â  


It is undisputed Hook immediately objected upon 
  learning of the wall, and attempts were made between the parties and Developer 
  to reach an amicable solution.Â  However, during these negotiations and while 
  on notice of Hookâ€™s objections, the Bishops continued to build the wall.Â  Furthermore, 
  by Mr. Bishopâ€™s own testimony, the wall was not yet complete at the time of 
  trial.Â  Bishop testified his plans include installing thirty-two-inch-high wrought-iron 
  brackets between the nine pillars capping the wall and topping the pillars with 
  one-foot tall brass lanterns.Â  
As the evidence in the record indicates the wall 
  was not yet complete at the time of trial, the master did not err by finding 
  suit was timely commenced.
IV.Â Â Â  Balancing of Equities
The Bishops argue the master erred by failing to 
  properly balance the equities between the parties.Â  We disagree.
â€œA court does not automatically issue a mandatory 
  injunction once it finds a restrictive covenant has been violated.Â  The court 
  must balance the equities between the parties; and if the harm to the defendant 
  outweighs the plaintiffâ€™s benefit, no relief will be granted.â€Â  Sea Pines, 
  294 S.C. at 274, 363 S.E.2d at 896 (citing Hunnicutt v. Rickenbaker, 
  268 S.C. 511, 515-516, 234 S.E.2d 887, 889 (1977)).Â  Although the issuance of 
  a mandatory injunction requires a balancing of the equities between the parties, 
  the decision of whether to issue such relief rests in the courtâ€™s sound discretion.Â  
  Sea Pines, 294 S.C. at 274, 363 S.E.2d at 896.
However, injunctions are routinely granted even 
  though the injunctive remedy may cause economic hardship to the defendant.Â  
  Sea Pines, 294 S.C. at 275, 363 S.E.2d at 896.Â  Furthermore, â€œa restrictive 
  covenant will be enforced irrespective of the amount of damage which will result 
  from the breach, and even though there is no substantial monetary damage to 
  the complainant by reason of the violation.Â  The amount of damages and even 
  the fact that the Plaintiff has sustained no pecuniary damages are totally immaterial.â€Â  
  Houck, 316 S.C. at 419, 450 S.E.2d at 109.Â  A court of equity will issue 
  an injunction when it is necessary to prevent an individual from violating the 
  equitable rights of another where he has notice, actual or constructive, of 
  such rights.Â  Sprouse v. Winston, 212 S.C. 176, 185, 46 S.E.2d 874, 878 
  (1948).Â  
The evidence presented at trial shows the removal 
  cost of the retaining wall would be $20,000.00, while the cost to rebuild the 
  wall outside of the twenty-foot side setback area would be between $60,000.00 
  and $80,000.00.Â  The Bishops also assert the removal of the wall would diminish 
  their ability to use the existing garage.Â  However, the master found this expense 
  is incurred solely by the Bishopsâ€™ actions in willfully proceeding to build 
  the wall while on notice of Hookâ€™s objections.Â  
In contrast to the harm caused by having to move 
  the retaining wall, the Bishops argue Hook has suffered no damage as a result 
  of the wall.Â  However, the master found Hookâ€™s property had substantially 
  diminished in value due to the breach of the covenants by the Bishops.Â  Without 
  issuance of an injunction, this harm would be irreparable.Â  Thus, the only remedy 
  available to restore Hook to the position she was in prior to the violation 
  is an injunction.Â  Â Â 
Furthermore, upon review of the record, it appears 
  the master, in balancing the equities, weighed heavily that Bishop proceeded 
  to build while on notice of Hookâ€™s objections.Â  The record clearly supports 
  the masterâ€™s finding that equity favors Hook, and thus, the master did not abuse 
  his discretion by issuing the mandatory injunction.Â  See Arnoti, 
  350 S.C. at 183, 564 S.E.2d at 694 (â€œ[W]hile removal . . . will result in a 
  hardship to the [plaintiffs], it was caused by [their] own actions in knowingly 
  failing to either comply with the restrictions of the subdivision or seek, through 
  proper means, an amendment of the restrictions.â€ ).
  V.              
Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
   
The Bishops argue the master erred by allowing 
  Hook to recover attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
It is well settled in South Carolina 
  that attorneyâ€™s fees are recoverable only when authorized by contract or statute.Â  
  Baron Data Systems, Inc., v. Loter, 297 S.C. 382, 383, 377 S.E.2d 296, 
  297 (1989).Â  â€œWhere there is a contract, the award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left 
  to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  an abuse of discretion is shown.â€Â  Baron Data Systems, 297 S.C. at 384, 
  377 S.E.2d at 297; see also Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 
  365, 384 S.E.2d 741, 748, (1989) (â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs is 
  a discretionary matter not to be overturned absent abuse by the trial court.â€)
The restrictive covenants allow Grantorâ€™s 
  nominee to collect reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and all other expenses incurred 
  by the nominee in any legal action.Â  The master found Wilkins effectively assigned 
  Hook his rights to enforce the covenants against the Bishops.Â  As the assignment 
  transfers â€œall rights, power, and authority to enforce this particular covenant,â€ 
  the right to recover fees and costs was also transferred.Â  Thus, the master 
  did not abuse his discretion in awarding Hook attorneyâ€™s fees and costs as incurred 
  in this action.
CONCLUSION
Â For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  master is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1]  â€œGrantorâ€ is Spence Plantation Phase III Limited Partnership, of 
    which RPW Development is the general managing partner.Â  

 
   
    [2]  At present, the wall ranges in height from 6.7 feet to 11.7 feet, 
    and is 104 feet long.Â  It sits approximately eleven feet from Hookâ€™s property 
    line.Â  Although, the majority of the wall runs parallel to Hookâ€™s property 
    line, an additional segment of the wall extends perpendicularly from the side 
    of the Bishopsâ€™ house to within six inches of Hookâ€™s property line.Â  

 
   [3]  The pool is located approximately ten feet from 
    Hookâ€™s property line. 

 
   
    [4]  The master found the assignment was made by Wilkins, as both general 
    managing partner of the Grantor and as Grantorâ€™s nominee.Â  Pursuant to this 
    covenant, the right to designate other individuals to serve as nominees to 
    enforce the restrictive covenants is reserved by the Grantor.Â  Therefore, 
    the assignment was valid as made by Wilkins in his capacity as the general 
    managing partner of the Grantor.Â  Furthermore, the master finds the right 
    to enforce the covenants is also assignable by Wilkins as Grantorâ€™s nominee, 
    and that Wilkins, in his capacity as Grantorâ€™s nominee, effectively made a 
    partial assignment of his right to enforce the covenants.Â

Submitted December 23, 2003 â€“ Filed March 2, 2004 


APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III , Office of Appellate

Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh,Â  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,

PER CURIAM:Â  Connie Brown (Appellant) was 
  convicted of two counts of murder, two counts of lynching, and one count of 
  criminal conspiracy.Â  She was sentenced to concurrent terms of life in prison 
  for the murders, twenty years on each lynching charge, and five years for criminal 
  conspiracy.
On appeal, counsel for Appellant has filed a final 
  brief along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Appellant has filed 
  a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant 
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s 
  petition to be relieved.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
GOOSLBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
