THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David Thomas Walters,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Margaret Smith Walters,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Walter B. Brown, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-153
Submitted November 3, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  9, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Walter B. Todd and J. Derrick Jackson, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Gene Trotter, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this domestic action, 
  David Thomas Walters (â€œHusbandâ€) sued Margaret Smith Walters (â€œWifeâ€) for divorce 
  and equitable distribution of marital property.Â  The family court granted the 
  divorce, divided the marital property, and awarded Wife alimony and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  Husband appeals, arguing the alimony award was excessive, the classification 
  of certain personal property as non-marital was erroneous, the modification 
  of the property distribution was made sua sponte, and the award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to Wife was improper.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife were married in July 1976.Â  They 
  have two children, an emancipated son and a daughter in her final year of college.Â  

In July 2000, Husband filed an action for divorce 
  and equitable distribution of marital property.Â  The court issued a temporary 
  order, requiring Husband to pay alimony to Wife.Â  In March 2001, Husband was 
  held in contempt of the courtâ€™s order requiring payment of temporary alimony 
  to Wife.Â  
In March 2002, the family court issued a divorce 
  decree imputing $150,000 annual income to Husband, ordering Husband to pay $3,000 
  per month permanent periodic alimony and $10,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  and dividing the marital estate.Â  Both Husband and Wife filed timely motions 
  to reconsider pursuant to Rule 59(e), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  
  The family court denied Husbandâ€™s request for re-hearing on the issues of imputed 
  income, alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, the family court altered the 
  distribution of property to award Wife a linen press initially granted to Husband. [1] Â  Husband appeals.Â  Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[A]n appellate court reviewing a family court 
  order may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of 
  the evidence.â€Â  Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 79, 535 S.E.2d 913, 917 
  (2000).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require an appellate court 
  to disregard the findings of the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses 
  and was in a better position to evaluate credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to the testimony.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 
  393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œ[W]hen an appellate court chooses to find facts 
  in accordance with its own view of the evidence, the court must state distinctly 
  its findings of fact and the reason for its decision.â€Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 
  351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony
Husband argues the family courtâ€™s 
  award to Wife of $3,000 per month permanent periodic alimony was excessive because: 
  1) the court improperly imputed income to Husband; 2) it was based on Wifeâ€™s 
  inflated expenses; 3) it was based on a lifestyle neither party could afford; 
  and 4) it serves as a disincentive for Wife to improve her employment.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion 
  of the family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  
  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 
  2001).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the court is controlled by some 
  error of law or where the order, based upon factual findings, is without evidentiary 
  support.â€Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 485, 477 S.E.2d 727, 729 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  
Alimony is a substitute for the support which is 
  normally incident to the marital relationship.Â  Nienow v. Nienow, 268 
  S.C. 161, 171, 232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977).Â  â€œOrdinarily, the purpose of alimony 
  is to place the supported spouse, as nearly as practical, in the position of 
  support . . . enjoyed during the marriage.â€Â  Johnson v. JohnsonÂ­, 296 
  S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  However, alimony should 
  not serve as a disincentive for a spouse to improve his or her employment potential 
  or to dissuade the spouse from providing, to the extent possible, for his or 
  her own support.Â  Id. at 303, 372 S.E.2d at 115.Â Â Â Â  
In determining an alimony award, the family court must consider the following 
  factors: (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of 
  the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history 
  and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during 
  the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; 
  (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) equitable 
  apportionment; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) 
  tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) any other factors 
  the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2002).Â  No 
  one factor is considered dispositive.Â  Lide v. Lide, 277 S.C. 155, 157, 
  283 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1981).Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Imputed Income
Husband argues the family court erred by imputing 
  $150,000 annual income to him.Â  We disagree.
Courts â€œwill closely scrutinize the facts of any 
  case wherein aÂ Â Â  husband . . . voluntarily changes employment so as to lessen 
  his earning capacity and, in turn, his ability to pay alimony . . . .â€Â  Camp 
  v. Camp, 269 S.C. 173, 174, 236 S.E.2d 814, 815 (1977).Â  â€œ[I]f the obligor 
  spouse has the ability to earn more income than he is in fact earning, the court 
  may impute income according to what he could earn by using his or her best efforts 
  to gain employment equal to his capabilities, and an award of alimony based 
  on such imputation may be a proper exercise of discretion even if it exhausts 
  the obligor spouseâ€™s actual income.â€Â  
Dixon v. Dixon, 334 S.C. 222, 240, 512 S.E.2d 539, 548 
  (Ct. App. 1999). When considering actual income versus earning capacity, the 
  family courtâ€™s responsibility is to closely examine the payorâ€™s good faith and 
  reasonable explanation for the decreased income.Â  Kelley, 324 S.C. at 
  489, 477 S.E.2d at 731.Â  
During the marriage, Husband and Wife were joint 
  owners of a family business, the Walters Company.Â  Husband is also a fifty-percent 
  owner of Carolina Service Group, but reported he does not receive any income 
  from this business.Â  However, the family court found Husbandâ€™s testimony concerning 
  his income was not credible.
Husband was employed by the Walters Company at 
  the time the divorce action was filed.Â  For purposes of the temporary hearing, 
  Husband reported his income as $16,045 per month.Â  Conversely, at trial his 
  financial declaration indicated his income was only $4,418 per month.Â  Husband 
  testified his income decreased because the Walters Company lost an account that 
  constituted sixty-percent of the companyâ€™s income.Â  In his cross-examination 
  testimony, however, Husband stated the business had not lost any accounts and 
  suffered no adverse conditions other than the divorce and the effects from the 
  attacks on September 11, 2001.Â  
We conclude the discrepancies in Husbandâ€™s testimony 
  regarding his income and the financial standing of the Walters Company, coupled 
  with his inability to provide a reasonable explanation for his reported decrease 
  in income, support the family courtâ€™s determination that Husbandâ€™s testimony 
  was not credible. [2] Â  Therefore, 
  we agree with the decision of the family court to disregard Husbandâ€™s asserted 
  decrease in income and to impute income to him consistent with his historical 
  earnings.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-3-130(C)(4) & 20-3-130(C)(6) 
  (Supp. 2002) (requiring family court to consider â€œthe employment history and 
  earning potential of each spouseâ€ and â€œthe current and reasonably 
  anticipated earnings of both spousesâ€ when 
  awarding alimony) (emphasis added). 
Reviewing the five-year period immediately prior 
  to separation, [3]  the family 
  court found the Walters Company income averaged $183,000, 
  [4]  and imputed income to Husband in the amount of $150,000 per year. [5] Â  As these findings are supported 
  by the record, we conclude the family court did not abuse its discretion by 
  imputing $150,000 annual income to Husband.Â  
B.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wifeâ€™s Expenses
Husband argues the family court erred by awarding 
  $3,000 per month permanent periodic alimony to Wife based on inflated expenses 
  reported by Wife.Â  We disagree.
Although Husband claims that Wifeâ€™s expenses 
  are inflated, he provides no evidence to support this assertion.Â  The family 
  court found, and the evidence supports, Wifeâ€™s reported monthly needs of approximately 
  $3,100 were reasonable.Â  Husbandâ€™s unsubstantiated claim to the contrary raises 
  a question of credibility, and we defer to the family court on this issue.Â  
  See Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 
  445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œBecause the appellate court 
  lacks the opportunity for direct observation of the witnesses, it should accord 
  great deference to trial court findings where matters of credibility are involved.â€).Â  

C.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lifestyle Financed by DebtÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Husband argues the family court erred by awarding 
  $3,000 per month permanent periodic alimony to Wife based on the partiesâ€™ lifestyle 
  maintained during the marriage because it was beyond their means.Â  We disagree.
Husband claims the family 
  court was penalizing him for both partiesâ€™ excessive lifestyle as evidenced 
  by the family courtâ€™s statements â€œthatâ€™s the way he let her liveâ€¦â€ and â€œI made 
  him accept responsibility.â€Â  We disagree with this interpretation.Â  Reviewing 
  these statements in context, the family court was merely responding to Husbandâ€™s 
  assertion that he should not be responsible for paying the debt incurred by 
  the parties during the marriage because he was unaware of Wifeâ€™s expenditures.Â  
  These statements reflect the family courtâ€™s belief that Husband was not only 
  aware of Wifeâ€™s expenditures, but he contributed to the exorbitant amount of 
  debt incurred and should be required to pay a portion of it.Â  
Furthermore, in awarding alimony, the family court 
  expressly considered the relevant factors as set out in South Carolina Code 
  Annotated section 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2002).Â  Specifically, the court considered 
  the unpaid debt incurred by the parties in maintaining their high standard of 
  living during the marriage, the fact the parties were married for twenty-five 
  years, and that Wife is forty-seven years old and earns twelve dollars per hour, 
  while Husband has the ability to earn more than $150,000 per year. 
  [6] Â  
D.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony as a Disincentive
Husband argues the family court erred by awarding 
  $3,000 per month permanent periodic alimony to Wife because it will act as a 
  disincentive for Wife to contribute to her own support.Â  Husband contends Wifeâ€™s 
  failure to seek a better paying job is evidence of her lack of incentive to 
  provide for her own support.Â  
Wife is employed at Blue Cross-Blue Shield, earning 
  twelve dollars per hour.Â  Wife obtained this job in January 2000, shortly before 
  the separation, so the parties would have health insurance.Â  After reviewing 
  Wifeâ€™s monthly income and expenses, the family court found Wifeâ€™s needs of $3,100 
  per month reasonable.Â  The family court also considered the length of the marriage, 
  the age of the parties, and the disparity of income between the parties.Â  Husband 
  admitted that Wife had been a good wife, mother, and homemaker, and that throughout 
  the marriage, he frequently traveled on business while Wife remained home caring 
  for their two children.Â  
Because the lifestyle enjoyed by the parties during 
  their marriage far exceeded $3,000 per month, Wife is forced to contribute to 
  her own support if she is to maintain any semblance of it.Â  As the purpose of 
  alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position of support enjoyed 
  during the marriage, we find Husbandâ€™s argument to be without merit.Â  JohnsonÂ­, 
  296 S.C. at 300, 372 S.E.2d at 113.
We conclude the family court did not abuse its 
  discretion by awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony in the amount of $3,000 
  per month.Â  This amount, together with her own income, should be sufficient 
  to allow Wife to attain some semblance of the lifestyle she enjoyed during the 
  marriage.Â  See JohnsonÂ­, 296 S.C. at 300, 372 S.E.2d at 113 (holding 
  â€œthe purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as nearly as practical, 
  in the position of support she enjoyed during the marriageâ€).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Identification 
  of Marital Property
Husband argues the family court erred 
  by classifying certain personal property as nonmarital.Â  We disagree.Â  
Marital property is â€œall real and personal property 
  which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned 
  as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1) (Supp. 2002).Â  However, â€œproperty acquired by either party 
  by inheritance, devise, bequest, or gift from a party other than the spouseâ€ 
  is considered nonmarital property.Â  Id.Â  Apportionment of marital property 
  is within the discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Greene, 351 S.C. at 340, 569 S.E.2d at 
  399. 
â€œ[N]onmarital property may be transmuted into marital 
  property if it (1) becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable;Â  
  (2) is titled jointly;Â  or (3) is utilized by the parties in support of the 
  marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties 
  to make it marital property.â€Â  Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 106, 
  529 S.E.2d 14, 20 (2000).Â  The spouse claiming transmutation must produce objective 
  evidence demonstrating that, during the marriage, the parties themselves regarded 
  the property as common property of the marriage.Â  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 
  327 S.C. 360, 368, 489 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 1997).Â Â Â  
The property at issue, including a dinette, sterling 
  silver, and childrenâ€™s furniture, were gifts to Wife from her relatives.Â  Husband 
  claims Wifeâ€™s testimony regarding the familyâ€™s use of the property clearly establishes 
  an intent to treat it as marital property.Â  Although this property was used 
  in the marital home, Wife testified she did not intend for it to become marital 
  property.Â  Therefore, the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s conclusion that 
  no transmutation occurred.Â  See Murray v. Murray, 312 S.C. 154, 
  157, 439 S.E.2d 312, 315 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding mere use of separate property, 
  without additional evidence of intent to treat it as marital property, is not 
  sufficient to establish transmutation).Â  Thus, the family court did not err 
  by classifying the property as nonmarital.
III.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Modification
Husband argues the family court erred 
  by modifying the divorce decree sua sponte and awarding Wife the linen 
  press when neither party asked for the relief granted.Â  We disagree.
To preserve an issue raised by an order in response 
  to a post-trial motion, the complainant must make a successive motion to alter 
  or amend the new judgment.Â  See Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 
  311 S.C. 56, 60, 427 S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993) (holding that â€œalthough the appellant 
  learned for the first time upon receiving the order on a post-trial motion that 
  the respondent would be granted certain additional relief, the appellant must 
  move under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment to preserve the 
  record for appealâ€).Â  â€œ[A] second motion for reconsideration is appropriate 
  only if it challenges something that was altered from the original judgment 
  as a result of the initial motion for reconsideration.Â  In such a case, a new 
  judgment has replaced the previous judgment and the party aggrieved by the alteration 
  may move for reconsideration.â€Â  Coward Hund Const. Co., v. Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 1, 3, 518 S.E.2d 
  56, 58 (Ct. App. 1999). 
In her motion for reconsideration, Wife generally 
  asked for a reconsideration of the allocation of personal property.Â  At the 
  hearing, Wifeâ€™s counsel specifically requested that Wife be given the linen 
  press in exchange for crediting Husband for alimony or paying him cash.Â  The 
  family court granted Wifeâ€™s motion to modify the allocation of personal property 
  by awarding Wife the linen press.Â  Although the family court awarded Wife the 
  linen press, it did so in lieu of a refund generated from the return of a cherry 
  secretary to the seller rather than in exchange for alimony credit or cash as 
  requested by Wife.Â  Husband contends, by providing this unrequested relief, 
  the family court modified the divorce decree sua sponte.Â  
However, Husband did not object or make a motion 
  for reconsideration in response to the new allocation of property judgment.Â  
  As Husband failed to make a motion for reconsideration from this ruling, this 
  issue is not preserved for appellate review. See Coward Hund Const. Co., 336 S.C. at 3, 518 S.E.2d at 
  58 (holding a second motion for reconsideration is necessary if it challenges 
  something that was altered from the original judgment as a result of the initial 
  motion for reconsideration).Â  
IV.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband contends the family court erred 
  by requiring him to pay $10,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is left to 
  the discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Smith v. Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 
  232, 234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The factors to be considered in awarding reasonable 
  attorney fees and costs include the:Â  (1) nature, extent, and difficulty of 
  the case;Â  (2) time necessarily devoted to the case;Â  (3) professional standing 
  of counsel;Â  (4) contingency of compensation;Â  (5) beneficial results obtained;Â  
  and (6) customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991).
In considering the award of attorney fees, the 
  family court found that Wifeâ€™s attorney is a long-standing practitioner in the 
  family court, beneficial results were obtained, the fees were reasonable in 
  relation to the complexity of the case, and there was a substantial disparity 
  of income between the parties.Â  In light of the factors enumerated in Glasscock, 
  the family court did not abuse its discretion by awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the family court is 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   [1]  Husband did not file a motion to reconsider this 
    ruling.Â  

 
   
    [2]  The family court also noted that Husband claimed only one-half of 
    the Walters Company net income in 2000 ($58,000), reporting the other one-half 
    as income to Wife, due to her ownership interest in the company.Â  However, 
    no distribution of the income was made to Wife and Husband retained the entire 
    $116,000 income.

 
   
    [3]  Husband argues the family court erred by considering outdated and 
    unreliable income figures for the Walters Company from the years 1995 through 
    1999.Â  He argues these figures are unreliable but gives no basis for the assertion 
    other than they were five years old at the time of trial.Â  However, the family 
    court concluded the recent figures reported by Husband were unreliable and 
    we agree with this conclusion.Â  Thus, we see no error in the consideration 
    of the income reported by the Walters Company over the five-year period in 
    question.

 
   
    [4]  Husband argues the family court erred in calculating the Walters 
    Company income for this five-year period.Â  The family court found the average 
    gross income for the years 1995-1999 was $183,000.Â  Conversely, Husband claims 
    the actual average for this time period was $164,460.Â  However, the family 
    court only imputed $150,000 to Husband as annual income.Â  Assuming, without 
    deciding, the family court erred in its calculation, the imputation of $150,000 
    annual income is still well below Husbandâ€™s calculation of the average income 
    for this time period.Â  Thus, we find no reversible error.

 
   [5]  In addition to this income, the family court concluded 
    that Husband owns a fifty percent share of Carolina Service Group, Inc., which 
    had gross sales of $900,000 in the year 2000.

 
   
    [6]  Husband argues the family court failed to consider his expenses in 
    relation to his earning capacity.Â  However, the family court order is replete 
    with evidence of the courtâ€™s consideration of both partiesâ€™ income and expenses.Â  
    Therefore, we find this argument to be without merit.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN NAY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Mappin Industries, Inc., and Roberta L.
Mappin,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Larry V. Mullins and CMC & Associates,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-154
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  9, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
D. GarrisonÂ  Hill, of Greenville, for Appellants.
W. Howard Boyd, Jr. and Fred W. Suggs, III, both of Greenville, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This case involves a change 
  of life insurance beneficiary form executed but not received by the insurance 
  companyâ€™s home office before the insuredâ€™s death.Â  The owners of the policy 
  brought this action against the insurance broker responsible for delivering 
  the change of beneficiary form, alleging his failure constituted breach of contract 
  and negligence.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the broker.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1997, Mappin Industries obtained a 
  loan from SouthTrust Bank.Â  Roberta Mappin, the sole shareholder of Mappin Industries, 
  signed for the loan, and Charles Theodore, a business associate of both Roberta 
  and her husband George, cosigned for the loan.Â  As a condition of the loan, 
  SouthTrust required that Mappin Industries buy insurance policies on the lives 
  of both Roberta and Charles in the amount of one million dollars each.Â  Mappin 
  Industries bought these required policies from First Colony Life Insurance Company 
  through Larry V. Mullins, an insurance broker in Greenville.Â  The proceeds of 
  the polices were assigned to SouthTrust.
Mappin Industriesâ€™ loan was subsequently 
  acquired by Carolina First Bank, which did not require an assignment of life 
  insurance proceeds.Â  However, Mappin Industries continued to pay the premiums 
  on the policies.
In the latter part of 1999, Charles informed 
  the Mappins that he had cancer and requested that they allow his wife, Patricia, 
  to be the beneficiary of a portion of the life insurance policy Mappin Industries 
  had on his life.Â  Pursuant to this conversation, George Mappin, as president 
  of Mappin Industries, executed a First Colony Insurance change of beneficiary 
  form making Roberta Mappin and Patricia Theodore each fifty percent beneficiaries 
  of the policy. The Mappins also testified that they instructed Mullins to obtain 
  a release of the assignment of the policy death benefits from South Trust Bank 
  and obtain an assignment of the proceeds in favor of Carolina First Bank in 
  the amount of $820,000.Â  Thus, in the event of Charlesâ€™ death, Mappin Industriesâ€™ 
  loan from Carolina First would be paid off, and the remaining $180,000 would 
  be split between Roberta Mappin and Patricia Theodore.Â  Mullins testified that 
  he delivered the change of beneficiary form to his administrative assistant, 
  who forwarded the form to First Colony Insurance. However, Mullins denied ever 
  being told to assign proceeds to Carolina First.
On December 1, 1999, another change of 
  beneficiary form was executed by George Mappin.Â  Under this second change, Roberta 
  Mappin was to receive eighty percent of the proceeds under the policy and Patricia 
  Theodore was to receive twenty percent. With this arrangement, upon Charlesâ€™ 
  death, Roberta would receive $800,000, Patricia would receive $200,000, and 
  there was no assignment to the bank.Â  As with the first change, Mullins claims 
  he forwarded the second change form to First Colonyâ€™s home office. 
Charles Theodore died on December 18, 
  1999. On January 6, 2000, Roberta Mappin and Patricia Theodore submitted their 
  claims to Mullins for the one million dollar death benefitâ€”claiming their respective 
  $800,000 and $200,000 shares.Â  Mullins forwarded the claims to First Colony. 

First Colony, however, claimed it had 
  not received the second, December 1, 1999, change form. Due to this discrepancy 
  in its records, First Colony filed a petition of interpleader to determine what 
  share of the proceeds each beneficiary was entitled to receive. First Colony 
  agreed to pay Mappin $500,000 and Theodore $200,000, and paid the disputed $300,000 
  into the court. 
Mappin and Theodore were able to resolve 
  their dispute outside of court, agreeing to a fifty-fifty split of the $300,000.Â  
  The parties also agreed to the entry of a consent order dismissing the interpleader 
  action and releasing First Colony from any further claims. Mullins, however, 
  was excluded from the release of liability. 
Ultimately, Roberta Mappin and Mappin 
  Industries (collectively â€œMappinâ€) brought the present action against Mullins, 
  claiming he had breached his contract and was negligent in failing to ensure 
  that the second change of beneficiary form was received and acknowledged by 
  First Colony. The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Mullins, 
  finding there was no genuine issue of material fact.Â  In its summary judgment 
  order, the trial court also denied Mappinâ€™s motion to amend its complaint to 
  state additional causes of action.Â  Mappin appeals both of these rulings. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court should grant a motion for summary 
  judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Fleming v. Rose, 
  350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  â€œIn determining whether any 
  triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably 
  drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.â€ Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 
  61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  If triable issues of fact exist, those issues 
  must go to the jury. Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 717, 
  511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Motion for Summary Judgment
Mappin argues the trial court erred in granting Mullinsâ€™ 
  motion for summary judgment on the claims for breach of contract and negligence.Â  
  Specifically, Mappin asserts Mullins breached his duty of care under contract 
  and common law by failing to ensure that the change of beneficiary form was 
  received and acknowledged by First Colonyâ€™s home office prior to Charles Theodoreâ€™s 
  death.Â  We disagree.
It is well-settled that â€œ[a]n essential 
  element in a cause of action for negligence is the existence of a legal duty 
  of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff.Â  Without a duty, there is no 
  actionable negligence.â€ Bishop v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 
  79, 86, 502 S.E.2d 78, 81 (1998).Â  As a general rule, â€œinsurance agents and 
  brokers â€˜are required to exercise due care in placing insurance and would be 
  personally liable for the neglect of that duty.â€™â€ Riddle-Duckworth, Inc. 
  v. Sullivan, 253 S.C. 411, 420, 171 S.E.2d 486, 490 (1969) (quoting La 
  Tourette v. McMaster, 104 S.C. 501, 89 S.E. 398 (1916)). 
In the present case, however, Mappin 
  has failed to show any facts indicating Mullins owed a duty to deliver Mappinâ€™s 
  change of beneficiary form prior to Theodoreâ€™s death.Â  On the contrary, under 
  South Carolina law, an insured has effectively changed a beneficiary under a 
  life insurance policy when he has â€œsubstantially complied with the method prescribed 
  by the policy language for changing the beneficiary.â€ Life of Georgia Ins. 
  Co. v. Bolton, 333 S.C. 406, 411, 509 S.E.2d 488, 491 (1998).Â  As in the 
  present case, the plaintiffs in Bolton argued that the failure of the 
  insurance company to receive a change of beneficiary form in its home office 
  rendered the change ineffective. Id. The supreme court rejected this 
  argument, finding the change was effective as of the time the owner or insured 
  executed a change of beneficiary form. Id.Â  
In the present case, the terms of the insurance 
  policy regarding the procedure for executing a change of beneficiary did not 
  require that the form be delivered or acknowledged by First Colonyâ€™s home office 
  in order to be effective.Â  The policy provides, in pertinent part, as follows:

CHANGE OF OWNER AND BENEFICIARY.Â  
  The Owner may change the designations of Owner and Beneficiary during the Insuredâ€™s 
  lifetime.Â  Any change is subject to the consent of an irrevocable beneficiary.Â  
  Written notice of change must be filed at the home office in a form acceptable 
  to the company.Â  The new designation will then take effect as of the date the 
  Owner signed the notice.Â  Such a change does not affect any payment made or 
  other action taken by the Company before the notice is received. 

Although Mullins was required to provide written notice to 
  First Colonyâ€™s home office under this provision, the language did not condition 
  the effectiveness of the change of beneficiary upon First Colonyâ€™s receipt of 
  the form or otherwise mandate delivery of the form within an essential time 
  period.Â  Mullins did not, therefore, have a dutyâ€”under principles of contract 
  or common lawâ€”to ensure First Colony received the change of beneficiary form 
  at its home office prior to Charles Theodoreâ€™s death in order for it to be effective.Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Motion to Amend
Mappin also appeals the trial courtâ€™s 
  denial of its motion to amend its complaint to assert three additional claims.Â  
  Under Rule 15(a), SCRCP, the trial court may grant a party leave to amend a 
  complaint or other pleading and shall do so â€œfreelyâ€ â€œwhen justice so requires 
  and does not prejudice any other party.â€Â  The trial judgeâ€™s finding will not 
  be overturned absent an abuse of discretion or unless manifest injustice has 
  occurred. Berry v. McCloud, 328 S.C. 435, 450, 492 S.E.2d 794, 802 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Mappinâ€™s 
  motion to amend.
In its motion to amend, Mappin first 
  sought to assert a new claim alleging Mullins was negligent in failing to obtain 
  an assignment of the policy in favor of Carolina First Bank.Â  Mappin had requested 
  Mullins make this assignment following the November 11, 1999, conference at 
  which George Mappin executed the first change of beneficiary form.Â  As both 
  Roberta and George Mappin acknowledged in their deposition testimony, however, 
  this agreement was superseded by the December 1, 1999, agreement under which 
  Mappin and Charles Theodore agreed to provide $200,000 from the death benefits 
  to Patricia Theodore.Â  In light of this agreementâ€”which gave rise to the need 
  for the second change of beneficiaryâ€”George and Roberta Mappin testified they 
  no longer wished to have the assignment made in favor of the bank.Â  By the Mappinsâ€™ 
  own testimony, therefore, the question of whether Mullins was negligent in failing 
  to obtain an assignment of the insurance proceeds in favor of the bank is wholly 
  irrelevant to the present case.
Next, Mappin asked the trial court to add a claim 
  that Mullins should be barred by res judicata and collateral estoppel 
  from taking a position contrary to the position taken by First Colony in the 
  interpleader action.Â  This request is also without merit.
Res judicata bars subsequent actions 
  by the same parties when the claims arise out of the same transaction or occurrence 
  that was the subject of a prior action between these parties.Â  Nelson v. 
  QHG of S.C. Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 304, 580 S.E.2d 171, 178 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
  Likewise, the doctrine of collateral estoppel precludes relitigation of claims 
  in subsequent suits involving the same parties or those in privity with the 
  previous parties. Carrigg v. Cannon, 347 S.C. 75, 79-80, 552 S.E.2d 767, 
  770 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding that â€œ[u]nder the doctrine of collateral estoppel, 
  once a final judgment on the merits has been reached in a prior claim, the relitigation 
  of those issues actually and necessarily litigated and determined in the first 
  suit are precluded as to the parties and their privies in any subsequent action 
  based upon a different claimâ€ (internal quotation marks omitted)).
In the present case, Mullins was not a party to the 
  interpleader action initiated by First Colony.Â  Nor can it be argued that Mullins 
  was in privity with any party to that action, as demonstrated by the fact that 
  Mullins was specifically excluded from the settlement reached in the interpleader 
  action.Â  Therefore, Mappinâ€™s attempt to argue that Mullins is now barred from 
  asserting his affirmative defenses in the instant action is manifestly without 
  merit.
Finally, Mappin sought to amend its complaint to request 
  additional damages to compensate for the attorneyâ€™s fees and costs it incurred 
  in defending the interpleader action.Â  As discussed above, however, Mullins 
  breached no duty under contract or common law which gave rise to the interpleader 
  action.Â  The fees and costs were incurred solely by reason of First Colonyâ€™s 
  wrongful refusal to honor the second change of beneficiary form which was executed 
  on December 1, 1999.Â  Accordingly, there is no basis under the applicable South 
  Carolina law to allow Mappin to recover the fees and costs incurred in defending 
  the interpleader action.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the trial court properly granted 
  summary judgment in favor of Mullins, finding no evidence of any duty owed under 
  contract or common law theories of recovery.Â  Additionally, we find the trial 
  court did not abuse its discretion in denying Mappinâ€™s motion to amend.Â  The 
  ruling of the trial court is therefore
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Norris Samuel Law, III,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Penny Jean Morris Law,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Robert R. Mallard, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-155
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  9, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED


  
    
      
David L. DeVane, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Margaret D. Fabri, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Norris Samuel Law, 
  III (Father) brought an action against Penny Jean Morris Law (Mother) alleging 
  several changes in circumstances that would justify a change in custody of their 
  daughter.Â  The family court judge granted custody to Father with visitation 
  to Mother every other weekend, alternating holidays, and one month in the summer.Â  
  Mother appeals.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Mother and Father separated 
  in June of 1997 and entered into an agreement concerning the custody of their 
  then two-year-old daughter, Grayson.Â  The agreement provided they would share 
  joint legal custody of Grayson, with Mother having primary physical custody 
  and Father having secondary physical custody with â€œliberal rights of visitation.â€Â  
  The parties also agreed that neither Mother nor Father would have the minor 
  child in their home if a paramour was visiting overnight.Â  The parties divorced 
  in September of 1997 and incorporated the agreement into their final decree 
  of divorce.Â  
At some time near the end of 1997, Father 
  began living with his girlfriend, Jennifer, whom he married in January 1999.Â  
  Mother also began living with her boyfriend, Jason Belcher, during 1997.Â  Mother 
  later married Mr. Belcher on August 22, 2000.Â  From 1997 to August 2000, Mother 
  and Father shared custody of Grayson on nearly a fifty-fifty basis.Â  Initially, 
  Mother had physical custody of Grayson one week and Father had physical custody 
  the next week.Â  At some point in 1998, Mother proposed a modified visitation 
  schedule, and the parties agreed to Grayson alternating three days with Mother 
  and two days with Father.Â  
According to Father, Mother attempted 
  to change the visitation schedule every three months or so.Â  Father testified 
  that in order to ensure he had time with Grayson, he would pay more money for 
  daycare or dance class, in addition to his child support obligation.Â  In September 
  1999, Mother sent Father a letter in which she attempted to change Fatherâ€™s 
  visitation to every other Friday through Monday.Â  Mother also set forth Fatherâ€™s 
  different payment obligations and informed Father she would be performing all 
  â€œmotheringâ€ duties, such as taking Grayson for doctor visits, buying clothes, 
  and making decisions regarding Graysonâ€™s extracurricular activities.Â  Following 
  this letter, the parties ultimately compromised on an alternative visitation 
  schedule giving Father three weekends plus one week with Grayson every month.Â  
  However, in August of 2000, Mother phoned Father and notified him that because 
  Grayson was beginning elementary school his visitation would be limited to every 
  other weekend.Â  Father tape recorded this telephone conversation. Â 
On August 21, 2000, Father filed this 
  action alleging a substantial change in circumstances supporting a change in 
  custody and seeking an emergency ex parte order of custody.Â  Father 
  pled, in the alternative, for joint custody of Grayson, with the non-custodial 
  parent to have liberal rights of visitation which he defined as â€œa minimum of 
  fifty percent (50%) of the time, temporarily and permanently.â€Â  Mother counterclaimed 
  for sole custody.Â  An ex parte order granted custody to Father 
  on August 21, 2000, and a hearing was set for August 23, 2000.Â  At the hearing, 
  Father was granted temporary custody.Â  Motherâ€™s motion for a stay of the temporary 
  order and petition for supersedeas were denied.Â  
At the final merits hearing in June 2001, 
  Mother objected on several occasions to Fatherâ€™s attorneyâ€™s line of questioning, 
  arguing that because this was an action for a change of custody rather than 
  a de novo proceeding, Father should not be permitted to introduce 
  any evidence other than that relating to the alleged changes in circumstances.Â  
  The family court judge admitted the testimony, finding it relevant.Â  In addition, 
  a transcript of the August 2000 telephone conversation was admitted at the hearing 
  over Motherâ€™s objection.Â  The family court issued a final order on September 
  28, 2001, granting sole custody to Father, with visitation for Mother to include 
  alternating weekends, alternating holidays, and one month in the summer.Â  Mother 
  appeals.Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Decisions affecting the custody 
  of a child are matters left principally to the discretion of the family court.Â Â  
  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 
  2000).Â  However, in appeals from the family court, this court has the authority 
  to find facts in accordance with our view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 335, 569 S.E.2d 393, 397 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  This broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of 
  the family court.Â  Id.Â  Nor does it require us to ignore the fact that 
  the family court judge, â€œwho saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position 
  to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  
  Id. (citation omitted).Â  An appellate court should be reluctant to substitute 
  its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the family court.Â  
  Shirley, 342 S.C. at 331, 536 S.E.2d at 430.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Custody
In arguing the family court erred in 
  awarding custody to the Father, Mother asserts that the court incorrectly treated 
  this case as a de novo custody dispute instead of a change of 
  custody dispute.Â  See Allison v. Eudy, 330 S.C. 427, 429, 499 
  S.E.2d 227, 228 (Ct. App. 1998) (stating that a finding in the family courtâ€™s 
  order denying a motion for reconsideration that â€œâ€˜the scales tip in [the non-movantâ€™s 
  favor],â€™â€ indicated the family court incorrectly treated the change in custody 
  action as a de novo custody dispute).Â  We disagree.Â  
In all child custody cases, the paramount 
  considerations are the childâ€™s welfare and best interests.Â  Hollar v. Hollar, 
  342 S.C. 463, 472, 536 S.E.2d 883, 888 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The party seeking a 
  change in custody assumes the burden of proof and must show changed circumstances 
  occurring subsequent to the entry of the original custody order that substantially 
  affect the interest and welfare of the child.Â  See id. at 473, 
  536 S.E.2d at 888.Â  In determining a change in custody, the family court should 
  consider how the custody decision will impact all areas of the childâ€™s life 
  and must assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness and attitude as they impact 
  the child.Â  Shirley, 342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430.Â Â  â€œâ€˜There are 
  no hard and fast rules for determining when to change custody and the totality 
  of the circumstances peculiar to each case constitutes the only scale upon which 
  the ultimate decision can be weighed.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Davenport v. 
  Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975)).Â  In order to 
  determine whether a change in circumstances has been shown, the court must consider 
  the facts leading up to and surrounding the present controversy.Â  Stutz v. 
  Funderburk, 272 S.C. 273, 277, 252 S.E.2d 32, 34 (1979).Â  The usual factors 
  family courts consider in determining the best interests of children are appropriate 
  considerations.Â  Glanton v. Glanton, 314 S.C. 58, 60 n. 3, 443 S.E.2d 
  810, 811 n.3 (Ct. App. 1994).
In support of Motherâ€™s argument that 
  the family court incorrectly treated this change of custody case as a de 
  novo custody dispute, Mother asks this court to consider, (1) Fatherâ€™s 
  testimony, over Motherâ€™s objection, about Motherâ€™s family background and home 
  life, (2) comments made by the family court judge in a telephone conference, 
  and (3) that the final order mentioned the standard used for a de novo 
  custody case, in addition to the standard for a change in custody case.Â  We 
  do not believe Motherâ€™s assertions are sufficient to find the family court incorrectly 
  treated this case as a de novo custody dispute.Â  
First, the testimony concerning Motherâ€™s 
  family background and home life, which was admitted over Motherâ€™s objections, 
  does not demonstrate that the judge improperly treated the case as a de 
  novo dispute.Â  Rather, the testimony demonstrates that the judge properly 
  admitted evidence related to the childâ€™s best interest and the totality of the 
  circumstances.Â  See Hollar, 342 S.C. at 472-73, 536 S.E.2d at 
  888; Shirley, 342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430.Â  
We likewise reject Motherâ€™s second argument 
  that the family court judgeâ€™s remarks made during a telephone conference that 
  Father presented a better situation do not demonstrate that the case was treated 
  de novo.Â  Initially we note that no transcript of the telephone 
  conference appears in the record.Â  See Bonaparte v. Floyd, 291 
  S.C. 427, 444, 354 S.E.2d 40, 50 (Ct. App. 1987) (stating that the appellant 
  has the burden of furnishing a sufficient record for this courtâ€™s review).Â Â  
  Mother asks this court to consider her attorneyâ€™s restatement of these remarks 
  during a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, hearing as evidence that the family court judge 
  not only made the remarks but that the judge improperly treated the case as 
  a de novo custody dispute.Â  However, it is well settled law that 
  arguments of counsel do not constitute evidence.Â  See e.g. Sosebee 
  v. Leeke, 293 S.C. 531, 535, 362 S.E.2d 22, 24 (1987).Â  Further, these remarks 
  are not reflected in the final change of custody order except in the orderâ€™s 
  consideration of the best interests of the child and the totality of the circumstances.Â Â  
  To the extent that the final order and the judgeâ€™s remarks at the Rule 59(e) 
  hearing are in conflict, the written order controls.Â  See Corbin v. 
  Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 621, 571 S.E.2d 92, 97 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The final 
  order does not improperly use the de novo custody standard in 
  changing custody as Mother argues.Â  Mother is correct in that the order concludes, 
  based on the totality of the circumstances and the best interests of the child, 
  that Father should have the primary, sole custody of Grayson.Â  However, Mother 
  overlooks the courtâ€™s initial determination that â€œFather has shown a substantial 
  change in circumstance since the time of the partiesâ€™ agreement and original 
  custody order which impacts and affects the best interest of the child.â€Â  The 
  order also sets forth several changes in circumstance to support this finding.Â  
  It was only after making this determination that the order addressed the childâ€™s 
  best interests based on the totality of the circumstances.Â  See Hollar, 
  342 S.C. at 472-73, 536 S.E.2d at 888; Shirley, 342 S.C. at 330, 536 
  S.E.2d at 430.Â  
Mother also argues that the family court 
  erred in awarding custody to Father because Father failed to show a substantial 
  change in circumstances materially affecting the best interests of the child.Â  
  Father alleged three changes in circumstance warranting a change in custody, 
  including: (1) Motherâ€™s unilateral decision to change Fatherâ€™s visitation, (2) 
  Fatherâ€™s remarriage and Graysonâ€™s close relationship with his new wife, and 
  (3) Motherâ€™s cohabitation with her boyfriend in violation of the prior court 
  order.Â Â  The family court judge changed custody to Father based on the totality 
  of the circumstances, including all three of the changed circumstances asserted 
  by Father.Â  We affirm the family court order changing custody to the Father 
  based on Motherâ€™s decision to significantly reduce Fatherâ€™s visitation with 
  Grayson.
In order to grant a change of custody, the 
  party seeking the change bears the burden of showing changed circumstances occurring 
  subsequent to the entry of the original custody decree.Â  Kisling v. Allison, 
  343 S.C. 674, 679, 541 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Shirley, 
  342 S.C. at 330, 536 S.E.2d at 430).Â  The change in circumstance relied on must 
  be one that would substantially affect the interest and welfare of the child, 
  not merely the wishes or convenience of the parties.Â  Id. at 679, 541 
  S.E.2d at 275-76.
It was error for the family court judge 
  to consider Motherâ€™s live-in relationship to be a change of circumstances.Â  
  â€œA parentâ€™s morality, while a proper factor for consideration, â€˜is limited in 
  its force to what relevancy it has, either directly or indirectly, to the welfare 
  of the child.â€™â€Â  Stroman v. Williams, 291 S.C. 376, 378, 353 S.E.2d 704, 
  705 (Ct. App. 1987) (citation omitted) (finding no material change in circumstances 
  occurred from motherâ€™s live-in relationship with lesbian partner where childâ€™s 
  welfare was not adversely affected).Â  In the present case, there is no evidence 
  showing Grayson was adversely affected by Mother and Stepfather living together 
  prior to marriage.Â  In fact, Father agreed that both Mother and Stepfather are 
  positive influences in Graysonâ€™s life, and the Stepfather has â€œassisted as [a 
  stepparent] in raising her, nurturing her, and attending to her needs.â€Â  In 
  addition, Father has had knowledge of Motherâ€™s cohabitation since 1997, and 
  Father himself cohabitated with his present wife prior to their marriage in 
  1999.Â  
Further, any adverse affect Motherâ€™s 
  cohabitation may have had on her moral fitness was remedied by Motherâ€™s subsequent 
  marriage to her boyfriend.Â  See Sealy v. Sealy, 295 S.C. 281, 
  284, 368 S.E.2d 85, 87 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œ[R]emarriage which restores â€˜moral 
  fitnessâ€™ has been recognized as a factor to be considered in awarding change 
  of custody.â€); Baer v. Baer, 282 S.C. 362, 365, 318 S.E.2d 582, 583 (Ct. 
  App. 1984) (finding motherâ€™s marriage to her paramour reinstated her moral fitness).Â  
  Finally, we do not see any merit to Fatherâ€™s argument that Motherâ€™s remarriage 
  demonstrated her lack of judgment because it occurred two days before the emergency 
  hearing.Â  Mother obviously intended to marry her boyfriend prior to Father filing 
  the present action, as evidenced by the fact that a marriage license was acquired 
  ten days prior to the filing.Â  There is no evidence to suggest that the timing 
  of Motherâ€™s remarriage materially affected the best interest and welfare of 
  Grayson.Â  See Baer, 282 S.C. at 365, 318 S.E.2d at 584 (finding 
  no evidence to show that motherâ€™s sudden marriage substantially affected the 
  welfare of the children).
Moreover, although the consent order 
  prohibited Mother or Father from cohabiting with a member of the opposite sex 
  while Grayson was present, â€œ[t]he court may not award or change custody to punish 
  a parent for acting in violation of the orders of the court.â€Â  Smith v. Smith, 
  261 S.C. 81, 85, 198 S.E.2d 271, 273 (1973).Â  See also Stroman, 
  291 S.C. atÂ  378, 353 S.E.2d at 705 (â€œCustody is not to be used to penalize 
  or reward a parent for his or her conduct.â€).Â  In this case, it appears the 
  family court judge placed an unnecessary emphasis on Motherâ€™s cohabitation.Â  
  After Stepfatherâ€™s redirect examination at the merits hearing, the family court 
  judge questioned Stepfather regarding the relationship he and Mother had with 
  their next-door neighbors, Charlie and Margie Creech, parents of the Honorable 
  Wayne M. Creech.Â  The judge asked, â€œDo you have anything to do with Judge Creechâ€™s 
  parents?â€Â  In response to Stepfatherâ€™s answer that the Creeches visited quite 
  often, the judge replied, â€œIâ€™m surprised to hear that.Â  Because I wouldnâ€™t think 
  he would have anything to do with anybody thatâ€™s living together without benefit 
  of marriage as straight-laced as he is and she is and Judge Creech is.Â  Iâ€™m 
  surprised they would have anything to do without [sic] anybody thatâ€™s living 
  together without the benefit of marriage.â€Â  The judgeâ€™s focus on this issue 
  continued when he questioned Margie Creech:

THE COURT: You gave an affidavit here and [it is] dated August 
  the 22nd in the year 2000.Â  If you would have known that [Mother 
  and Stepfather] were not married, would you have given that affidavit?Â  Would 
  you have given them an affidavit that said: How much you enjoyed them as neighbors 
  . . . .
MARGIE CREECH: Yes, sir, I would have.
THE COURT: Even though they were not married.Â  They were 
  living together without the benefit of marriage and they were bringing their 
  daughter in there, a young child in there?
MARGIE CREECH: Well, I donâ€™t guess that â€“ Iâ€™m not down on 
  anybody because of what they do because, you know, that I donâ€™t agree with it.Â  
  Actually, I pray for them.Â  So, therefore, they were good parents, so thatâ€™s 
  all I could see is say what I see.Â  

We disagree with the emphasis placed on 
  the Motherâ€™s cohabitation prior to her present marriage by the family court 
  judge and with his finding that her cohabitation was a change in circumstances 
  sufficient to warrant a change in custody.Â  
Further, Fatherâ€™s current living 
  situation alone, including his remarriage and Graysonâ€™s relationship with Stepmother, 
  is not sufficient to support a change in custody.Â  See Fisher v. Miller, 
  288 S.C. 576, 578, 344 S.E.2d 149, 150 (1986) (stating remarriage alone is not 
  a substantial change of circumstances).Â  In this particular case, Grayson has 
  known both Stepmother and Stepfather since 1997, when both couples began dating.Â  
  Graysonâ€™s relationship with her Stepmother in itself does not substantially 
  affect her welfare and thus does not qualify as a change in circumstances because 
  the evidence establishes that both Stepparents had been a positive influence 
  on her life for over three years prior to the time Father commenced this litigation.Â  

However, we agree with the family 
  court judgeâ€™s determination that Motherâ€™s unilateral decision to significantly 
  reduce Fatherâ€™s visitation was a substantial change in circumstance materially 
  affecting the best interests and welfare of Grayson.Â  The original divorce decree 
  granted the parties joint custody of Grayson and gave Mother primary physical 
  custody and Father liberal rights of visitation.Â  The decree did not set forth 
  any guidelines as to how the parties should determine visitation nor did it 
  specifically define what liberal visitation would be.Â  Father exercised liberal 
  visitation from 1997 to August 2000.Â  During this time, Mother and Father shared 
  physical custody of Grayson.Â  Mother frequently attempted to change Fatherâ€™s 
  visitation schedule by reducing Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â  On each occasion, the 
  parties successfully negotiated an alternate visitation schedule, which gave 
  Father more time with his daughter.Â  Father testified that he would have to 
  agree to give Mother more money or take on additional expenses in order to have 
  more time with Grayson.Â  However, in August of 2000, Mother phoned Father and 
  notified him that because Grayson had started elementary school his visitation 
  would be limited to every other weekend.Â Â  Based on the transcript of this conversation, 
  Mother was unwilling to negotiate with Father regarding this new schedule and 
  even further reduced Fatherâ€™s access to Graysonâ€™s extracurricular activities 
  when he attempted to negotiate additional time with Grayson.Â  
Mother argues there is no evidence 
  in the record to show that her proposed visitation change negatively impacted 
  Grayson.Â  However, contrary to Motherâ€™s assertion, the requirement that the 
  party seeking to change custody must show a change of circumstances affecting 
  the interests and welfare of the child does not require a finding of a present 
  existing injury to the child.Â  See Routh v. Routh, 328 S.C. 512, 
  520, 492 S.E.2d 415, 419 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Rather, â€œ[a]n existing unhealthy 
  environment that is likely to impact on the child in the future, affects the 
  welfare of the child.â€Â  Id. at 520, 492 S.E.2d at 420.Â Â  In this case, 
  Mother has made repeated attempts to diminish Fatherâ€™s time with Grayson despite 
  the decree awarding the parties joint custody and the Father liberal visitation.Â  
  Motherâ€™s final proposal of visitation every other weekend suggested a significant 
  reduction in the time Grayson had been spending with Father.Â  It is uncontroverted 
  that Grayson was thriving under the previous visitation schedule, which allowed 
  her to see Father nearly fifty percent of the time.Â  The Motherâ€™s new proposed 
  visitation schedule provided for visitation with Father only every other weekend 
  and would significantly limit Fatherâ€™s ability to be an active and positive 
  influence in Graysonâ€™s life.Â  Further, the transcript of the tape recorded telephone 
  conversation demonstrates that Mother was unwilling to compromise on the issue 
  and even suggested that Mother retaliated against Father by further reducing 
  his visitation.Â  As such, we find Motherâ€™s decision to significantly reduce 
  Fatherâ€™s visitation with Grayson substantially affected the welfare and best 
  interest of the child and constituted a change in circumstance warranting a 
  change in custody to Father.Â  See Watson v. Poole, 329 S.C. 232, 
  239, 495 S.E.2d 236, 240 (Ct. App. 1997) (changing custody to father based in 
  part on motherâ€™s unwillingness to facilitate the childâ€™s visitation with father 
  and arbitrarily canceling fatherâ€™s visitation);Â  Morehouse v. Morehouse, 
  317 S.C. 222, 226-27, 452 S.E.2d 632, 634-35 (Ct. App. 1994) (upholding an award 
  of custody to father where mother was unwilling to encourage a relationship 
  between the child and father).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Motherâ€™s Visitation
Mother argues the family court erred in 
  restricting her visitation to every other weekend, alternating holidays, and 
  one month in the summer.Â  We agree.
Although we affirm the change in custody 
  to Father due to Motherâ€™s unilateral decision to alter his visitation, we do 
  not believe the evidence supports an award of standard visitation to Mother.Â  
  The welfare and best interests of the child are the primary considerations in 
  determining visitation.Â  Paparella v. Paparella, 340 S.C. 186, 191, 531 
  S.E.2d 297, 300 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The family court has broad discretion to decide 
  visitation issues and its decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an 
  abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  
The type of visitation the judge granted 
  Mother in this case is considered â€œstandardâ€ visitation.Â  See Woodall 
  v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 12, 471 S.E.2d 154, 158 (1996).Â  Although visitation 
  tantamount to divided custody is disfavored, in certain circumstances courts 
  will expand visitation beyond standard.Â  See id. (stating that 
  visitation tantamount to divided custody is avoided).Â  But see 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(42) (Supp. 2003) (â€œThe family court shall have exclusive 
  jurisdiction . . . [t]o order joint or divided custody where the court finds 
  it is in the best interest of the child.â€);Â  Paparella, 340 S.C. at 191, 
  531 S.E.2d at 300 (finding the evidence did not support an award of standard 
  visitation to the father and expanding his visitation).Â  In Paparella, 
  this court granted additional visitation to the father because he was very involved 
  in raising his children and the mother testified she thought father should receive 
  more than just standard visitation.Â  340 S.C. at 191, 531 S.E.2d at 300.Â  Similarly, 
  there is overwhelming evidence in this case, including testimony from all four 
  parents, teachers, family members, and neighbors showing Grayson was thriving 
  on the previous visitation schedule, which allowed her to see both parents virtually 
  equally.Â  Father testified both parents had been very active in Graysonâ€™s life.Â  
  Father also agreed it was healthy for Grayson to see both of her parents at 
  her ballgames and dance recitals.Â  Just as in Paparella, Father stated 
  he thought Mother should receive more than standard visitation.Â  He believed 
  both parents should have â€œliberal accessâ€ to Grayson.Â  He agreed if he were 
  in Motherâ€™s position, alternating weekends would not be fair.Â  Father even agreed 
  that the standard visitation would be detrimental to Graysonâ€™s well-being and 
  that all four parents should have equal access to her.Â  In fact, Father pled, 
  in the alternative, for a continuation of the joint custody arrangement the 
  parties had previously enjoyed.Â  
Mother testified she wanted the visitation 
  arrangement to go back to the way it was before she changed it, where both Mother 
  and Father spent equal amounts of time with Grayson.Â  Mother admitted it was 
  a mistake for her to change the schedule.Â  Referring to the every other weekend 
  visitation schedule, she stated, â€œI donâ€™t believe itâ€™s healthy for anyone to 
  be away from their child for that long,â€ and that standard visitation is not 
  in Graysonâ€™s best interests.Â  
In addition to the testimony of family and 
  friends, the guardian ad litem testified that it would be in Graysonâ€™s best 
  interests for her to spend time equally at each of her parentâ€™s homes.Â  
Based on the above, we reverse the family 
  courtâ€™s order granting standard visitation to Mother.Â  While Father remains 
  the primary, sole custodian, we find Mother should receive expanded visitation 
  and remand this issue to the family court to establish a schedule consistent 
  with this opinion.
III.Â Â Â Â  Guardian Ad Litemâ€™s Recommendation
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Mother argues the family court erred 
  in failing to give proper weight to the recommendation of the guardian ad litem 
  and in failing to consider joint custody as recommended by the guardian ad litem. 
  [1] Â  In light of our determination that the family court did not err in 
  changing custody to Father and our remand of the visitation issue, we need not 
  reach this argument on appeal.Â Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of 
  Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (finding 
  it unnecessary to review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are 
  dispositive).
IV.Â Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Mother contends the family court erred 
  in awarding Father $23,469.79 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We agree that this issue 
  should be remanded for reconsideration by the family court judge in light of 
  our decision to remand the issue of visitation.
The award of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  is left to the discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed absent 
  an abuse of discretion.Â  Smith v. Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 
  232, 234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  The court considers the following factors in awarding 
  attorneyâ€™s fees: (1) the beneficial results obtained; (2) the abilities of the 
  parties to pay; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the 
  effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. 
  v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992) (citing Glasscock 
  v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991)).Â  
Because we remand the issue of visitation 
  in order to give Mother expanded visitation, Fatherâ€™s beneficial results have 
  been altered.Â  Therefore, we remand this issue for a de novo review 
  by the family court.Â  
As to Motherâ€™s arguments regarding the 
  specific hourly rate charged, the hours incurred, or the expert witness fees, 
  these issues are not preserved.Â  Mother did not raise any objection to these 
  issues at trial.Â  An issue not raised at trial is not properly before an appellate 
  court.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â Â  
  However, because we are remanding the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees de novo, 
  Mother may raise these issues on remand. 
CONCLUSION
We find the family court did not err in finding 
  a substantial change in circumstances based on Motherâ€™s unilateral decision 
  to alter Fatherâ€™s visitation.Â  However, we find it is in Graysonâ€™s best interests 
  to spend considerable time with both of her parents.Â  Therefore, we reverse 
  the family courtâ€™s award of standard visitation to Mother, and remand this issue 
  for an increase in Motherâ€™s visitation consistent with this opinion.Â  We also 
  remand the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  For the foregoing reasons, the decision 
  of the family court is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY,
J.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We note that subsequent to the merits hearing in this case, the South 
    Carolina General Assembly specifically addressed the role of private guardians 
    ad litem in family court actions in which custody or visitation of a minor 
    child is at issue.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1545 to â€“ 1557 (Supp. 
    2003).Â  In particular, the General Assembly made clear that a guardian may 
    only be appointed when â€œthe court will likely not be fully informed about 
    the facts of the case and there is a substantial dispute which necessitates 
    a guardian ad litem,â€ and with both of the partiesâ€™ consent.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 20-7-1545 (Supp. 2003).Â  Additionally, the code provides that a guardian 
    must not include a recommendation concerning custody in the written report, 
    nor may the guardian include a recommendation at the merits hearing unless 
    specifically requested by the court for reasons specifically set forth in 
    the record.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
BB&T of South Carolina,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Patricia W. Fuller,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


 

Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-156
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2004Â Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
John William Ray, of Greenville, for Appellant
Patricia W. Fuller, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Branch Banking and Trust Company 
  (â€œBB&Tâ€) appeals an order of the Circuit Court setting aside a default judgment 
  against Patricia W. Fuller (Fuller).Â  We conclude the circuit court abused its 
  discretion in setting aside the judgment and reverse.
FACTS
In May 1994, Fuller obtained a $65,000 unsecured line of 
  credit from BB&T.Â  Under the terms of the line of credit instrument, Fuller 
  was obligated to repay the balance owed under the credit line in a variable 
  number of monthly installments as a percentage of the balance owed BB&T.
Beginning around July 
  2001, Fuller stopped making payments on the line of credit.Â  After Fuller refused 
  BB&Tâ€™s demands for payment, BB&T commenced the present action seeking 
  a judgment against Fuller for the outstanding balance due on the credit line.Â  
  At the time of Fullerâ€™s default, she still owed $19,381.49.Â  BB&T requested 
  a judgment in that amount plus interest at the contract rate of 8.75 percent 
  dating from July 2001. 
On June 17, 2002, the trial court entered 
  default judgment in favor of BB&T for $24,196.98.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order 
  notes that, though BB&Tâ€™s summons and complaint was personally served on 
  Fuller, she had failed to respond. 
Sometime in July 2002, Fuller sent a letter 
  to the trial court asking that the default judgment be set aside because she 
  had timely served her answer prior to the judgment.Â  The letter was personally 
  addressed to Circuit Judge Larry R. Patterson.Â  It is stamped as having been 
  received by the Greenville County Clerk of Court on July 16, 2002.Â  The record, 
  however, contains no certificate of service indicating BB&T was properly 
  served with a copy of Fullerâ€™s letter, nor is there any indication on the face 
  of the letter that Fuller attempted to provide BB&T a copy of the letter 
  or otherwise notify it of the request made to Judge Patterson.
With no notice or opportunity to be heard, 
  Judge Patterson thereafter rescinded his June 17, 2002, entry of default judgment 
  by order filed July 16, 2002.Â  BB&T claims it was not aware of the trial 
  courtâ€™s decision to set aside the default judgment until it received a copy 
  of the order on July 17, 2002.Â  In its entirety, the order setting aside judgment 
  reads:Â  

The Order dated June 17, 2002 
  is rescinded.Â  The defendant tried to serve Plaintiffâ€™s counsel by registered 
  mail; however, Plaintiffâ€™s counsel refused delivery.Â  Pursuant to Rule 5, SCRCP, 
  service subsequent to the original summons and complaint may be served by mail 
  and is complete upon mailing (Citation omitted). Therefore, The Court hereby 
  rescinds the Order of June 17, 2002.

BB&T now appeals this order, arguing 
  inter alia, that it was not afforded an opportunity to rebut Fullerâ€™s 
  claim that BB&T was properly served with Fullerâ€™s answer to the original 
  complaint. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A motion to vacate a judgment is addressed to the 
  sound discretion of the trial court, and itâ€™s ruling will not be reversed on 
  appeal absent a clear showing of abuse of that discretion.Â  Ledford v. Pennsylvania 
  Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 674-75, 230 S.E.2d 900, 902 (1976); Loweâ€™s 
  of Georgia, Inc. v. Constantino, 288 S.C. 106, 109, 341 S.E.2d 382, 383 
  (Ct. App. 1986).Â  An abuse of discretion arises when an order of a lower court 
  on a motion to vacate a judgment was controlled by an error of law or when the 
  order is without evidentiary support.Â  Ledford, 267 S.C. at 675, 230 
  S.E.2d at 902.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Based on our review of the record before 
  us, we conclude the trial court abused its discretion in setting aside the June 
  17, 2002, entry of default judgment.Â  
 The trial court apparently 
  treated Fullerâ€™s July 2002 letter as a motion to set aside the judgment pursuant 
  to Rule 60 (b), SCRCP.Â  After default judgment has been entered, the trial court 
  may set aside that judgment in accordance with Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Rule 55(c), 
  SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(b) provides that â€œ[o]n motion and upon such terms 
  as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from 
  a final judgment, order, or proceedingâ€ due to mistake, inadvertence, excusable 
  neglect, newly discovered evidence, fraud or other similar reasons. (emphasis 
  added). Notwithstanding, such a motion may not be granted without affording 
  an affected party the procedural due process guarantee of notice and opportunity 
  to be heard.Â  â€œ[I]t is fundamental that no judgment or order affecting the rights 
  of a party to the cause shall be made or rendered without notice to the party 
  whose rights are affected.â€Â  Tryron Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Phelps, 
  307 S.C. 361, 362, 415 S.E.2d 397, 398 (1992) (citing Insurance Co. of North 
  America v. Hyatt, 290 S.C. 159, 348 S.E.2d 532 (1986)).Â  â€œGenerally, a person 
  against whom a judgment or order is taken without notice may rightly ignore 
  it and may assume that no court will enforce it against his person or property.â€Â  
  Universal Benefits, Inc. v. McKinney, 349 S.C. 179, 183, 561 S.E.2d 659, 
  661 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  The requirements of due process not only include notice, 
  but also an opportunity to be heard in a meaningful way, and judicial review.Â  
  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Holden, 319 S.C. 72, 78, 459 S.E. 2d 846, 
  849 (1995).
It is clear from the 
  record that the trial court failed to afford BB&T the opportunity to be 
  heard on Fullerâ€™s claim that she was not in default because she tried to serve 
  BB&Tâ€™s attorney by registered mail and the mail was refused.Â  Because the 
  trial court abused itsâ€™ discretion in granting relief to Fuller under Rules 
  55(c) and 60(b) by rescinding its earlier entry of default judgment, the trial 
  courtâ€™s order setting aside the default judgment is reversed.Â  The effect of 
  this reversal is to vacate the trial courtâ€™s order of July 11, 2002 and filed 
  on July 16, 2002.
 REVERSED.
HUFF and STILWELL, 
  JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.
