THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Branch Banking and Trust Company,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

V.

  
    
      
Wilson L.
Pickens,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-157
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2004

VACATED


  
    
      
John William Ray, of Greenville, for appellant.
Wilson L. Pickens, of Florence, for respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Branch Banking and Trust Company 
  (â€œBB&Tâ€) appeals an order of the Circuit Court setting aside a default judgment 
  against Wilson L. Pickens (Pickens).Â  BB&T contends the circuit judge lacked 
  jurisdiction to set aside the judgment.Â  We agree and vacate the order setting 
  aside the judgment.
FACTS
In June 1999, Pickens obtained a loan from BB&T 
  to purchase a used 1998 Ford Windstar van.Â  Under the terms of the loan documents, 
  Pickens was obligated to repay BB&T (including interest and other finance 
  charges) $29,791.80 over 60 months.Â  As collateral for the loan, BB&T held 
  a purchase money security interest in the van. 
Around August 2000, Pickens stopped making 
  payments on the loan.Â  BB&T subsequently repossessed the van and sold it, 
  applying the proceeds of the sale to the amount due on the loan.Â  Because the 
  proceeds from the sale of the van did not cover the entire amount Pickens owed 
  BB&T, it commenced the present action seeking a judgment against Pickens 
  for $12,844.37, the outstanding balance due on the loan at the time the complaint 
  was filed. Â BB&T also requested interest and attorneyâ€™s fees. 
Although personally served with the summons 
  and complaint on October 10, 2001, Pickens did not enter responsive pleadings 
  or otherwise respond to BB&Tâ€™s complaint.Â  Accordingly, on November 14, 
  2001, the trial court entered a default judgment against Pickens for $17,952.60 
  [1]  plus post-judgment interest at the statutory rate.Â  The judgment also 
  allowed BB&T â€œleave to foreclose or execute against Property or otherwise 
  enforce its judgment in any manner provided by law.â€ 
According to BB&T, on or about December 
  17, 2001, Pickens filed a Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition (individual liquidation).Â  
  It appears from the record that, during the pendency of his bankruptcy case, 
  Pickens filed a motion with the Bankruptcy Court to avoid BB&Tâ€™s â€œjudicial 
  lienâ€ pursuant to 11 U.S.C. Â§ 522(f).Â  The motion lists â€œbankruptâ€™s truckâ€ as 
  the type of property liened and â€œ1999â€ as the date of the lien.Â  The bankruptcy 
  judge denied Pickensâ€™ motion for failure to comply with SC LBR 9014-2 (Local 
  Rule) on December 21, 2001.  [2]  Â The bankruptcy court ultimately granted Pickens 
  a discharge in April 2002. [3] Â  
On June 14, 2002, the trial court entered 
  an order setting aside the November 14, 2001 judgment against Pickens.Â  According 
  to BB&Tâ€™s brief, the trial court entered its order setting aside the judgment 
  sua sponte. The order states â€œ[u] pon reviewing this case it has 
  come to the attention of the court that defendant did file an answer to the 
  complaint within the time provided by the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.â€Â  
  BB&T objected after receipt of notice of the order.Â  The trial court then 
  allowed Pickens to respond.Â  By letter addressed to the trial court, Pickens 
  stated: â€œIn response to letter I was sent concerning my case with regards to 
  BB&T. That debt was listed and discharg[ed] in my bankruptcy.Â  And my bankruptcy 
  case was discharged on April 22, 2002.â€ 
Apparently, the trial court took no further 
  action to modify or amend its order setting aside judgment (nor did it expressly 
  decline to do so).Â  BB&T now appeals the order setting aside judgment.



 
 DISCUSSION
BB&T appeals the trial courtâ€™s order setting aside 
  the judgment against Pickens, arguing the lower court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction to set aside the November 14, 2001 order.Â  We agree.
The prerogative of a circuit judge to sua 
  sponte alter, amend, or vacate his previous judgments and orders is significantly 
  restricted.Â  Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure regarding post-trial 
  relief from a trial courtâ€™s orders, the trial court retains jurisdiction to 
  reconsider or change its previous rulings for a limited timeâ€”generally for ten 
  days after entry of judgment, or if upon motion of party, ten days after the 
  party received written notice of the order.Â  See Rule 52(b), SCRCP (providing 
  that motion to amend findings must be made within ten days of entry or receipt 
  of judgment); Rule 59(e), SCRCP (providing that a motion to alter or amend judgment 
  must be made within ten days of entry or receipt of judgment).
 This court confronted a similar question 
  in Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 566 S.E.2d 193 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  In Ness, the trial judge sua sponte vacated his prior order 
  denying the defendantâ€™s motion to set aside a default judgment. Id. at 
  401, 566 S.E.2d at 195.Â  On appeal, this court held the trial judge lacked jurisdiction 
  to vacate his previous order where the modification was not made pursuant to 
  a motion to alter or amend the courtâ€™s decision, but on the judgeâ€™s own initiative, 
  and the modification was made more than ten days after the initial order.Â  Id. 
  at 403, 566 S.E.2d at 195.Â  
In the present case, as in Ness, 
  the trial judgeâ€™s order setting aside the default judgment was entered on the 
  courtâ€™s own initiative, not as requested in a motion pursuant to Rule 59(e) 
  or other applicable rule, and well outside the ten day period generally allowed 
  under the rules.Â  The trial judge therefore lacked jurisdiction to set aside 
  his original order.
Additionally, we note that the appellant devotes 
  a significant portion of its argument on appeal to the putative impact on this 
  case of the bankruptcy proceedings involving Pickens.Â  We find this has little 
  bearing on our consideration of the case.Â  Although the debt emanating from 
  theÂ  trial courtâ€™s order of November 14, 2001 may have been discharged by the 
  bankruptcy court, the record before us contains no proof that has occurred.Â  
  Moreover, there is no evidence in the record indicating the trial court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to enter the original default judgment due to the 
  effect of the automatic stay that obtains under 11 U.S.C. Â§ 362 when a bankruptcy 
  petition is filed.Â  Regardless, it does not appear from the face of the trial 
  courtâ€™s order setting aside the original judgment that the outcome of the bankruptcy 
  case prompted or controlled its decision.
CONCLUSION
Because the trial court lacked jurisdiction to 
  set aside its order of November 14, 2002, its order of June 14, 2002 is therefore 
  vacated.Â  The status of BB&Tâ€™s debt emanating from the trial courtâ€™s order 
  of November 14, 2001, is a matter to be determined by the bankruptcy court.
VACATED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  This figure includes the $12,844.37 account balance plus pre-judgment 
    interest of $2,673.23, attorneyâ€™s fees of $2,300, and costs of $135.

 
   [2]  We would note that the record reflects that BB&T 
    exercised its lien rights prior to September 17, 2001, repossessed the van 
    and sold it. These actions appear to have occurred prior to the bankruptcy 
    filing and thus theÂ  lien avoidance motion, as it pertains to the collateral, 
    may have been ineffective in any event. 

 
   [3]  The record before this Court 
    does not contain a listing of debts sought to be discharged, nor does it contain 
    documentation of the precise date Pickens filed for bankruptcy.Â  It should 
    be noted, however, that under 11 U.S.C. Â§ 727(b), a Chapter 7 discharge covers 
    all prepetition debts unless excluded under Â§ 523 of the Code.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Steven Wayne Bowman,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Edgefield County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

AFFIRMED

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-158
Submitted January 12, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  10, 2004


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald 
  J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Steven Wayne Bowman appeals 
  his conviction for murder, claiming the trial court improperly admitted evidence 
  of a prior bad act.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In the early morning of October 26, 
  2000, Jean Holmes drove past her son Phillipâ€™s home in Edgefield County on the 
  way to work.Â  As she was driving, she noticed her sonâ€™s vehicle was still parked 
  in the driveway.Â  When she stopped to investigate, she saw what she thought 
  was a â€œmummy.â€Â  As she approached the body, she discovered it was her son.Â  
  An investigation revealed that Phillip had been shot twice in the upper body.Â  
  His body had also been partially burned.
Prior to his death, Holmes had been involved in 
  a relationship with Debi Blankenbecker.Â  They had been dating since January 
  2000.
Blankenbecker testified she had an affair with 
  Bowman several years earlier, and that Bowman became extremely jealous of her 
  new relationship with Holmes.Â  She claimed Bowman committed several threatening 
  and violent acts against her from February to October 2000.Â  For example, Blankenbecker 
  claimed:Â  Bowman made threatening calls demanding that she stop seeing Holmes; 
  Bowman â€œtrashedâ€ her house on one occasion; Bowman had attempted to â€œcarry her 
  away;â€ her ribs and chest were injured after a violent episode during which 
  Bowman washed her mouth out with soap after she spoke of Holmes; and Bowman 
  broke into her home at night, entered her bedroom, and demanded sex. 
The crux of the present controversy 
  concerns Blankenbeckerâ€™s testimony regarding the incident in July 2000 in which 
  she claimed Bowman broke her ribs.Â  On direct examination at trial, Blankenbecker 
  initially described what happened that day.Â  She testified that she and Bowman 
  got into a fight while returning from a trip they had taken together to Atlanta, 
  Georgia.Â  They returned to Bowmanâ€™s house against her wishes.Â Â  She claimed 
  that Bowman â€œripped the phone out of the wall so I couldnâ€™t call anybody.â€Â Â  
  The solicitor then asked Blankenbecker: â€œNow, while there at his home, did you 
  receive some injuries to your ribs?Â  Thatâ€™s all I want to know.Â  Did you receive 
  some injuries to your ribs?â€Â  She responded: â€œYes, I did.â€Â Â  Blankenbecker further 
  testified that she asked Bowman if she could call Holmes, at which point Bowman 
  put soap in her mouth and told her â€œnot to mention [Holmesâ€™s] name in his house.â€Â Â  
  The examination regarding this event then concluded as follows:

Solicitor:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Also during this same night, was there a bruise on your chest area?
Blankenbecker:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.
Solicitor:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Did the Defendant tell you that you should show that bruise to anyone?
Blankenbecker:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.Â  
  He said, â€œYou can show this to [Holmes].â€ 

Defense counsel did not object to any of this testimony.
A few minutes later, the solicitorâ€™s 
  examination turned to another topic.Â  Blankenbecker was asked when she had last 
  heard from Bowman.Â  She responded: â€œI had not heard very much from him since 
  July 5th, since he broke my ribs.â€ Defense counsel immediately objected, arguing 
  testimony from a witness regarding a prior bad act of a defendant that is not 
  directly related to the deceased is not admissible and that a mistrial should 
  be declared.Â  The solicitor responded that the testimony was not offered to 
  show the character of Bowman, but rather offered to show Bowmanâ€™s malice and 
  animus toward the victim.Â Â  The trial court denied defense counselâ€™s request 
  for a mistrial, finding the probative value of the testimony outweighed any 
  harm that may have been done by the statement. Â Â The court then instructed the 
  jury that it should not consider Blankenbeckerâ€™s statement as a reflection of 
  the defendantâ€™s character, but only as an explanation of events that had occurred.
The State continued its case and presented 
  evidence in an attempt to connect Bowman to the murder.Â  The night before the 
  murder, Bowman borrowed his fatherâ€™s Dodge Dakota truck.Â  According to investigators, 
  the truckâ€™s engine was â€œvery loud.â€Â  A neighbor of Holmes testified that at 
  approximately 12:15 to 12:30 a.m. on October 26, 2000, he heard three gunshots.Â  
  At approximately 12:55 a.m, he saw a truck driving down the road at a high 
  rate of speed.Â  He noted the truckâ€™s engine was so loud that it rattled the 
  windows.Â Â Â  
Two other neighbors of Holmes 
  testified that a week before the murder they saw a man, who they later identified 
  as Bowman, jump out of ditch and run to a car parked near Holmesâ€™s house.Â  
  A map of Edgefield County found in Bowmanâ€™s car was admitted into evidence.Â  
  The map had Bowmanâ€™s fingerprints on it, some of which were located right below 
  the area depicting the roads around Holmesâ€™s house.
The State also called Vicky Redfern 
  as a witness.Â  Redfern, a co-worker who had dated Bowman, testified that a week 
  before the murder Bowman asked to borrow her Ruger .357 pistol to practice for 
  a hunting trip.Â  Redfern loaned him the weapon and gave him three bullets.Â  
  The night of the murder Bowman left work with Redfern. Â Â She testified 
  Bowman asked her to â€œcoverâ€ for him because a man named â€œPhillipâ€ had been killed 
  in Edgefield and he did not have an alibi.Â  He told her that Phillip 
  had been dating a girl that he used to date and that he and Phillip had had 
  â€œverbal confrontations.â€Â  According to Redfern, Bowman admitted killing 
  Holmes, but recanted shortly thereafter.Â Â  Redfern testified that when 
  she asked Bowman for her gun, he told her she could not have it because he had 
  used it. Â Â 
 A security guard at Bowmanâ€™s work testified 
  that when Bowman walked through his security station in the early morning of 
  October 26, 2000, he detected the smell of burnt leaves or barbeque. Â Â An 
  inmate incarcerated with Bowman at the Edgefield County Jail testified Bowman 
  told him that he had told â€œthis girlâ€ that he had committed the murder but recanted.Â  
  Bowman also said that the authorities would never find the murder weapon in 
  South Carolina.Â  
 Bowman presented several witnesses.Â  
  Three witnesses, who officiated high school football with Bowman, testified 
  Bowman acted normally the weekend after the murder.Â  In an effort to explain 
  the Edgefield County map that was admitted into evidence, a friend of Bowmanâ€™s 
  who was a federal inmate in Edgefield County testified Bowman was planning to 
  visit him.Â  Additionally, a mechanic testified regarding the exhaust system 
  in Bowmanâ€™s fatherâ€™s truck.Â  He testified the original muffler on the truck 
  had not been altered.
Bowman testified in his own defense. 
  Â Although his testimony was lengthy, Bowman essentially testified he 
  was being sarcastic when he told Redfern that he had committed the murder.Â  
  He denied committing the murder.Â Â  He explained that the night of the murder 
  he borrowed his fatherâ€™s truck because he thought he was going to transport 
  items to work for Redfern. Â Â He testified that night he went to his work 
  to talk with Redfern who ended her day around 10:30 p.m.Â  When he arrived around 
  11:25 p.m., he discovered that she was not there.Â  He then went to a nearby 
  Waffle House and Wal-Mart.Â  Afterwards, he drove to Redfernâ€™s house and arrived 
  around 12:40 a.m., but did not go in because her lights were off.Â Â  He then 
  decided to go back to work to get caught up.Â  He testified his previous work 
  week had included the 11:00 p.m. to 7:30 a.m. shift.Â  After working for 
  a while, Bowman left work around 2:40 a.m.Â  
In reply, the State presented an employee 
  where Bowman worked who testified that the night of the murder Bowman went through 
  security at 1:55 a.m. and logged on his computer at 2:05 a.m.Â  A SLED agent 
  also testified to inconsistencies in Bowmanâ€™s statements.
The jury convicted Bowman of murder.Â  
  The trial court sentenced Bowman to life imprisonment without parole.Â  Bowman 
  appeals.
DISCUSSION
Bowman argues the 
  trial court erred in admitting Blankenbeckerâ€™s statement that â€œI had not heard 
  very much from him since July 5th, since he broke my ribs.â€Â  Specifically, Bowman 
  claims the probative value of this statement did not outweigh its unduly prejudicial 
  effect, particularly where the Stateâ€™s case was entirely circumstantial.Â  We 
  disagree. 
In reviewing the trial courtâ€™s decision 
  to admit evidence of a defendantâ€™s prior bad acts, our scope of review is limited 
  to determining whether there is any evidence reasonably supporting the trial 
  courtâ€™s decisions. State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 
  (2001).Â  â€œIf there is any evidence to support the admission of the bad act evidence, 
  the trial judgeâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.â€ Id. (noting 
  in footnote that â€œ[a]lthough we have never articulated this standard of review 
  in the context of bad act evidence, we have in fact applied it on review of 
  such cases;â€ citing four previous Supreme Court decisions applying the â€œany 
  evidenceâ€ standard of review in cases analyzing the admissibility of prior bad 
  acts).
As a general rule, â€œ[e]vidence of other 
  crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person 
  in order to show action in conformity therewith.â€ Rule 404(b), SCRE; see 
  State v. Jenkins, 322 S.C. 414, 416, 472 S.E.2d 251, 252 (1996) (stating 
  evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to prove a defendant 
  committed the specific crime charged).Â  However, evidence of other crimes, wrongs, 
  or acts is admissible if it tends to establish motive, intent, the absence of 
  mistake or accident, identity, or the existence of a common scheme or plan. 
  Rule 404(b), SCRE; Anderson v. State, 354 S.C. 431, 435, 581 S.E.2d 834, 
  835-36 (2003) (â€œRule 404, SCRE, the modern expression of the Lyle rule, 
  excludes â€˜evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or actsâ€™ offered to â€˜prove the character 
  of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.â€™Â  The rule creates 
  an exception when the testimony is offered to show motive, identity, the existence 
  of a common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.â€ 
  (quoting Rule 404(b), SCRE)).Â  
To admit evidence of prior bad acts, there must 
  be a logical relevance between the acts in question and the purpose for introduction.Â  
  State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 416, 118 S.E. 803, 807 (1923); State 
  v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 153, 561 S.E.2d 640, 645 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Even if 
  the prior crime evidence is relevant, it must be excluded if its probative value 
  is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant. 
  Rule 403, SCRE; State v. King, 334 S.C. 504, 512, 514 S.E.2d 578, 582 
  (1999).
Generally, it is improper to introduce incidents 
  of violence involving the defendant and someone other than the decedent. See 
  State v. Braxton, 343 S.C. 629, 634-36, 541 S.E.2d 833, 836 (2001) (holding 
  evidence of an argument between defendant and his brother the night before the 
  victimâ€™s murder was inadmissible character evidence); cf. State v. 
  Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 168, 508 S.E.2d 870, 874 (1998) (â€œIn homicide cases, 
  evidence that the accused and the decedent had previous difficulty is admissible.Â  
  The evidence is admissible to show the animus of the parties and to aid the 
  jury in deciding who was the probable aggressor.â€). 
The instant case, however, is distinguishable given 
  the interrelationship between Bowman, Blankenbecker, and Holmes.Â  Evidence was 
  presented at trial demonstrating the violence Bowman inflicted on Blankenbecker 
  was directly related to Bowmanâ€™s envy and ill feelings toward Holmes. This evidence 
  is sufficient to support a finding that Bowmanâ€™s act of breaking Blankenbeckerâ€™s 
  ribs was part of a series of violent acts committed by Bowman, all of which 
  involved his hatred for Holmes.Â  Thus, the evidence was admissible to show Bowmanâ€™s 
  motive and animus with regard to the victim.Â  See State v. Alford, 
  264 S.C. 26, 32, 212 S.E.2d 252, 254 (1975) (â€œâ€˜Evidence is inadmissible to show 
  a difficulty between accused and a third person in no way connected with the 
  victim or offense . . . However, where [the] connection with the offense sufficiently 
  appears, evidence of prior difficulties between accused and a third person is 
  admissible to show malice, premeditation, or general state of mind, as is evidence 
  . . . that accused had a grudge against the companion of the victim at the time 
  of the assault.â€™â€ (quoting 40 C.J.S. Homicide Â§ 209 (pre-cursor to 41 
  C.J.S. Homicide Â§ 207 (1991))); see also Mitchell v. United 
  States, 629 A.2d 10, 13-14 (D.C. 1993) (â€œ[W]e have also recognized that 
  the web of spousal discord often entangles third parties, and accordingly, have 
  extended the scope of the motive exception to allow evidence showing wrongful 
  acts against the spouse when the ultimate crime was committed against a third 
  party . . . [F]or admissibility determinations under the â€˜motiveâ€™ exception, 
  we see no reason to artificially distinguish between those situations where 
  the victim of the initial wrongful conduct and the ultimate crime are identical, 
  and where the ultimate victim is a third party with a clear nexus to the initial 
  misconduct.â€). [1] 
Even assuming the court erred in admitting 
  Blankenbeckerâ€™s testimony, any error in its admission was harmless.Â  As described 
  above, the brief statement regarding the injury to Blankenbeckerâ€™s ribs that 
  prompted defense counselâ€™s objection occurred after earlier, more extensive 
  testimony on the same incident. That testimony and the testimony of Blankenbecker 
  regarding numerous other violent acts directed against her was admitted without 
  objection.Â  Viewed in context, therefore, the statement that is the subject 
  of this appeal was merely cumulative.Â  Thus, its admission did not constitute 
  reversible error.Â  See State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 196, 577 
  S.E.2d 445, 448 (2003) (stating the erroneous admission of prior bad act evidence 
  is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt if its impact is minimal in the context 
  of the entire record); State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 
  859, 862 (1993) (finding any error in admission of evidence cumulative to other 
  unobjected-to evidence is harmless).
Accordingly, we find the trial court 
  did not abuse its discretion in admitting Blankenbeckerâ€™s statement regarding 
  Bowmanâ€™s prior bad act.Â  Additionally, even if it had been error to admit this 
  testimony, the error was a harmless one, not warranting the intervention of 
  this Court.Â  We affirm Bowmanâ€™s murder conviction and sentence.
 AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, 
  AJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  To the extent Bowman argues the evidence was inadmissible because 
    it was too remote in time to the homicide, we find this argument is not preserved 
    for our review because it was not raised at trial.Â  See State v. 
    Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 113, 485 S.E.2d 360, 363 (1997) (stating to be preserved 
    for appellate review, an issue must be raised to and ruled on by the trial 
    judge).Â  In any event, the remoteness did not negate the relevance of the 
    evidence.Â  See Commonwealth v. Pacell, 497 A.2d 1375, 1378 (Pa. 
    Super. Ct. 1985) (finding evidence that defendant struck common-law wife five 
    days before the murder of wifeâ€™s paramour was relevant to defendantâ€™s motive, 
    and remoteness did not vitiate relevance given incident was part of the sequence 
    of events leading directly to the homicide).

  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Tony Lovette, Rudolph S. Scott, Jr., and Julius Higgins,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sonoco Products Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-159
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  11, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cletus K. Okpalaeke, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Clifford L. Bourke, Jr., of Columbia; James M. Powell, of 
  Greensboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Tony Lovette, Rudolph 
  S. Scott, Jr., and Julius Higgins (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal an order 
  of the trial court granting Sonoco Products Company summary judgment in Appellantsâ€™ 
  wrongful termination action. We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Appellants were each employed by Anchor Continental, 
  Inc. in the spiral tubing division.Â  In 1996, Sonoco bought Anchorâ€™s spiral-tubing 
  department.Â  Prior to the buy-out, Sonoco conducted a meeting with the employees 
  of this division offering them the opportunity to work for Sonoco.Â  Appellants 
  offered evidence that in this meeting Sonoco made several assurances concerning 
  employment.Â  Although the actual wording and substance of these assurances varied 
  slightly from worker to worker, from this evidence it appears Sonoco generally 
  assured the Anchor employees: [2] Â  (1)Â  No jobs would be eliminated by the buy-out;Â  
  (2)Â  employees who wanted to switch to Sonoco would be granted positions and 
  would maintain their positions as long as they performed their work satisfactorily; 
  (3)Â  previous seniority would be honored;Â  (4)Â  Sonoco personnel policies would 
  be the same as existing Anchor personnel policies;Â  (5)Â  wages would remain 
  the same or increase;Â  (6)Â  all employees would maintain the same positions, 
  responsibilities, and hours but would be offered the choice of changing jobs 
  or remaining at their former jobs following any departmental restructuring;Â  
  (7) former Anchor employees would be able to participate in Sonocoâ€™s retirement 
  pension plan after two years and their years of employment with Anchor would 
  be included in calculating eligibility for Sonocoâ€™s retirement pension plan;Â  
  (8)Â  insurance premiums would be waived for at least three years; (9)Â  employees 
  could roll over their 401(k) contributions to Sonocoâ€™s plan, if desired;Â  (10)Â  
  any employee who decided to stay with Anchor would be given a job in another 
  department with that company.Â  Eighteen of the twenty employees in the division 
  agreed to change to Sonoco employment, including division supervisor Scott Franklin.Â  

After Brian Wellman became the 
  manager of the Sonoco division in July of 1997, he significantly restructured 
  the division.Â  As part of this restructuring, the pay rates for many jobs were 
  lowered.Â  Although no employeeâ€™s pay decreased, the employeesâ€™ pay rates were 
  frozen until the rates for their jobs met their current pay rates.Â  Wellman 
  offered Appellants new jobs under the restructuring.Â  They turned the offers 
  down because they felt the pay increases were not proportionate to the new responsibilities.Â  
  Appellants stated that because they complained about the changes Wellman made 
  to the division, they were branded troublemakers.Â  
In August of 1997, Wellman began investigating 
  time-keeping irregularities by the employees in the department after hearing 
  rumors that employees were gone from the work area for long periods of time 
  on weekends when no members of management were around.Â  Wellman obtained the 
  records of the turnstile controlled by magnetic key cards through which the 
  employees entered the plant from the parking lot and compared them to the employeesâ€™ 
  time cards.Â  He found significant discrepancies in the records of eight employees, 
  including the three Appellants.Â  As a result of this investigation, four employees, 
  including Appellants, were fired.Â  
Appellants initially brought an action in the U.S. 
  District Court for the District of South Carolina, alleging Title VII race-based 
  discrimination, as well as pendent state claims of wrongful breach of employment 
  contract and wrongful retaliatory termination in violation of state public policy.Â  
  Adopting the report of an assigned magistrate, the District Court dismissed 
  Appellantâ€™s federal claims, but added, â€œthe remaining state law claims are hereby 
  dismissed without prejudice, to be pursued, if at all, in state court.â€Â  The 
  Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed this ruling.Â  
Appellants then brought an action in state court.Â  
  Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted 
  summary judgment in favor of Sonoco.Â  It subsequently denied Appellantsâ€™ motion 
  for reconsideration.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the 
  disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  Dawkins 
  v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003).Â  Summary judgment 
  is appropriate when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the 
  moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 
  346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  The evidence and all reasonable 
  inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party.Â  Id.Â  â€œIt is well established that summary judgment should be 
  granted â€˜. . . in cases in which plain, palpable and indisputable facts exist 
  on which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€™â€Â  Anders v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. 
  Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 371, 373, 415 S.E.2d 406, 407 (Ct. App. 1992) (quoting 
  Main v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 526, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984)); see 
  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000) (finding 
  where a verdict is not reasonably possible under the facts presented, summary 
  judgment is proper).Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
Appellants argue that the promises made by 
  Sonoco before the buy-out constitute an oral employment contract and an exception 
  to the doctrine of employment at-will. We disagree.
South Carolina recognizes the doctrine of 
  employment at will in wrongful termination actions.Â Â  Prescott v. Farmers 
  Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).Â  Although 
  some exceptions have been recognized, the doctrine of employment at-will remains 
  in South Carolina as a longstanding economic incentive that provides the marketplace 
  its necessary flexibility.Â  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 335, 442 S.E.2d at 
  925.Â  At-will employment may be terminated by either party at any time, for 
  any reason or for no reason at all.Â  Prescott 335 S.C. at 334, 516 S.E.2d 
  at 925.Â  The general rule is that termination of an at-will employee normally 
  does not give rise to a cause of action for breach of contract.Â  Connor v. 
  City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 463, 560 S.E.2d 606, 610 (2002).Â  
An employer and employee may choose to contractually 
  alter the general rule of employment at-will through an oral contract of definite 
  employment.Â  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 335-36, 442 S.E.2d at 925-26.Â  However, 
  to prove the existence of such a contract, which is usually unilateral, the 
  employee must establish:Â  â€œ1) a specific offer, 2) communication of the offer 
  to the employee, and 3) performance of job duties in reliance on the offer.â€Â  
  Id. at 336, 442 S.E.2d at 926.Â  
â€œAn offer is the manifestation of willingness to enter 
  into a bargain, so made as to justify another person in understanding that his 
  assent to that bargain is invited and will conclude it.â€Â  Prescott, 335 
  S.C. at 336, 442 S.E.2d at 926.Â  In order to be considered binding, an offer 
  of employment must be definite.Â  Id. at 336-37, 442 S.E.2d at 926.Â  An 
  offer arises from conduct from which a reasonable person in the offereeâ€™s position 
  would be justified in inferring a promise in return for a requested act. Â Id. 
  at 336, 442 S.E.2d at 926.Â  â€œVague assurances of job security, even if repeated, 
  do not give rise to contractual rights.â€Â  Id.
In Prescott, the supreme court found an alleged 
  offer of â€œ[a]s long as you do your job, keep your nose clean, that youâ€™d have 
  a job at [the employer] right onâ€ was not sufficiently explicit to constitute 
  an offer to limit termination to just cause.Â  Id. at 337, 442 S.E.2d 
  at 926.Â  It explained a reasonable person in the employeeâ€™s position would construe 
  the statement as praise or encouragement, or even â€œpuffery,â€ rather than as 
  an offer of definite employment.Â  Id.Â  
Even when construing the alleged assurances made by 
  Sonoco in the light most favorable to Appellants, we find these assurances did 
  not satisfy the criteria set forth in Prescott.Â  Sonocoâ€™s alleged statement 
  to the employees that they â€œwould maintain their positions as long as they performed 
  their work satisfactorilyâ€ amounts to no more than a vague assurance of job 
  security.Â  It did not create any type of contractual rights that would remove 
  Appellants from the general rule of at-will employment.Â  
Appellants cite Weber v. Perry for 
  the contention that the relinquishment of gainful employment to pursue new employment 
  promised by another is adequate consideration to take a position out of the 
  realm of at will employment. 201 S.C. 8, 21 S.E.2d 193 (1942). The controlling 
  distinction between Weber and the case before us is the nature of the 
  relinquished employment.Â  In Weber, the plaintiff abandoned his own established 
  business in Michigan to work for another in South Carolina.Â  While the court 
  did find this move adequate to establish independent consideration, subsequent 
  case law has distinguished these facts from circumstances where an at-will position 
  is relinquished to take another at-will position, even if the new employer promises 
  â€œlifetimeâ€ employment.Â  Orsini v. Trojan Steel Corp., 219 S.C. 272, 64 
  S.E.2d 878 (1951).Â  The mere act of leaving one at-will job for another does 
  not take the new employment out of the general rule, notwithstanding any inducements 
  or promises by the later employer to the contrary.Â  
There is no evidence in the record that Appellantsâ€™ 
  employment with Anchor was not at-will.Â  Accordingly, their decision to leave 
  their at-will employment with Anchor to take positions with Sonoco did not create 
  any contractual rights.Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s determination 
  that as a matter of law, Appellants were at-will employees of Sonoco and could 
  lawfully be terminated at any time for any or no reason.
Moreover, even when assuming that Appellants were contractual 
  employees who could only be terminated for cause, we find the trial court correctly 
  held no genuine issue of material fact existed to support the Appellantsâ€™ contention 
  that Sonoco breached the alleged contract.Â  When an employment contract only 
  permits termination for cause, the appropriate test on the issue of breach focuses 
  on whether the employer had a â€œreasonable good faith belief that sufficient 
  cause existed for termination.â€Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 
  S.C. 454, 464, 560 S.E.2d 606, 611 (2002).Â  â€œ[T]he fact finder must not focus 
  on whether the employee actually committed misconduct;Â  instead, the focus must 
  be on whether the employer reasonably determined it had cause to terminate.â€Â  
  Id. at 464-65, 560 S.E.2d at 611.
Wellman testified that based on a rumor he suspected 
  employees had been leaving the premises without clocking out, in effect being 
  paid for time not spent at work.Â  It was suspected that most of these violations 
  had occurred over the weekends, when the plant operated without a supervisor 
  or manager present.Â  Employees could only enter plant from the parking lot through 
  a turnstile controlled by a magnetic â€œkey cardâ€. A record of the use of each 
  card was maintained by a computer system belonging to Anchor.Â  Wellman initiated 
  an investigation comparing the timecard records and the key card turnstile records 
  of every employee in the Sonoco division of the plant.Â  
After comparing the records of all the hourly employees, 
  Wellman disregarded all timecard discrepancies he felt were insignificant, such 
  as times that might reflect the moving of a car, retrieving items from the parking 
  lot, rolling up car windows, etc.Â  He found eight employees whose discrepancies 
  were substantial.Â  The absences in question all took place before Wellman assumed 
  the position of plant manager. Wellman then approached division supervisor Scott 
  Franklin for any information regarding the paid absences of these eight employees.Â  
  Franklin recalled satisfactory explanations for two of them.Â  Wellman then met 
  with the remaining six employees.Â  All six were suspended following the meeting, 
  but were told that a second meeting would take place later in the week and that 
  any information regarding the absences would be appreciated between the meetings.Â  

Prior to the second meeting, two employees came to 
  Wellman with explanations and apologies. They each received an official warning 
  and were reinstated, one with pay and one without.Â  Appellants, three of the 
  remaining four employees, offered no further information until the second meeting. [3] Â  Following the second meeting, 
  Appellants were terminated.Â  
Appellants argue Sonoco waived enforcement of its 
  rule against employees leaving the premises without clocking out by allowing 
  a â€œlunch runâ€ system.Â  According to the testimony of the Appellants and several 
  other employees, Franklin had initiated this system while supervising the Anchor 
  division, whereby a designated employee would leave the premises without clocking 
  out to purchase lunch for the entire crew or cash checks for the crew.Â  Although 
  this practice continued after Sonoco took over the division, it ended when Wellman 
  became the manager.Â  
We find no evidence in the record that Sonoco waived 
  its rule against employees leaving the premises without clocking out.Â  At the 
  most, the â€œlunch runâ€ system may have provided a viable excuse for absences 
  when an employee was the designated lunch runner.Â  The Appellants, however, 
  admitted to paid absences from work at times and for reasons that cannot be 
  justified by the existence of Franklinâ€™s â€œlunch runâ€ system.Â  They were given 
  ample opportunity to apologize or explain these absences, evidence of Sonocoâ€™s 
  good faith.Â  The turnstile records and Appellantsâ€™ admissions in meetings with 
  Brian Wellman gave Sonoco a reasonable good faith basis to terminate Appellants. [4] Â Â  
Appellants also argue that they were terminated in 
  violation of a clear mandate of public policy. The trial court did not address 
  the issue of wrongful termination in violation of public policy in its order 
  granting summary judgment.Â  Appellants failed to seek a ruling on the issue 
  in their motion for reconsideration.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved 
  for our review.Â  SeeÂ  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 43, 492 
  S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (holding that an issue, if not ruled on, must be ruled 
  on by request in a post trial motion to be preserved for appeal).
The Respondent argues in its brief this court lacks 
  jurisdiction because Appellants failed to file their notice of appeal with this 
  court within ten days after they served it on Respondent as required by Rule 
  203(d)(2), SCACR.Â  As this court stated in its order allowing Appellants to 
  file their notice of appeal out of time, 
[I]t is the time for serving the notice of appeal that 
  may not be extended.Â  See Mears v. Mears, 287 S.C. 168, 337 S.E.2d 
  206 (1985) (timely service of the notice of appeal is jurisdictional requirement 
  that cannot be extended or expanded).Â  This court may allow late filing of a 
  notice of appeal if timely service has been accomplished for good cause shown.Â  
  See Rules 203(d)(3), 231, & 234(b), SCACR.  
Finding Appellants had established good cause, this 
  court allowed the late filing.Â  Accordingly, we reiterate this court does have 
  jurisdiction over Appellantsâ€™ appeal.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the trial court 
  granting summary judgment to Sonoco is
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, HOWARD, and CURETON, J.J. concur.Â  

 
    [1]    Respondent filed a motion to strike Appellantsâ€™ 
    reply brief.Â  The motion is DENIED.Â  The reply brief was given such consideration 
    as is appropriate under appellate court procedure.Â  

 
    [2]    As mandated by this courtâ€™s scope of review, we 
    must view the evidence in the light most favorable to Appellants.Â  Thus, we 
    list these assurances in the broadest manner alleged for the purposes of this 
    appeal only.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
    [3]    Lovette admitted to leaving the plant to work 
    on a boat.Â  Scott denied leaving for long periods and claimed he often loaned 
    his card to others. Higgins claimed permission for most absences, but admitted 
    to leaving to run an errand for his wife on one Sunday in question.Â  

 
    [4]    We need not rule on Appellantsâ€™ argument that 
    the trial court erred in its finding of collateral estoppel.Â  The court only 
    found that Appellants were estopped from claiming that the discrepancies in 
    turnstile/timecard records did not exist.Â  No such claim was made by Appellants 
    on appeal.

PER CURIAM:Â  James Higgins appeals his convictions 
  for kidnapping, armed robbery, common law robbery, and possession of a stolen 
  vehicle.Â  Higginsâ€™s appellate counsel has petitioned to be relieved as counsel, 
  stating he has reviewed the record and has concluded Higginsâ€™s appeal is without 
  merit.Â  The issue briefed by counsel concerns whether Higgins, in pleading guilty 
  as charged, understood the facts in relationship to the applicable law as required 
  by Boykin v. Alabama. [1] Â  
  Higgins has not filed a brief with this court on his own behalf.
After a review of the record as required 
  by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable 
  issues in this case that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss 
  Higginsâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
  [2] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard Fletcher,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-164
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 15, 2004

VACATED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, 
  Jr.;Â  and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM: Richard Fletcher 
  was indicted for second-degree lynching.Â  Fletcher pled guilty to assault and 
  battery of a high and aggravated nature as a lesser-included offense of lynching 
  and was sentenced to five years imprisonment, suspended on the service of three 
  years probation.Â  Fletcher appeals, arguing the circuit court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction to accept his plea to assault and battery of a high and 
  aggravated nature because it is not a lesser-included offense of lynching.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
A grand jury indicted Fletcher for second-degree 
  lynching.Â Â Â  Subsequently, Fletcher pled guilty to assault and battery of a 
  high and aggravated nature (â€œABHANâ€). Â Fletcher appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Fletcher argues ABHAN is not a lesser-included 
  offense of lynching, and thus, the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to accept his plea.Â  We agree.
â€œThe lack of subject matter jurisdiction over a criminal 
  case can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, 
  and can be raised sua sponte by the court.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 
  103, 107, 572 S.E.2d 309, 311 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A circuit court lacks subject 
  matter jurisdiction to accept a guilty plea unless: 1) there is an indictment 
  that sufficiently states the offense; 2) the defendant has waived presentment 
  of the indictment; or 3) the plea is to a lesser-included offense of the crime 
  charged in the indictment.Â  Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 81, 84, 530 S.E.2d 
  887, 888 (2000).Â  â€œThe test for determining when a crime is a lesser included 
  offense is whether the greater of the two offenses includes all the elements 
  of the lesser offense.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
In Knox v. State, although the defendant 
  was indicted for second-degree lynching, he pled guilty to ABHAN as a lesser-included 
  offense of second-degree lynching.Â  Our supreme court determined that because 
  all of the elements of ABHAN are not included in the offense of second-degree 
  lynching, ABHAN is not a lesser-included offense of that crime.Â  Id. 
  at 84-85, 530 S.E.2d at 888-889.
Here, a grand jury indicted Fletcher for second-degree 
  lynching.Â  Subsequently, as in Knox, Fletcher pled guilty to ABHAN. Â At 
  the plea hearing, the circuit court accepted Fletcherâ€™s guilty plea to ABHAN 
  as a lesser-included offense of lynching.Â  However, â€œABHAN is not a lesser-included 
  offense [of lynching].â€Â  Id. at 85, 530 S.E.2d at 889.Â  Furthermore, 
  Fletcher did not waive presentment of an indictment for ABHAN.
Because Fletcher was not indicted for 
  ABHAN, he did not waive presentment of an indictment for ABHAN, and ABHAN is 
  not a lesser-included offense of second-degree lynching, the circuit court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to accept Fletcherâ€™s guilty plea.Â  See Id. 
 

CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Fletcherâ€™s conviction 
  is
VACATED.Â 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concurring.

PER CURIAM:Â  Mammie Lee Griffin appeals, 
  contending the sentencing court abused its discretion by revoking her probation 
  solely for failure to pay fines and restitution.Â  Having concluded oral argument 
  would not aid the court in resolving the issue raised by Griffin, we decide 
  this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR, and affirm pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, because the point raised by her is manifestly without 
  merit.Â  See State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 647, 511 S.E.2d 94, 
  96 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding the decision to revoke probation is committed to 
  the discretion of the sentencing court and the review of the court of appeals 
  is limited to correcting errors of law unless the lack of a legal or factual 
  basis indicates the sentencing judge acted arbitrarily or capriciously); Bearden 
  v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660, 672 (1983) (â€œIf the probationer willfully refused 
  to pay or failed to make sufficient bona fide efforts legally to acquire the

  to imprisonment within the authorized range of its sentencing authority.â€);

Cheryl Turner Hopkins, of Florence, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Leslie D. Stewart and Susan 
  F. Van Epps cross appeal the family courtâ€™s order granting Van Epps a temporary 
  reduction in child support payments, awarding Stewart partial attorneyâ€™s fees, 
  and declining to sanction Van Epps for contempt.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  
  As to all issues:Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 181-182, 554 
  S.E.2d 421, 423 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œIn appeals from the family court, the appellate 
  court has authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the 
  preponderance of the evidence.Â  However, this broad scope of review does not 
  require us to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Neither are we required 
  to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was 
  in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight 
  to their testimony.â€Â  (internal citations omitted)).Â  
As to Van Eppsâ€™ Issue: Calvert v. Calvert, 
  287 S.C. 130, 336 S.E.2d 884 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding a substantial or material 
  change of circumstances must occur to warrant a modification of child support.); 
  Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 384 S.E.2d 715, 717 (1989) (holding a 
  reduction in child support cannot be based on a decrease in the noncustodial 
  parentâ€™s income absent a strong showing by the latter that he or she can no 
  longer make the support payments required by the earlier order); Engle v. 
  Engle, 343 S.C. 444, 449, 539 S.E.2d 712, 714 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œWhere a 
  parent voluntarily lessens his or her earning capacity, this Court will closely 
  scrutinize the facts to determine the parentâ€™s earning potential, rather than 
  the parentâ€™s actual income.â€).
As to Stewartâ€™s Issue I:Â  Smith v. Smith, 
  308 S.C. 492, 495, 419 S.E.2d 232, 234-235 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding that an 
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and 
  will not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion); Glasscock v. Glasscock, 
  304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991) (holding the trial court must 
  consider six factors in determining the amount of an award of attorneyâ€™s fees:Â  
  â€œ(1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily 
  devoted to the case; (3) professional standing of counsel; (4) contingency of 
  compensation; (5) beneficial results obtained; [and] (6) customary legal fees 
  for similar services.â€).
As to Stewartâ€™s Issue II:Â  Am. Fed. Bank 
  v. Kateman, 335 S.C. 273, 277, 516 S.E.2d 1, 2 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œContempt 
  results from the willful disobedience of a court order.â€); Jackson v. Jackson, 
  241 S.C. 1, 126 S.E.2d 855 (1962) (holding a determination of contempt should 
  be imposed sparingly and within the sound discretion of the trial judge); Taylor 
  v. Taylor, 294 S.C. 296, 299, 363 S.E.2d 909, 911 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe 
  determination of contempt is within the discretion of the trial judge and will 
  not be disturbed in the absence of plain abuse of that discretion [and] [a]lthough 
  a family court is empowered to find and punish for contempt, there is no requirement 
  that sanctions be imposed upon such a finding.â€).Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Jonathan West was convicted 
  of armed robbery, possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent 
  crime, and pointing a firearm. West appeals, arguing the trial court improperly 
  denied his motion for directed verdict.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On April 30, 2002, two men robbed the 
  Applebeeâ€™s restaurant in Moncks Corner, South Carolina.Â  West was immediately 
  identified as a suspect by the victim and two employees, but investigators were 
  unable to locate him.Â  West turned himself in to police three days later.Â  He 
  was indicted for armed robbery, possession of a firearm during the commission 
  of a violent crime, and pointing a firearm.Â  West was tried by a jury on September 
  16, 2002, and was convicted on all charges.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
West appeals, arguing the circuit court erred in 
  denying his motion for directed verdict, because the State failed to present 
  evidence tending to prove his guilt.Â  Specifically, he argues the Stateâ€™s evidence 
  was insufficient, because it did not place him at the actual scene of the crime.Â  

In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the 
  trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not 
  its weight.Â  State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 S.E.2d 63 (1998); State 
  v. Williams, 303 S.C. 274, 400 S.E.2d 131 (1991).Â  In reviewing the trial 
  courtâ€™s motion for directed verdict, the evidence must be viewed in the light 
  most favorable to the State, and if there is any direct or any substantial circumstantial 
  evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, we must find 
  that such issues were properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Wiggins, 
  330 S.C. 538, 500 S.E.2d 489 (1998); State v. Long, 325 S.C. 59, 480 
  S.E.2d 62 (1997).Â  
Contrary to Westâ€™s contentions, the record reveals 
  ample evidence to affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of his directed verdict motion.Â  
  The victim of the robbery was a co-worker of Westâ€™s, who positively identified 
  Westâ€™s voice.Â  Moreover, another employee was arriving at work as the robbers 
  were exiting, and she identified West as one of the individuals.Â  This employee 
  observed the suspects run toward a blue vehicle located in an adjacent parking 
  lot.Â  Furthermore, another employee, who had previously worked with West, observed 
  West in a blue car near the restaurant near the time ofÂ  the robbery.Â  Viewing 
  the light most favorable to the State, there was sufficient evidence to justify 
  the denial of Westâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, J.J., concur.Â

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Paul L. Held, of Sumter, for Appellant.
William Ceth Land, of Manning, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Affirmed 
  pursuant to South Carolina Rules of Appellate Practice, Rule 220, and the following 
  authorities: As to Issue I: Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 
  282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002) (â€œThe decision to grant or deny alimony rests 
  within the discretion of the family court . . . . [and] will not be disturbed 
  on appeal absent abuse thereof.â€); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(1)-(13) 
  (Supp. 2002) (stating the family court must consider and weigh the following 
  factors in making an award of alimony: 1) â€œduration of the marriage;â€Â  2) physical 
  and emotional health of the parties; 3) â€œeducational backgroundâ€ of the parties;Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  4) â€œemployment history and earning potentialâ€ of the parties; 5) â€œstandard of 
  living established during the marriage;â€ 6) â€œcurrent and reasonably anticipated 
  earningsâ€ of the parties; 7) â€œcurrent and reasonably anticipated expensesâ€ of 
  the parties; 8) â€œmarital and nonmarital properties of the parties;â€ 9) â€œcustody 
  of the children;â€ 10) â€œmarital misconduct or fault;â€ 11) â€œtax consequences;â€ 
  12) prior support obligations; and 13) â€œother factors the court considers relevantâ€); 
  see also Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 186, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 
  (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œOur inquiry on appeal is not whether the family court gave 
  the same weight to particular factors as this court would have; rather, our 
  inquiry extends only to whether the family court abused its considerable discretion 
  in assigning weight to the applicable factors.â€).
 As to Issue 
  II: Ortowski v. Ortowski, 237 S.C. 499, 504, 117 S.E.2d 860, 
  862 (1961) (â€œIn a 
  motion for a new trial based upon after-discovered evidence, the moving party 
  must show . . . [the evidence] could not have been discovered before the trial 
  by the exercise of due diligence . . . . Such motions are addressed to the sound 
  discretion of the hearing Judge and his refusal will not be interfered with 
  by [an appellate court] unless an abuse of discretion amounting to error of 
  law is shown.â€ (internal citations omitted)); 
  see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (stating the family 
  court may â€œgive weight in such proportion as it finds appropriateâ€ to each of 
  the factors outlined in section 20-3-130).Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

  issues that are arguable on their merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss this appeal 
  and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. [1] Â Â Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, J.J., concur.Â  
  Â 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Annette W. Randolph,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-186
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka 
  and Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  W. Townes Jones, IV, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Annette Randolph (Appellant) was convicted of murder and 
  sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.Â  Randolph 
  argues on appeal the trial court erred (1) by denying her motion for a directed 
  verdict of acquittal and (2) by ruling that she waived her right to challenge 
  the voluntariness of her statement to law enforcement.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
On March 3, 2001, Officer Kevin Hughes was dispatched to Appellantâ€™s home in 
  response to a call that an individual needed medical help.Â  Upon Hughesâ€™ 
  arrival, Michael Darby, the man who made the call to 911, invited him into the 
  home.Â  Hughes saw the decedent, Ronald Epps, lying on the couch with a small 
  towel over his face and a lot of blood around him.Â  Officer Hughes determined 
  Epps was dead and requested assistance.Â  Appellant was the only other 
  person present in the home and in â€œan excited state.â€Â  Officer Hughes testified 
  there were no signs of forced entry and no mention of an intruder.
 Darby testified Appellant woke him up in the morning and asked him 
  to wake up Epps, who she said was on the couch with a towel over his face and 
  blood around him.Â  While Darby was attempting to wake Epps, Appellant 
  pointed out a hammer on the kitchen counter and asked him to move it.Â  He refused.Â  
  Recognizing that Epps needed medical attention, Darby called 911.Â  Assistance 
  arrived but Epps was deceased.
Officer Michael Oâ€™Connell arrived at the scene and testified 
  that a hammer was found in the bottom drawer next to the stove.Â  Based on information 
  he obtained from Officer Hughes, Officer Oâ€™Connell took the hammer first to 
  the morgue and later to the evidence locker.
Officer Danny Remion testified he recovered a hammer from 
  the home and it had rust on it.Â  Three days later, the hammer had even more 
  rust on it.Â  His testimony was that the rust was consistent with the hammer 
  having been recently washed.Â  He testified that there were traces of blood in 
  the shower in the master bathroom and in the sink in a second bathroom.Â  Officer 
  Chuck Counts testified that he tested the hammer and that it had recently been 
  wet.
The coroner testified Epps had been dead â€œfor several hours,â€ and 
  the results of the autopsy indicated that a blunt object had been used.Â  
  Dr. Janice Ross performed the autopsy on the decedent and concluded that 
  he had been dead â€œfrom four to five hours up to twelve hours.â€Â  She testified 
  she had seen the hammer and could not rule out that it could have been used 
  to cause the blunt force injury.
Eppsâ€™ girlfriend, Yvette Pratt, testified that she and Epps 
  had driven around Newberry the night of March 2.Â  He was carrying a roll of 
  cash totaling at least $1200 that night.Â  At trial, Officer Eddie Salizar 
  confirmed Prattâ€™s testimony, adding that he had searched Epps the evening of 
  March 2 between 8:00 and 9:00 p.m. on Wise Street and Epps had a lot of cash 
  on him.
At about 11:30 p.m., Pratt dropped Epps off where he resided, a trailer owned 
  by Appellant and her husband, Linart Randolph (â€œLinartâ€).Â  Pratt returned 
  to the trailer at about 1:00 a.m.Â  Appellant and Linart were arguing, and Linart 
  was walking around with a hammer.Â  Pratt left the trailer.Â  She testified that 
  Epps was alive when she left.
A witness testified that Linart was seen at a friendâ€™s house about 3:00 a.m. 
  smoking crack and had a roll of money on him at the time.Â  A neighbor 
  testified that in the morning when the police arrived in response to the 911 
  call, she spoke to Appellant, who pulled out a roll of $100 bills.Â  Appellant 
  and Linart were subsequently arrested and charged with murder and criminal conspiracy.Â  
  The trial judge directed a verdict of acquittal on the criminal conspiracy charge 
  for each of them.Â  However, the jury found Appellant guilty of murder.Â  
  Appellant was sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Directed Verdict
Appellant contends the trial judge erred in denying her motion 
  for a directed verdict on the murder charge because there was nothing in the 
  Stateâ€™s case to connect her to the murder.Â  We disagree.
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal 
  case, this Court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  
  State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 411, 578 S.E.2d 32, 35 (Ct. App. 2003); 
  State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 364, 574 S.E.2d 203, 205 (Ct. App. 2002). 
  When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned 
  with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight. State v. 
  Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 274, 584 S.E.2d 138, 140 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If there 
  is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably 
  tending to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was 
  properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 653, 
  572 S.E.2d 267, 273 (2002).Â  On the other hand, if the State fails to produce 
  evidence of the offense charged, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict.Â  
  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001); State 
  v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 271, 580 S.E.2d 159, 161 (Ct. App. 2003).
Appellant argues the evidence only raised a suspicion of 
  guilt.Â  â€œSuspicionâ€ implies a belief or opinion as to the guilt based on facts 
  or circumstances that do not amount to proof.Â  State v. Buckmon, 347 
  S.C. 316, 322, 555 S.E.2d 402, 404 (2001) (citing State v. Lollis, 343 
  S.C. 580, 541 S.E.2d 254 (2001)). 
The State argues there is sufficient circumstantial evidence 
  to submit the murder charge to the jury.Â  On March 2, 2001, Epps lived in the 
  home owned by Appellant and Linart.Â  A friend, Darby, lived in the home with 
  them.Â  When Officer Hughes, the first officer to arrive, got to the house and 
  found Epps dead, Appellant and Darby were the only two people there.Â  Darby 
  had placed the 911 call to the police.Â  According to Officer Hughes, there was 
  no evidence of a forced entry.
Eppsâ€™ girlfriend, Pratt, testified she had spent most of 
  the day of March 2 with him and, when she dropped him off at the house at some 
  point that night, he had at least $1200 on him.Â  She stopped back by 
  the house later that night but left when Appellant and Linart were arguing.Â  
  Linart was walking around with a hammer in his hand.Â  She testified Epps was 
  alive when she left.Â 
Officer Salizar confirmed Prattâ€™s testimony about the money, 
  adding that he had searched Eppsâ€™ person sometime on March 2 between 8:00 and 
  9:00 p.m. on Wise Street and Epps had a lot of cash.Â  A witness testified Linart 
  was at a friendâ€™s house at 3:00 a.m. and had a roll of money on him at that 
  time.Â  A neighbor testified that, after the police arrived in response 
  to the 911 call, she spoke to Appellant, who pulled out a roll of $100 bills.
After Darby tried to wake Epps and got no response, he saw 
  a hammer on the kitchen counter.Â  Appellant asked him to move it and he refused.Â  
  Officer Remion testified the hammer recovered from the home had rust on 
  it.Â  Over the next three days, the hammer had even more rust on it, consistent 
  with the hammer having been recently washed.Â  When Officer Chuck Counts tested 
  the hammer, he concluded that it had recently been wet.Â  Traces of blood were 
  found in the shower in the master bathroom and in the sink in a second bathroom.Â 
Officer Michael Oâ€™Connell testified that he found a hammer 
  in the bottom drawer next to the stove.Â  He took the hammer first to the morgue 
  and later to the evidence locker.
 The coroner testified the decedent had been dead â€œfor several hoursâ€ 
  and the results of the autopsy indicated that a blunt object had been used.Â  
  Dr. Janice Ross, who performed the autopsy on Epps, concluded that Epps 
  had been dead â€œfrom four to five hours up to twelve hoursâ€ and that she had 
  seen the hammer and could not rule out that it could have been used to cause 
  the blunt force injury.
The evidence in the instant case raised more than a mere suspicion 
  of guilt toward Appellant:

  
    Appellant had access to the victim;
  
    there was no evidence of a break-in;
  
    Appellant had spent her money 
  on crack cocaine;
  
    Epps had a roll of money hours 
  before the murder;
  
    Epps did NOT have money on him 
  when he was found dead;
  
    Appellant had a roll of money 
  hours after the murder;
  
    Appellant exhibited unusual behavior 
  with her neighbor;
  
    Appellant attempted to get someone 
  else to touch the hammer;
  
    the hammer had been washed;
  
    Appellant immediately began to 
  shift the blame to her husband or the victimâ€™s girlfriend;
  
    Appellant attempted to mislead 
  law enforcement by asserting she did not know who was sleeping on her couch, 
  although the victim had been living with her for at least two weeks.

These facts, especially Appellantâ€™s request to Darby to move 
  the hammer, that the hammer had been wet, that Epps had a considerable amount 
  of money when he got home and Appellant had a roll of money in the morning, 
  constitute sufficient circumstantial evidence presented by the State to warrant 
  submission of the case to the jury.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Voluntariness of Appellantâ€™s 
  Statement
Appellant argues the trial judge erred by ruling that she 
  waived her right to challenge the voluntariness of her statement.Â  We disagree.
At the start of the trial, the trial judge inquired 
  whether there were any pretrial motions, specifically, pursuant to Jackson 
  v. Denno. [2] Â  Appellant 
  answered that there were no motions.Â  The State did not introduce Appellantâ€™s 
  statement in their case in chief.
 On direct examination by trial counsel, Appellant 
  testified that she returned to the trailer on Friday night and â€œwent to bed 
  around sometime Friday morning or it could have been Friday night, over into 
  Friday morning.Â  I really donâ€™t know the times. . . .â€Â  Appellant testified 
  she had voluntarily given a statement to Officer Hughes the morning of the incident.Â  
  She said she went to the police station voluntarily with Officer Hughes, read 
  her rights and knew â€œwhat she was doing.â€Â  She said she made the statement voluntarily.Â  
  Trial counsel pointed out where Appellant had written on the third page of her 
  statement that she had gone to bed at 1:30 a.m., to which she responded: â€œI 
  was just getting nervous and really confused and stuff.Â  And so, I really donâ€™t 
  know.Â  It could have been 10:30, 11:30, 12:30 or 1:30.â€Â  She testified 
  further that she was buying crack on Wise Street somewhere between 10:25 and 
  10:40 p.m.Â  At another point in her testimony, Appellant said she had been in 
  bed at 10:30 or 10:40 p.m.
When Appellant was questioned on cross-examination 
  about her statement, the following colloquy occurred:

[STATE:]Â  Officer Hughes did not pressure you?
[APPELLANT:]Â  He told me to write the statement.
[STATE:]Â  To write the statement.
[APPELLANT:]Â  He did not bother me.
[STATE:]Â  Didnâ€™t bother you?
[APPELLANT:]Â  No, he did not.
. . . .
[STATE:]Â  He didnâ€™t put any pressure on you to write this?
[APPELLANT:]Â  No.

Appellant testified she became confused and Officer Jackie 
  Swindler tried to â€œcross her up,â€ had her â€œshook up,â€ and was â€œpressing herâ€; 
  however, she never claimed the statement was involuntary.Â  In fact, her testimony 
  was that she gave the statement voluntarily.
 At the conclusion of cross-examination, the State 
  moved to introduce the statement.Â  Trial counsel objected because â€œthere is 
  no reason whatsoever to put it in there.â€Â  The judge sustained the objection, 
  but reserved the right to reverse himself.
At the close of the case, the State asked the judge 
  to revisit the issue of the statement being admitted into evidence.Â  The judge 
  admitted the statement into evidence, and trial counsel renewed his prior objection 
  arguing that admission of the written statement would give it more credibility 
  than the rest of the testimony.Â  Trial counsel was asked why a Jackson 
  v. Denno hearing was not requested.Â  Trial counsel responded with the argument 
  that nobody told him they were going to admit the statement.Â  In overruling 
  the objection, the judge explained that since the State did not attempt to put 
  the statement into evidence in their case in chief and trial counsel questioned 
  Appellant about it, voluntariness was waived and the State was entitled to cross-examine.
The conclusion of the trial judge as to the voluntariness 
  of a statement will not be disturbed unless so erroneous as to show an abuse 
  of discretion.Â  State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 
  247 (1990); State v. Livingston, 223 S.C. 1, 6, 73 S.E.2d 850, 852 (1952).Â  
  For the trial judge to determine whether a statement was knowingly, intelligently, 
  and voluntarily made, an examination of the â€œtotality of the circumstancesâ€ 
  surrounding the waiver must be made.Â  State v. Doby, 273 S.C. 704, 708, 
  258 S.E.2d 896, 900 (1979).Â  An express waiver is not necessary to support the 
  finding that a defendant has waived the right to counsel or the right to remain 
  silent.Â  North Carolina v. Butler, 441 U.S. 369, 373 (1979).
Trial counsel denied the offer for a Jackson 
  v. Denno hearing at the start of the case.Â  The State never introduced Appellantâ€™s 
  statement in its case in chief.Â  The State only cross-examined Appellant on 
  specific issues of time after trial counsel introduced the contents of the statement 
  during direct examination.
Based on the foregoing facts, the trial judge was 
  correct in finding that the statement was given voluntarily and allowing it 
  into evidence.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, based on the foregoing reasons, Appellantâ€™s conviction and sentence 
  are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and BEATTY,
JJ., concur.

 
    [1]
    
   
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
    [2]
    
   
    Jackson v. Denno, 378 U.S. 368 (1964).
