THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Zepher Frederick, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Forriest 
        Cave,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Manly Dunbar; First Citizens Bank & Trust Company of South Carolina; 
        and Lang Dunbar,        Defendants,
Of Whom Manly Dunbar and Lang Dunbar are the       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Barnwell County
Richard B. Ness, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-187
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Martin Harvey and Pete Kulmala, both of Barnwell, for Appellants.
Miles Loadholt, of Barnwell, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, the personal representative 
  of the Estate of Forriest Cave, brought this action against Respondents, Manly 
  Dunbar and Lang Dunbar, seeking to determine that certain cashierâ€™s checks and 
  certificates of deposit were assets of the decedentâ€™s estate.Â  The matter was 
  referred to a special referee, who ruled in favor of Respondents.Â  This appeal 
  follows.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Forriest Cave died in Barnwell County on August 
  26, 2001.Â  Appellant, a resident of Barnwell County, is Caveâ€™s niece, the sole 
  devisee in Caveâ€™s Last Will and Testament and the personal representative of 
  the estate.Â  Manly Dunbar and Lang Dunbar are Caveâ€™s nephews.
Although they lived in Ohio, the Dunbars often 
  visited Caveâ€™s home.Â  On a visit to her home in 1999, Cave informed the Dunbars 
  that she had $65,000.00 in cash hidden underneath her mattress.Â  The Dunbars 
  told her it was not wise to keep such large amounts of cash in her home and 
  convinced her to put the money in certificate of deposits.Â  As a result, on 
  August 26, 1999, Cave put the money in two certificate of deposits with First 
  Citizens Bankâ€”one issued in Caveâ€™s name only, the other issued in Caveâ€™s name, 
  payable on death to Manly Dunbar.
On a subsequent visit in April 2000, Cave told 
  the Dunbars about an additional sum of cash in the house.Â  Cave converted this 
  cash into cashierâ€™s checks, one made payable to Cave only and two made out to 
  â€œForriest Cave or Manly D. Dunbar or Lang D. Dunbar, Jr.â€Â  Cave placed the cashierâ€™s 
  checks in a bank bag, which she gave to the Dunbars along with the bank bagâ€™s 
  key, asking them to take the bag with them back to Ohio.Â  Deciding it was best 
  to leave the bag with Cave, the Dunbars hid the bank bag in Caveâ€™s home, though 
  they retained possession of the bagâ€™s key.
Upon Caveâ€™s request, Manly Dunbar again visited 
  Cave in March 2001.Â  After seeing his aunt, Manly Dunbar went to First Citizens 
  Bank and spoke with certain representatives of the bank.Â  As a result of the 
  conversation, Barbara Wright, a longtime employee of the bank and lifetime friend 
  of Cave, traveled to Caveâ€™s home with specific instructions from her supervisor 
  not to transact any business with Cave unless she was alert and in a position 
  to do business.Â  As per Caveâ€™s instructions, Wright assisted Cave in performing 
  transactions that made Manly Dunbar a joint owner of a certificate of deposit 
  having a face value of $16,659.83, a joint owner of Caveâ€™s checking account, 
  and a joint owner of Caveâ€™s safety deposit box.
Appellant commenced this action on August 31, 2001 
  by filing a Complaint, along with a Rule to Show Cause and Temporary Restraining 
  Order seeking to prohibit the Dunbars from disposing or liquidating the cashierâ€™s 
  checks and certificate of deposits.
On December 20, 2001, the circuit court 
  referred this matter to a special referee pursuant to Rule 53, SCRCP on Appellantâ€™s 
  motion.Â  On the accompanying form order, the circuit court left blank the line 
  supplied for the deadline for which the case must be heard and final order filed. 
  Â A hearing was held before the special referee on February 6, 2002, and an order 
  in favor of the Dunbars was filed on September 18, 2002.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Timeliness of Order/ Jurisdiction
Frederick asserts that the special refereeâ€™s 
  order should be declared void and without effect because the December 20, 2001 
  Order of Reference had expired, leaving the special referee without jurisdiction 
  to issue the order.Â  We disagree.
Effective July 1, 1985, the South Carolina 
  Supreme Court issued an order outlining certain procedures applicable to masters-in-equity 
  and referees.Â  This order included the following provisions:

IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that within sixty (60) days from the 
  date of filing of the Order of Reference, the Master or Referee shall hear the 
  referred matter.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that within sixty (60) days from the 
  date of the hearing, the Master or Referee shall make and file his report or 
  order with the clerk of court, unless such time shall have been extended in 
  writing by the Chief Judge for Administrative Purposes upon a showing of exceptional 
  circumstances.

The crux of Appellantâ€™s argument is that because 
  over seven months passed between the hearing and order in this case, the special 
  referee failed to comply with the supreme courtâ€™s 1985 mandate that referees 
  file orders within sixty days of holding a hearing on the matter.Â  Citing our 
  decision in Smith v. Ocean Lakes Family Campground, 315 S.C. 379, 433 
  S.E.2d 909 (Ct. App. 1993), Appellant contends the failure to meet the deadline 
  divested the special referee of jurisdiction over the matter.
Appellantâ€™s reliance on the 1985 supreme 
  court order to establish a timeliness requirement is misplaced because it no 
  longer governs the procedure for references to masters-in-equity and referees.Â  
  Instead, Rule 53, SCRCP has become the controlling authority over such references 
  and has fully supplanted the 1985 order.
In 1986, our supreme court substantially amended 
  Rule 53, SCRCP.Â  Among other changes, the amended rule left scheduling of the 
  time and place of hearings to the referee.Â  Such a delegation of discretionary 
  scheduling authority cannot be concurrently reconciled with the mandatory sixty-day 
  time limit proscribed by the 1985 order, and as such, the amended Rule 53 must 
  be understood to supplant its predecessor.Â  Cf. Ramsey v. County of 
  McCormick, 306 S.C. 393, 397, 412 S.E.2d 408, 410 (1991) (â€œ[W]here conflicting 
  provisions exist, the last in point of time or order of arrangement, prevails.â€).
Moreover, the 1986 amendments also made clear that 
  referees have the same powers as a court sitting without a jury unless the order 
  of reference explicitly limits the refereeâ€™s authority.Â  Rule 53, SCRCP, Notes 
  to the 1986 Amendments.Â  Accordingly, just as the circuit courtâ€™s order of reference 
  can limit the subject matter to which the refereeâ€™s authority extends, so too 
  can the order of reference limit the duration of that authority.Â  Such was our 
  holding in Ocean Lakes.Â  In that case, we ruled that a master had been 
  divested of jurisdiction for failing to file an order within the ninety-day 
  time limit the circuit court included in its order of reference.Â  Id.Â  
  Unlike the order of reference in Ocean Lakes, which â€œexpired by its own 
  terms 90 days after the date of the order of reference,â€ the order of reference 
  in the instant contained no temporal limitation, no period after which it would 
  automatically expire.Â  See Ocean Lakes, 315 S.C. at 381, 433 S.E.2d 
  at 910.Â  
The rule was amended again in 1999, and as the 
  following notes to the amendment explain, previous procedural restrictions were 
  done away with:Â  

The detailed discussion of the powers of masters and special 
  referees, and the procedure to be followed in matters pending before them, has 
  been eliminated as unnecessary since the master or special referee has all the 
  powers that a circuit court judge sitting without a jury would have in the matter 
  and the procedure is that provided by the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.

Rule 53, SCRCP, Notes to the 1999 Amendment.
Accordingly, as a corollary to our supreme 
  courtâ€™s adoption of Rule 53 as the exclusive controlling authority for references 
  to masters and referees, the 1985 order is no longer of any effect, and masters 
  and referees are subject to no temporal limits for order entry other than those 
  included in the order of reference.Â  Therefore, because the order of reference 
  contained no time restraint, jurisdiction remained soundly with the referee 
  when the order was issued on September 17, 2002.
Inter Vivos Gift
Appellant asserts that the special referee 
  erred in concluding that the cashierâ€™s checks were inter vivos gifts to the 
  Dunbars.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn inter vivos gift is a contract between the 
  living which takes place by the mutual consent of the donor, who divests himself 
  of the property given in order to transmit the title to it to the donee gratuitously, 
  and the donee, who accepts and acquires legal title thereto.â€Â  Baptist Found. 
  for Christian Educ. v. Baptist Coll. at Charleston, 282 S.C. 53, 58, 317 
  S.E.2d 453, 457 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  In order to establish the existence of an 
  inter vivos gift, there must be a donative intent to transfer the property, 
  a delivery by the donor, and an acceptance by the donee.Â  Worrell v. Lathan, 
  324 S.C. 368, 371, 478 S.E.2d 287, 288 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
The thrust of Appellantâ€™s contention in this case 
  is that the delivery element was not satisfied because Cave never relinquished 
  possession.Â  Although a transfer of possession is perhaps the clearest form 
  of delivery, it is not the only method by which delivery can be made.Â  Our supreme 
  court explained this in Smith v. Johnson, 223 S.C. 64, 70, 74 S.E.2d 
  419, 421 (1953), when it stated:

It has been settled that it is not necessary that there should 
  be in all cases an actual manual delivery.Â  The principle is stated thus:Â  Property 
  in a chattel cannot be transferred by a parol gift without delivery; but by 
  delivery is not meant an actual manual delivery in all cases, but any circumstances 
  amounting to a clear demonstration of the intention of the one to transfer, 
  and of the other to accept, and which puts it into his power, or gives him authority 
  to take possession, is all that is necessary, and is a fact that is left to 
  the jury.

Id. at 70, 74 S.E.2d at 421 (internal quotations 
  omitted).Â  Indeed, whenever a donor intending to make a gift â€œso acts as to 
  put it within the power of the donee to take possession and exercise dominion 
  and control, he has completed delivery, whether he actually makes a manual deliverance 
  of the thing itself or not.â€Â  Copeland v. Craig, 193 S.C. 484, 496, 8 
  S.E.2d 858, 866 (1940).Â  
Applying the forgoing to the case at bar, 
  when Cave bestowed the key to the bank bag upon the Dunbars, she relinquished 
  and the Dunbars retained much more than a small metallic object.Â  Keys are instrumentalities 
  of access; to deliver a key is to deliver that which is held under lock.Â  See 
  Jaggers v. Estes, 22 S.C.Eq. (3 Strob. Eq.) 379 (1849) (â€œBut if the key 
  be delivered of a desk, in which a paper or a jewel is contained, the paper 
  or jewel is thereby delivered; because he who has the key has the dominion of 
  it.â€).Â  Although the Dunbars left the bank bag hidden in Caveâ€™s residence, by 
  retaining the key given to them, they likewise retained the power to take possession 
  of the bagâ€™s contents.Â  As correctly noted by the special referee, â€œpossession 
  of the key gave the Dunbars sole authority to take possession of the cashierâ€™s 
  checks at any time they desired, as even Ms. Cave did not have access to the 
  checks without the key to open the locked bag.â€Â  Accordingly, because Caveâ€™s 
  delivery of the key satisfied the element of delivery for the cashierâ€™s checks, 
  the continued physical presence of the bag in Caveâ€™s residence does not render 
  ineffective the inter vivos gift to the Dunbars.
Mentally Competency
Lastly, Appellant contends that the special 
  referee erred in concluding that Cave was mentally competent when she executed 
  the banking transaction on March 16, 2001.Â  We disagree.
When a party challenges a transaction based on 
  mental incompetence, â€œthe party alleging incompetence bears the burden of proving 
  incapacity at the time of the transaction by a preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  
  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 572, 544 S.E.2d 854, 858 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (internal citations omitted).Â  This Court has previously defined contractual 
  capacity as â€œa personâ€™s ability to understand, at the time the contract is executed, 
  the nature of the contract and its effect.â€Â  Id. at 570, 544 S.E.2d at 
  857.Â  To make this determination, we generally inquire as to whether the individual 
  lacked sufficient mental capacity to reasonably understand the transaction, 
  including the consequences and effects the transaction has upon the individualâ€™s 
  rights and interests.Â  Id.Â  
At trial, Appellant relied primarily on assessments 
  of Caveâ€™s capacity in generalâ€”including testimony that she tended to be more 
  alert in the afternoon than in the morningâ€”to insinuate her incapacity on the 
  morning of the transaction.Â  The special referee noted this deficiency by stating 
  that although Appellant â€œoffered several witnesses to testify about Ms. Caveâ€™s 
  mental state prior to and subsequent to March 16, [Appellant] offered no testimony 
  about Ms. Caveâ€™s mental capacity on the date these transactions occurred.â€Â  
  The refereeâ€™s analysis is in keeping with the rule that the question of competency 
  relates only to the date of the transaction.Â  Church v. Trotter, 278 
  S.C. 504, 506, 299 S.E.2d 332, 333 (1983) (â€œ[T]his Court has looked specifically 
  to the condition of a party at the time of a transaction.â€).Â  Respondent, on 
  the other hand, introduced the testimony of Ms. Wright, the bank employee under 
  specific instructions not to transact any business with Cave unless she was 
  alert and in a position to do business.Â  This was the only testimony of an unbiased 
  witness as to Caveâ€™s capacity at the time of the transaction.Â  Accordingly, 
  viewing the record in full, we find sufficient evidence to support the refereeâ€™s 
  conclusion that the burden of proving Caveâ€™s incapacity was unmet by Appellant.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
REA Construction
Company,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v. 

  
    
      
Columbia Country
Club,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
Joseph M. Strickland, Master-in-Equity 

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-188
Submitted November 3, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard D. Ries and John S. Nichols, both of Columbia, for 
  Appellant.
James Coffas and James D. Cooper, Jr., both of Columbia, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this contract case, REA 
  Construction Company (â€œREAâ€) sued Columbia Country Club (â€œCountry Clubâ€) for 
  the remaining balance due on a construction contract, plus interest and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  The master-in-equity granted judgment to REA, finding Country Club owed 
  REA a total of $135,221.55.Â  Country Club appeals, arguing: 1) the contract 
  was ambiguous as to whether it was a unit price contract; 2) even assuming the 
  contract was not ambiguous, the contract was orally modified into a fixed price 
  contract; 3) Country Club was not bound by the portions of the contract requiring 
  it to pay interest on past due amounts and attorneyâ€™s fees connected with the 
  collection of past due amounts; and 4) REA breached the implied covenant of 
  good faith and fair dealing.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In 1998, Country Club solicited bids for 
  a construction project that entailed resurfacing a parking lot, repairing cart 
  paths along a golf course, and completing miscellaneous work to other areas 
  of its business.Â  
Although REA faxed its proposal to Country 
  Club in July of 1998, Country Clubâ€™s board of directors did not approve the 
  project for more than a year.Â  
On August 11, 1999, Don Litchford, a member of 
  Country Clubâ€™s board of directors, signed the â€œProposal and Contract Formâ€ (â€œthe 
  contractâ€) on behalf of Country Club.Â  William Rosengarten, a commercial manager 
  for REA, signed the contract on REAâ€™s behalf. 
The contract provided prices for various units 
  of work to be performed and listed $135,182.50 as the estimated price for the 
  total project. The contract also contained provisions authorizing REA to collect 
  interest on past due amounts and attorneyâ€™s fees. 
 After the parties signed the contract, Ray Ross, 
  Country Clubâ€™s representative on the project, met with Tim Metz, an employee 
  of REA, to discuss the scope of work to be completed pursuant to the contract.Â Â  

When the work on the project was finished, 
  REA sent a final bill in the amount of $208,406.94.Â  Country Club made a payment 
  to REA in the amount of $117,407.50, but refused to make additional payments.Â  

REA commenced this action on October 11, 2000, 
  alleging Country Club breached the contract.Â  As damages, REA sought the difference 
  between the amount of the final bill and the amount paid by Country Club, as 
  well as interest on the outstanding balance and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Country Club 
  answered, denying the breach of contract claim, and counterclaimed for breach 
  of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, negligence, and unfair trade 
  practices pursuant to the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act. [1] Â  
In an order dated July 25, 2002, the master 
  found the parties entered into a valid unit price contract, and Country Club 
  had breached that contract by refusing to pay the invoice amount.Â  Accordingly, 
  REA was awarded a judgment against Country Club for $135,221.55, which consisted 
  of the remainder of the amount billed, plus interest and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Country 
  Club appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to construe a contract is an 
  action at law.â€Â  Pruitt v. South Carolina Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting 
  Assoc., 343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001).Â  In an action at 
  law, the appellate court will correct any error of law, but it must affirm the 
  masterâ€™s factual findings unless there is no evidence that reasonably supports 
  those findings.Â  Sea Cabins on the Ocean IV Homeowners Assâ€™n v. City of N. 
  Myrtle Beach, 337 S.C. 380, 388, 523 S.E.2d 193, 197 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ambiguous 
  Contract
Country Club argues the master erred by finding 
  the contract was not ambiguous as to whether it was a unit price contract.Â  
  We disagree.
If a contract is clear on its face and reasonably 
  susceptible to only one interpretation, it is not ambiguous.Â  Padgett v. 
  South Carolina Ins. Reserve Fund, 340 S.C. 250, 254, 531 S.E.2d 305, 307 
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Conversely, â€œ[a] contract is ambiguous when the terms of the 
  contract are reasonably susceptible of more than one interpretation.â€Â  South 
  Carolina Dept. of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 
  623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001).Â  When the language of the contract is ambiguous, 
  parol evidence is allowed to determine the intent of the parties.Â  Southern 
  Atlantic Fin. Servs. v. Middleton, 349 S.C. 77, 81, 562 S.E.2d 482, 484-85 
  (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
The determination of whether the language of a 
  contract is ambiguous is a question of law.Â  McClellanville, 345 S.C. 
  at 623, 550 S.E.2d at 302-03.
 Initially, we note, Country Club does not deny 
  the contract is clear on its face.Â  The front page of the contract stated the 
  price was â€œestimatedâ€ and the contract was â€œa unit price contract.â€ 
Instead, Country Club argues these two terms, estimated 
  and unit price contract, each have more than one reasonable meaning, rendering 
  the contract ambiguous.Â  Specifically, Country Club argues these words in the 
  contract could mean REA was only allowed to charge the estimated amount, and 
  any additional work authorized by Country Club would be billed at a unit price.Â  
  The master disagreed with this argument, as do we.
The meaning proposed by Country Club for the term 
  estimated would render the term meaningless.Â  Further, nothing in the contract 
  required REA to seek Country Clubâ€™s approval to exceed the estimated total listed 
  on the front page of the contract.Â  
Additionally, as to the term unit price contract, 
  the attachment to the contract outlined estimated expenditures.Â  For each type 
  of work to be performed, a subsection provided the price per unit, the estimated 
  number of units to be used, and the estimated total price for that subsection. [2] Â  A statement on the front page of the contract instructed measurements 
  to be taken to determine the total amount to charge for the work performed pursuant 
  to the contract.Â  Further, the contract contained no language suggesting the 
  estimated number of units could only be increased if Country Club authorized 
  additional work.
We conclude the master correctly held the contract 
  was not ambiguous.Â  Therefore, the master did not err in deciding the contract 
  was a unit price contract. [3] Â  Id. at 623, 550 S.E.2d at 302-03 (â€œIt 
  is a question of law for the court whether the language of a contract is ambiguous.â€).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Oral Modification
Country Club argues even assuming the contract originally 
  was a unit price contract, the master erred by failing to find the contract 
  was orally modified into a fixed price contract.Â  We disagree.
After the contract was signed, Ross, Country Clubâ€™s 
  representative on the project, and Metz, an employee of REA, discussed modifications 
  to the contract.Â  Ross testified Country Club wanted to increase the size of 
  a parking lot, as well as add parking-lot islands and several man-hole covers.Â  
  He also testified Country Club had decided against installing several cart paths.Â  
  According to Ross, these changes would result in a total cost of $121,000.00 
  for the project.Â  Ross testified Metz agreed with Ross that the price of the 
  project was to remain within Country Clubâ€™s $121,000.00 budget.Â  Based on this 
  conversation between Ross and Metz, Country Club argues the unit price contract 
  was modified into a fixed price contract.
Generally, a written contract may be orally 
  modified.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 
  (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œAny modification of a written contract must satisfy all requisites 
  of a valid contract.â€Â  Player v. Chandler, 299 S.C. 101, 104, 382 S.E.2d 
  891, 893 (1989).Â  However, a person who enters into a contract on behalf of 
  a company must have authority to do so for the contract to be valid.Â  Pee 
  Dee Nursing Home v. Florence Gen. Hosp., 309 S.C. 80, 81-85, 419 S.E.2d 
  834, 835-37 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
The master found no evidence to suggest Metz had 
  the authority to negotiate contracts on behalf of REA and concluded these discussions 
  between Ross and Metz did not result in a valid contract modification. 
The record supports this conclusion.Â  Ross testified 
  he assumed Metz was the project manager for REA, but that Metz did not make 
  such a representation.Â  Ross also testified he, not REA, had given Metz a copy 
  of the contract. 
Because the evidence supports the masterâ€™s conclusion 
  that there was no modification of the written contract, we hold the master did 
  not abuse its discretion.Â  
Country Club also contends 
  that because the testimony of Litchford and Ross as to the modification was 
  not contradicted by REA, the master erred by failing to rule the contract had 
  been modified.Â  However, the trier of fact is not required to accept uncontradicted 
  testimony as true.Â  Black v. Hodge, 306 S.C. 196, 198, 410 S.E.2d 595, 
  596 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Therefore, the master did not err by ruling against Country 
  Club on this issue.Â Â  
III. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Contract Provisions Concerning Interest and Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Country Club argues there is no evidence in the record 
  from which the master could have concluded Country Club agreed to be bound by 
  the portions of the contract requiring it to pay interest on past due amounts 
  and attorneyâ€™s fees connected with the collection of past due amounts.Â  We disagree.
â€œA person signing a document is responsible for reading 
  the document and making sure of its contents. Every contracting party owes a 
  duty to the other party to the contract and to the public to learn the contents 
  of a document before he signs it.â€Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 
  648, 663, 582 S.E.2d 432, 440 (Ct. App. 2003); see Munoz v. Green 
  Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 541, 542 S.E.2d 360, 365 (2001) (â€œ[A] person 
  who can read is bound to read an agreement before signing it.â€).Â  
Although Litchford admits signing the contract 
  on behalf of Country Club, Litchford testified that he did not read the â€œGeneral 
  Terms and Conditionsâ€ section, the section relating to interest and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  Because Litchford failed to read this section of the contract, Country 
  Club argues it should not be required to pay interest or attorneyâ€™s fees.
Litchfordâ€™s signature is located on the front page 
  of the contract.Â  Above Litchfordâ€™s signature, there is a provision that states 
  â€œ[REA] propose[s] to furnish all the necessary supervision, labor, equipment 
  and materials required to complete the following work as outlined below, subject 
  to terms and conditions stated below and on reverse side hereof and incorporated 
  as part of this proposal.â€ (emphasis added).Â  
The â€œGeneral Terms and Conditionsâ€ section is located 
  on the back of the first page of the contract.Â  One of its subsections authorizes 
  REA to collect interest on past due accounts, while another subsection allows 
  REA to recoup attorneyâ€™s fees related to the collection of past due amounts.Â  

Because Litchford acknowledged 
  signing the contract, the master did not err by concluding Country Club was 
  bound by the â€œGeneral Terms & Conditionsâ€ section of the contract.Â  
Country Club also argues 
  the â€œGeneral Terms & Conditionsâ€ section of the contract was not conspicuous, 
  and as such, Country Club should not be bound by it.Â  To support this proposition, 
  Country Club relies on Kumpf v. United Tel. Co. of Carolinas, 311 S.C. 
  533, 429 S.E.2d 869 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
In Kumpf, this court 
  was confronted with the task of determining whether a contract disclaimer in 
  an employee handbook was sufficiently conspicuous to assure the promises in 
  the handbook were nonbinding.Â  Id. at 537, 429 S.E.2d at 872.Â  To assist 
  in its determination, this Court looked to the South Carolina Uniform Commercial 
  Code (â€œUCCâ€) for guidance as to the definition of conspicuous.Â  Id.Â Â  

In Kumpf, we did 
  not hold all contract provisions must be conspicuous, and we decline to do so 
  now.Â  Further, because Kumpf does not discuss contract provisions concerning 
  interest or attorneyâ€™s fees, and we have found no South Carolina cases specifically 
  requiring contract provisions regarding interest or attorneyâ€™s fees to be conspicuous, 
  we hold there is no requirement that these provisions be conspicuous.Â  Thus, 
  Country Clubâ€™s argument is without merit.
IV.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Implied Covenant of Good Faith and 
  Fair Dealing
Country Club argues REAâ€™s 
  failure to obtain approval before increasing the price of the project was a 
  breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[T]here exists in every 
  contract an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.â€Â  Commercial 
  Credit Corp. v. Nelson Motors, 247 S.C. 360, 367, 147 S.E.2d 481, 484 (1966).Â  
  â€œHowever, there is no breach of an implied covenant of good faith where a party 
  to a contract has done what provisions of the contract expressly gave him the 
  right to do.â€Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 
  S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995). 
Because we have concluded 
  the master was correct in finding the parties entered into an unambiguous unit 
  price contract and Country Club was bound by it, there is no evidence to support 
  bad faith on the part of REA.Â  
The attachment to the contract 
  outlined estimated expenditures.Â  For each type of work to be performed, a subsection 
  provided the price per unit, the estimated number of units to be used, and the 
  estimated total price for that subsection.Â  Both the number of units and the 
  total price for the subsection were labeled as estimates.Â  Although REA increased 
  the number of units used in the project and this increase in units was reflected 
  in the final bill, the unit price did not increase.Â  Because only estimated 
  terms increased, REA performed according to the contract.Â  Therefore, the master 
  did not err by finding that REA did not breach the implied covenant of good 
  faith and fair dealing.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing 
  reasons, the masterâ€™s decisions are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1]  The master found Country Club failed to prove its claims for negligence 
    and unfair trade practices.Â  These rulings are not appealed.

 
   
    [2]  Under the heading â€œResurfacing Lot and Related Work,â€ for example, 
    the price for the parking lot resurfacing was shown as â€œ$36.00 per ton. We 
    estimated 12.070 square yards.Â  This yields approximately 1,000 
    tons.Â  Subtotal estimated price = $36,000.00.â€Â  Â (emphasis added). 
  

 
   
    [3]  Country Club further argues both parties intended a fixed price contract, 
    and thus, the contract should be reformed.Â  Because Rosengarten signed the 
    contract on behalf of REA, and Rosengarten testified REA intended to create 
    a unit price contract, there is evidence that reasonably supports the masterâ€™s 
    implicit decision that there was no mutual mistake as to the type of contract 
    entered into by the parties.Â  See Crosby v. Protective Life Ins. 
    Co., 293 S.C. 203, 206, 359 S.E.2d 298, 300 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œA contract 
    may be reformed on the ground of mistake when the mistake is mutual. . . . 
    A mistake is mutual where both parties intended a certain thing and by mistake 
    in the drafting did not obtain what was intended.â€).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Laura T. Tyler,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mary Gail T. Salley, Personal Representative of the Estate of Hal Barr 
        Tyler,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-189
Submitted March 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

 
AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jan L. Warner, of Columbia; for Appellant
Elizabeth Van Doren Gray and Laura W. Robinson, both of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Laura T. Tyler commenced 
  this action by filing a Summons and Petition seeking, among other things, to 
  have Respondent Mary Gail T. Salley removed as the personal representative for 
  the estate of Hal Barr Tyler and to have a substitute personal representative 
  appointed.Â  The trial court denied all requested relief. [1] 
FACTS
On December 10, 1997, Hal Barr Tyler died 
  of cancer.Â  Unable to locate her husbandâ€™s will, Laura Tyler hired an attorney 
  and filed an intestate estate with the Probate Court for Richland County.Â  Halâ€™s 
  will was eventually recovered, and in accordance with its terms, Halâ€™s sister 
  Mary Gail T. Salley was appointed personal representative of the estate on January 
  26, 1998.
When Salley learned that she was the named 
  personal representative, she hired Elaine H. Fowler, an attorney who practices 
  in the area of probate administration, to represent and advise her in connection 
  with the performance of her duties and responsibilities as personal representative.Â  
  According to the testimony offered at trial, Salley did not take any action 
  as personal representative without express guidance and direction from Fowler.
Under the will, Salley was to receive 
  a one-half interest in farmland located in Orangeburg, South Carolina; Halâ€™s 
  inherited interest in certain personal property; the proceeds from a $51,000 
  life insurance policy; and a $50,000 specific bequest.Â  The residuary was left 
  to Tyler and included SCANA stock, a duplex on Brennen Road, and other personal 
  property.Â  
During his lifetime, Hal took out a loan 
  against the proceeds of a $10,000.00 life insurance policy of which Salley was 
  the beneficiary.Â  After receiving the remaining proceeds of the policy after 
  Halâ€™s death, upon the advice of Fowler, Salley took out $4,214 from the estate.Â  
  This represented the difference between the initial policy amount and the reduced 
  value of the policy.Â  When Fowler realized her advice was mistaken, she instructed 
  Salley to reimburse the estate.Â  Salley then repaid the estate with interest.
On July 1, 1999, Tyler filed a Summons 
  and Petition in the Probate Court, seeking to have Salley removed as personal 
  representative and to have a substitute personal representative appointed.Â  
  She sought to disgorge all attorneyâ€™s fees paid to Fowler and all commissions 
  paid to Salley.Â  The trial court denied Tylerâ€™s requested relief.Â  This appeal 
  follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A request to remove a personal representative seeks 
  affirmative relief that lies in equity.Â  Dean v. Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 
  437 S.E.2d 154 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  As such, we may make findings according to 
  our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, though we need not disregard 
  the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a 
  better position to judge their credibility.Â  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 
  571, 544 S.E.2d 856, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Removal
Tyler contends that the trial court erred 
  in not removing Salley as personal representative.Â  We disagree.
Although the appointment of a personal representative 
  â€œis not lightly to be set aside,â€ the Probate Code provides that anyone â€œinterested 
  in the estate may petition for removal of a personal representative for cause 
  at any time.â€Â  See Witherspoon v. Watts, 18 S.C. 396, 422 (1883); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-611(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  

Cause for removal exists when removal would be in the best 
  interests of the estate, or if it is shown that a personal representative or 
  the person seeking his appointment intentionally misrepresented material facts 
  in the proceedings leading to his appointment, or that the personal representative 
  has disregarded an order of the court, has become incapable of discharging the 
  duties of his office, or has mismanaged the estate or failed to perform any 
  duty pertaining to the office.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-611(b) (Supp. 2003).Â  
Tylerâ€™s numerous complaints can be summarized into 
  two general categorical allegations:Â  (1) Salley was late in performing her 
  obligations; and (2) she engaged in self-dealing.Â  
In support of her contention that Salley 
  was excessively dilatory in administering the estate, Tyler notes that Salley 
  did not file the estateâ€™s inventory until more than a year after it was initially 
  due and did not file the Form 706 estate tax return until almost a year after 
  the initial due date.Â  In both cases, however, Salley received deadline extensions 
  from the relevant authority.Â  Moreover, evidence presented at trial indicates 
  that Tyler at least shared the blame with Salley for any unnecessary delays.Â  
  Tyler and her counsel engaged Salley and Fowler in lengthy discussions concerning 
  what property was to be included in the estate and how much it was worth, and 
  Tylerâ€™s indecisiveness on the elective share issue only acted to forestall finality.Â  
  In any event, the rather modest delays in this case have not so jeopardized 
  the best interest of the estate as to warrant removing the personal representative.
We find Tylerâ€™s allegations of self-dealing to 
  be unfounded.Â  Although Salley did improperly remove $4,214 from the estate 
  to repay a loan Hal had taken against a life insurance policy, she did so at 
  the advice of the estateâ€™s attorney.Â  When Salley realized there had been a 
  mistake about the propriety of the transaction, she reimbursed the estate with 
  interest.Â  Nonetheless, Tyler asserts that the absence of the funds from the 
  estate caused a cash shortfall, precluding Salley from making necessary repairs 
  to the duplex on Brennen Road and forcing her to sell the SCANA stocks for too 
  low of a price.Â  
Contrary to Tylerâ€™s contention, Salley did not 
  fail to make necessary repairs to the Brennen Road duplex for want of estate 
  funds.Â  Quite the opposite, at a cost of $3,500, [2]  Salley arranged to have the roof of the duplex 
  repaired to prevent damage from leakage.Â  The only repairs she forwent were 
  those she deemed to be cosmetic in nature.Â  Indeed, even without the cosmetic 
  repairs, tenants regularly occupied the duplex during the estateâ€™s administration, 
  thereby generating rental income for the estate. 
We find most remarkable Tylerâ€™s contention that 
  Salley wasted estate assets by selling the SCANA stocks too early:Â  

Mrs. Salley also admitted that, because the estate needed 
  money to pay its lawyers, she sold SCANA stock at $27.00 per share when, if 
  she had made one phone call or kept up with this investment in the newspaper, 
  she would have learned that had she waited six weeks, the stock could have been 
  sold for $30.00 per share.

Though the role of personal representative comes 
  with many responsibilities, stock market clairvoyance is certainly not one of 
  them.Â  A personal representative does not waste estate assets when she fails 
  to anticipate fluctuation in the value of securities.
We see no error committed by the trial 
  judge, who after considering the testimony of Salley, Tyler, and the estate 
  attorney, determined that Salley had not failed to perform any duty as personal 
  representative, engaged in willful misconduct, or improperly disposed of estate 
  assets.Â  Accordingly, we conclude the trial court did not err in refusing to 
  remove Salley as personal representative.
Disgorgement
Tyler contends that the trial court erred 
  in refusing to disgorge attorneyâ€™s fees paid to the attorney hired by Salley 
  to assist her in her role as personal representative.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina law specifically authorizes and 
  empowers personal representatives to hire attorneys, accountants, and advisors 
  to perform or assist in the performance of the personal representativeâ€™s duties.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-715(19) (1987).Â  The personal representative is likewise 
  authorized to hire counsel when an estate brings or defends a lawsuit.Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-715(20) (1987).Â  Section 62-3-720 specifically makes the estate 
  responsible for the resulting attorneyâ€™s fees:

If any personal representative or person nominated as personal 
  representative defends or prosecutes any proceeding in good faith, whether successful 
  or not, he is entitled to receive from the estate his necessary expenses and 
  disbursements including reasonable attorneysâ€™ fees incurred.

The attorney hired by Salley charged $150.00 
  per hour, and prior to the litigation commenced by Tyler, Salley had spent only 
  $8,342.05 in attorneyâ€™s fees on a $200,000.00 estate.Â  We agree with the trial 
  courtâ€™s determination that the fees paid by Salley were not excessive and find 
  ample evidence in the record to support that finding. 
  [3] 
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  The Record on Appeal erroneously refers to $35,000.

 
   
    [3] Â  We likewise dismiss Tylerâ€™s claim that the trial court should have 
    allowed her to recover fees paid to Salley as personal representative or against 
    Salleyâ€™s beneficial interest.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Joyce Smith and Brenda L. Warren Brown, as Personal Representatives of 
        the Estate of Christopher Bernard Smith,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The South Carolina Department of Transportation, an Agency of the State 
        of South Carolina, and William P. Cannington,       
Defendants,
of whom William P. Cannington is       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Robert A. Smoak, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-190
Submitted March 8, 2004- Filed March 
  22, 2004Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James H. Moss, of Beaufort, for Appellants.
Robin A. Braithwaite, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:  Joyce Smith and Brenda L. Warren 
  Brown, as personal representatives of the Estate of Christopher Bernard Smith 
  (â€œthe Estateâ€), commenced this wrongful death action against the South Carolina 
  Department of Transportation (â€œSCDOTâ€) and William P. Cannington.Â  In this appeal, 
  the Estate argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Cannington 
  and in finding insufficient evidence existed for the submission of a conscious 
  pain and suffering claim against Cannington.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTS
This case arose out of an automobile 
  accident, which occurred on November 10, 1997.Â  Christopher Bernard Smith (â€œthe 
  Decedentâ€) drove a tractor-trailer from Jasper County, South Carolina to Augusta, 
  Georgia where he picked up a load of fertilizer.Â  As he was returning to Ridgeland, 
  South Carolina along Highway 278 in Aiken County, he encountered a detour, which 
  routed him off Highway 278 and onto a series of secondary roads.Â Â Â  
SCDOT created the detour due to construction on 
  the closed portion of Highway 278.Â  The detour eventually led travelers to DeSoto 
  Road, which intersects back into Highway 278 at a T-type intersection.Â  Travelers 
  on DeSoto Road encountered a steep downgrade for a short distance prior to the 
  intersection with Highway 278.Â  For unknown reasons, the Decedent failed to 
  stop when he reached the intersection, and as he turned the tractor-trailer 
  to the right and onto the highway, it overturned resulting in his death.Â  
Following the accident, the Estate commenced wrongful 
  death and conscious pain and suffering actions against SCDOT and William P. 
  Cannington.Â  The Estate alleged SCDOT was negligent in several particulars related 
  to the detour.Â  For example, the Estate averred SCDOT was negligent in its failure 
  to erect proper signs warning travelers of the T-type intersection at DeSoto 
  Road and Highway 278.Â Â  
As to Cannington, the owner of the tractor-trailer 
  the Decedent was operating at the time of the accident, the Estate alleged inter 
  alia that he was negligent in failing to provide a vehicle in suitable 
  mechanical condition, and that this failure caused or contributed to the Decedentâ€™s 
  death.Â  
On April 26, 2001, SCDOT moved for summary judgment 
  on the Estateâ€™s cause of action for conscious pain and suffering.Â  On May 22, 
  2002, the trial court issued an order granting SCDOTâ€™s motion, stating that 
  no issue of material fact existed which would establish that the Decedent was 
  conscious prior to his death.Â  Following the grant of summary judgment, the 
  Estate and SCDOT reached a settlement, and thus, SCDOT is no longer a party 
  to this action.Â  
Cannington moved for complete summary 
  judgment on April 4, 2002, arguing no evidence rising beyond mere speculation 
  was presented that the vehicle was in an unsafe condition.Â  On June 18, 2002, 
  the trial court granted Canningtonâ€™s motion.Â  The Estate filed motions to alter 
  or amend; those motions were denied by order dated August 16, 2002.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Estate argues the trial court erred 
  in granting summary judgment to Cannington.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.â€Â  Fisher v. Stevens, 355 S.C. 290, 294, 584 S.E.2d 149, 
  151 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 
  S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 (1991)). Accordingly, summary judgment is appropriate 
  when â€œâ€˜there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and . . . the moving 
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, as 
  will preclude summary judgment, the evidence and all inferences which can be 
  reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the 
  nonmoving party.â€Â  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 341, 499 S.E.2d 
  488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998).
Thus, an issue must be submitted to a 
  jury when material evidence exists tending to establish the point in the minds 
  of reasonable jurors.Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 353 S.C. 596, 609, 
  579 S.E.2d 136, 142-143 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  However, this does not mean an issue 
  must be presented to a jury if the presentation rests on â€œspeculative, theoretical 
  and hypotheticalâ€ views.Â  Id.Â  This is part and parcel of the firmly 
  established rule that â€œverdicts may not be permitted to rest upon surmise, conjecture 
  or speculation.â€Â  Small v. Pioneer Machinery, Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 461, 
  494 S.E.2d 835, 841 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Hanahan v. Simpson, 
  326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997). 
  [2] 
The Estate points to eleven specific factors 
  the trial court failed to consider when granting Canningtonâ€™s summary judgment 
  motion.Â  However, only three of the eleven are even arguably relevant in making 
  the determination of whether something was wrong with Canningtonâ€™s vehicle.Â  
  The Estate mentions the presence of skid marks showing the Decedentâ€™s attempt 
  to make the turn, the speed at which the Decedent was attempting to make the 
  turn, and the fact that the brakes on the right side of the trailer â€œshould 
  have loaded if, in fact, they were working.â€Â  The Estate also points out that 
  the trial court failed to mention that the vehicle had brake problems.Â  
Although it is true the trial court did 
  not specifically state that the vehicle had previous brake problems, the court 
  does acknowledge that the vehicle passed the required safety inspection within 
  one year of the accident.Â  The trial court also noted that preventive maintenance 
  had been performed on the vehicleâ€™s braking system in the weeks prior to the 
  accident.Â  In addition, Lonnie Grant, the mechanic who performed the maintenance 
  on the vehicle, testified he drove the truck the week he worked on it and that 
  it â€œ[drove] good.â€Â  It is also important to note, as the trial court did, that 
  the only person who inspected the actual vehicle, Officer Richard Todd Sawyer 
  of the South Carolina State Transport Police, testified that his visual inspection 
  of the vehicle produced no evidence from which it might be inferred that the 
  brakes were not working properly.Â  
The Estate points to the deposition testimony 
  of two accident reconstruction experts, Joe Wade Kent and Ronald Kirk, to support 
  its contention that something was wrong with the vehicleâ€™s brakes.Â  However, 
  neither of these experts states with any reasonable degree of certainty that 
  the brakes were inoperable or contributed to causing the accident.Â  In fact, 
  Kent testified that â€œone of the possibilities and fairly likely probabilit[ies] 
  is that during the time the driver was trying to make this right turn he was 
  not on the brakes, that he was just trying to make the turn.â€Â  His point was 
  not that the brakes were never applied, but that no physical evidence of braking 
  existed.Â  When specifically asked whether he could say with a reasonable degree 
  of â€œengineering certaintyâ€ that the brakes had anything to do with the accident, 
  Kent replied as follows: â€œI donâ€™t think I could really state it anymore explicitly 
  than I already have.Â  There are [three] possible causes, and it could be any 
  one or any combination to [sic] any percentage of those [three].â€Â  
Similarly, Kirk testified that he could 
  not state â€œto a reasonable degree of engineering certainty that there was anything 
  wrong with the truck brakes.â€Â  When asked whether he had formed any opinions 
  within a reasonable degree of certainty as to the cause of the accident, Kirk 
  stated: â€œWhat led to [the accident], I donâ€™t know.Â  Whether it was a braking 
  deficiency, whether its inattention, some combination, whether he didnâ€™t see 
  the stop sign soon enough, I just donâ€™t know.Â  Or whether some third vehicle 
  may have been somehow responsible.Â  I just donâ€™t know all that.â€Â  
Thus, because no evidence existed which 
  rose beyond conjecture or speculation that the brakes on the vehicle were defective, 
  we find the trial court did not err in granting Cannington summary judgment. [3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor 
  of Cannington is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY,
JJ., concur.

 
    [1]    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
     
    [2]    The Estate appears to argue that the adoption of comparative negligence 
    has somehow changed the standard for the grant or denial of a motion for summary 
    judgment.Â  As is apparent by the cases relied on in the preceding paragraph, 
    however, this argument is without merit.

 
    [3]    Because we find the trial court did not err in 
    granting Canningtonâ€™s motion for complete summary judgment, we need not address 
    the Estateâ€™s argument regarding the Decedentâ€™s conscious pain and suffering.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Melva Vatick,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Federal Credit Union,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-191
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Reese I. Joye and J. Craig Smith, of N. Charleston; Stephen 
  L. Brown, of Charleston; for Appellant.
Andrea St. Amand and Richard A. Farrier, Jr., of Charleston; 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Melva Vatick 
  filed a negligence suit against South Carolina Federal Credit Union for damages 
  incurred when she fell after using Credit Unionâ€™s automatic teller machine.Â  
  At the close of Vatickâ€™s case, the trial court granted Credit Unionâ€™s motion 
  for a directed verdict.Â  Vatick appeals.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Vatick, a customer of Credit 
  Union, routinely used its automatic teller machine (ATM).Â  Vatick testified 
  that she always parked her car in front of the building and walked to the ATM, 
  which included climbing one step from the pathway to the ATM enclosure.Â  Vatick 
  testified she would then withdraw money from the ATM and immediately count it.Â Â  

On the day in question, Vatick drove 
  to Credit Union, accompanied by her nephew.Â  Due to construction outside of 
  Credit Unionâ€™s building, Vatick was forced to park on the right side of the 
  building, in a space where she never parked before. 
  [2] Â  Vatick parked the car and walked over to the ATM.Â  Vatick testified 
  that she walked through the construction site along a path that included two 
  steps in order to reach the ATM.Â  Vatick stated that she saw red cones in the 
  construction area and agreed with defense counselâ€™s contention that such cones 
  generally indicated that one should â€œproceed with caution.â€Â  However, Vatick 
  testified there were no warning signs, handrailings, or personnel from Credit 
  Union present at the site to warn her to watch her step.Â Â Â  
While Vatick stated the path through 
  the construction site was â€œnarrow,â€ Vatick did not require her nephewâ€™s assistance 
  to reach the ATM.Â  In fact, Vatick successfully navigated the parking lot, the 
  temporary path, and the two unfamiliar steps up to the ATM.Â  Vatick testified 
  the steps to the ATM were not obstructed.Â  After Vatick used the ATM, she began 
  to count her money.Â  She testified that she was â€œintriguedâ€ by the design of 
  the new twenty-dollar bill, and began to walk back to her car while looking 
  at the bill.Â  Vatick fell down the two steps on the temporary path and was injured.Â  
  She filed a complaint alleging Credit Union was â€œnegligent, reckless, and breached 
  the dutiesâ€ owed to her.Â  
At the close of Vatickâ€™s case, 
  Credit Union moved for a directed verdict.Â  The trial judge granted the motion.Â  
  Though Vatick filed a motion for reconsideration under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, it 
  was denied.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn deciding whether to grant 
  or deny a directed verdict motion, the trial court is concerned only with the 
  existence or non-existence of evidence.â€Â  Sims v. Giles, 343 S.C. 708, 
  714, 541 S.E.2d 857, 861 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This court can reverse the trial 
  court only when there is no evidence to support the ruling below.Â  Sabb v. 
  South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Vatick
argues the trial court erred in granting Credit Unionâ€™s motion for a directed
verdict.  We do not agree.
 In order to establish a claim 
  for negligence, the plaintiff must prove the following elements:Â  1) a duty 
  of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff; 2) a breach of that duty by 
  the defendantâ€™s negligent act or omission; 3) the plaintiff was damaged; and 
  4) the damages proximately resulted from the breach of the duty.Â  Thomasko 
  v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 11, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002).Â  â€œIn a negligence 
  action, the court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the defendant 
  owed a duty of care to the plaintiff.â€Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 334, 566 S.E.2d 536, 545 (2002) (citation 
  omitted); see also Doe v. Batson, 345 S.C. 316, 322-23, 
  548 S.E.2d 854, 857 (2001) (â€œAn essential element in a cause of action for negligence 
  is the existence of a legal duty of care owed by the defendant to the plaintiff.â€).Â Â Â Â 
  â€œA merchant is not an insurer 
    of the safety of his customer but owes only the duty of exercising ordinary 
    care to keep the premises in reasonably safe condition.â€Â  Garvin v. Bi-Lo, 
    Inc., 343 S.C. 625, 628, 541 S.E.2d 831, 832 (2001) (citation omitted); 
    see also Wintersteen v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 
    36, 542 S.E.2d 728, 730 (2001) (â€œStorekeeper liability is founded upon the 
    duty of care a possessor of land owes to an invitee.â€).Â  A merchant does not 
    owe a duty to maintain its premises in such a condition that no accident could 
    happen to a patron.Â  See Denton v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 
    312 S.C. 119, 120, 439 S.E.2d 292, 293 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œTo recover damages 
    for injuries caused by a dangerous or defective condition on a storekeeperâ€™s 
    premises, the plaintiff must show either (1) that the injury was caused by 
    a specific act of the respondent which created the dangerous condition; or 
    (2) that the respondent had actual or constructive knowledge of the dangerous 
    condition and failed to remedy it.â€Â  Garvin, 343 S.C. at 628, 541 S.E.2d 
    at 832 (citations omitted).
   Credit Union, as a merchant, 
    owed Vatick the duty of exercising ordinary care to keep its premises, including 
    its passageways, in a reasonably safe condition.Â  See Wintersteen, 
    344 S.C. at 36, 542 S.E.2d at 730 (stating that a merchant owes a duty to 
    keep aisles and passageways in a reasonably safe condition).Â  Therefore, under 
    the two part analysis set forth in Garvin, Vatick must present evidence 
    to prove either that her injury was caused by a specific act by Credit Union 
    which created a dangerous condition or that Credit Union had knowledge of 
    a dangerous condition and failed to remedy it.Â  See Garvin, 
    343 S.C. at 628, 541 S.E.2d at 832.Â  
  Vatick failed to present evidence to 
    satisfy the first part of the Garvin test, that her injuries resulted 
    from a specific act of Credit Union that created a dangerous condition.Â  Initially, 
    we note Vatick does not identify a particular hazard that proximately caused 
    her to fall.Â  Rather, she appears to imply the construction site in the entire 
    ATM area was hazardous.Â  While Credit Union initiated the construction work 
    on its premises, we do not find it created a dangerous condition.Â  Vatick 
    testified there was a â€œnarrowâ€ path to the ATM, but she did not state she 
    had any trouble walking along it.Â  Vatick also testified her view of the area 
    was unobstructed and that she noticed red cones in the area.Â  However, Vatick 
    did not state these cones were blocking the path and testified that she knew 
    this indicated she should be cautious.Â  Further, while Vatickâ€™s testimony 
    seems to imply the addition of an extra step leading up to the ATM caused 
    her to fall, Vatick testified she noticed the path had two steps and successfully 
    navigated the steps on her way to the ATM.Â  This court has found a merchant 
    was not liable when a customer was injured after failing to step over a clearly 
    visible and unobstructed object.Â  See Denton, 312 S.C. at 121-22, 
    439 S.E.2d at 294 (finding the store was not liable when the patron testified 
    she saw the clearly visible concrete dividers in the parking lot but that 
    she was preoccupied and tripped over one of the dividers).Â  Finally, Vatick 
    suggests that the lack of railings along the path and steps created a dangerous 
    condition; however, because we find the construction, path, and step did not 
    create a dangerous condition as they existed, this argument is without merit.
  Vatick also failed to present evidence 
    to satisfy the second part of the Garvin test, that Credit Union had 
    actual or constructive knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to 
    remedy it.Â  Vatick appears to argue Credit Union should have known, by virtue 
    of performing construction in the ATM area, that a dangerous condition could 
    have resulted.Â  However, Vatick failed to establish that a dangerous condition 
    did result or that Credit Union had actual or constructive knowledge of any 
    such dangerous condition.Â  See id. at 121, 439 S.E.2d at 294 
    (â€œAccidents may happen around . . . steps, escalators, and other raised structures.Â  
    This does not mean they are unreasonably dangerous or that a person exercising 
    due care would not have them on the premises.Â  They are, in fact, common structures 
    that a person taking reasonable care for his own safety would likely expect 
    and see while on the premises.â€).Â  By Vatickâ€™s own testimony, she did not 
    require any assistance to walk from the parking lot to the path through the 
    construction area, and up the two steps to the ATM.Â  Further, Vatick admitted 
    that she fell down after she left the ATM and was examining the new twenty-dollar 
    bill while walking to her car.
  It is axiomatic that one cannot prevail 
    on a negligence claim without proving a breach of duty.Â  Because Vatick cannot 
    prove Credit Union breached its duty to exercise ordinary care to keep its 
    premises in a reasonably safe condition, she cannot prevail on this negligence 
    action.Â  See Thomasko, 349 S.C. at 11-12, 561 S.E.2d at 599.Â  
    Accordingly, the trial court did not err in granting Credit Unionâ€™s motion 
    for a directed verdict.
  CONCLUSION 
     Based upon the foregoing, the trial 
      courtâ€™s grant of Credit Unionâ€™s motion for a directed verdict is 
     AFFIRMED.
    HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, 
      J.J., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Vatickâ€™s daughter, who was a Credit Union employee at the time of 
    the accident, testified there was construction at the site in order to erect 
    a new drive-up ATM and eliminate the walk-up ATM.Â  Â Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT 
  SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William Charles Seich,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-192
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson; 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter III, of Columbia; Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy III, of Spartanburg; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: William Charles Seich (â€œSeichâ€) 
  was found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.Â  
  Seich argues on appeal the circuit court erred by admitting into evidence a 
  bullet found at the unsecured crime scene nine days after the murder.Â  We affirm. 

FACTS
On October 28, 2001, a shooting incident took place 
  at the home of Patricia Parris (â€œParrisâ€) that resulted in her death. Â According 
  to Parrisâ€™s daughters, eleven year-old Deann Wilson (â€œDeannâ€) and fourteen year-old 
  Janice Wilson (â€œJaniceâ€), Seich was drinking liquor when they arrived home that 
  evening with their mother.Â  Deann testified Parris and Seich began arguing and 
  Seich pushed Parris and pulled her by the hair. Â Â Parris placed a call 
  to 911.Â  Â Deann testified she and Parris ran outside when Seich pulled 
  out a gun.Â  Janice was not able to exit the mobile home.Â Â  Janice testified 
  Seich pushed her back into the mobile home, causing her to fall on the floor.Â  
  Deann stated after she and Parris ran outside, â€œthe police pulled up and he 
  [Seich] shot Momma.â€ 
When Officers Kevin Carper (â€œCarperâ€) 
  and Jeremy Soukup (â€œSoukupâ€) arrived at the scene, they observed Parris and 
  Seich on the front porch.Â  Soukup testified he â€œheard two, sounded like a cannon 
  to me, shots at point blank range, which I mean is less than a foot, and Mrs. 
  Parris disappeared off that front porch.â€ Â Soukup said he and Carper 
  drew fire at Seich to protect Parris and Deann.Â  Soukup and Carper both testified 
  they did not fire their weapons until Seich fired his gun and they saw Parris 
  fall. Â Officer Carper accidentally shot Janice when he was firing at 
  Seich.Â  Â Janice testified after she and Seich were shot, he started saying 
  he loved her and was sorry he shot Parris. 
The police used 9mm guns and Seich 
  used a .44 Magnum pistol.Â Â  When the SLED agents processed the crime scene on 
  the night of the shooting, they used a metal detector and found seventeen 9mm 
  cartridge casings outside.Â Â  Inside, they found Seichâ€™s gun with four unfired 
  bullets and two fired cartridge casings, a .44 caliber fired cartridge casing, 
  and a fired projectile.Â  They also found a spent projectile from a .44 caliber 
  weapon in the dishwasher of an adjacent mobile home. 
Nine days after the incident, one of the agents 
  returned to the scene, which had been unsecured since the shooting, and 
  found a spent .44 caliber bullet outside on the ground in the approximate location 
  where Parrisâ€™s body had been dragged.Â  The State offered the bullet into 
  evidence, and Seich moved to exclude it.Â  The trial judge allowed the bullet 
  into evidence, but limited the applicable testimony to the fact it was found 
  at the scene.
Dr. David Wren, the pathologist who performed the 
  autopsy on Parris, testified Parris died from a single gunshot wound to the 
  chest and the injury to the chest was more likely caused by a .44 caliber weapon 
  than a 9mm weapon.Â  Â Â 
The jury convicted Seich of murder 
  and the trial judge sentenced him to life imprisonment without parole.Â  Seich 
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This Court may not reverse the trial courtâ€™s 
  ruling on the admissibility of evidence absent an abuse of discretion or the 
  commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant. State 
  v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002); State v. Adams, 
  354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003) (cert. pending).Â  
  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the judgeâ€™s ruling has no evidentiary support.â€Â  
  State v. Manning, 329 S.C. 1, 7, 495 S.E.2d 191, 194 (1997).Â  Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Seich argues the trial court erred 
  by admitting the bullet into evidence.Â  We find any error committed by the trial 
  court was harmless.
Seich contends the State failed to lay 
  a proper foundation to connect the bullet to the crime.Â  Furthermore, Seich 
  argues the introduction of the .44 caliber bullet invited speculation about 
  its connection to the shooting.Â Â Â  
Although it is troubling the bullet was found nine 
  days after the shooting, and from an unsecured crime scene, we find, even assuming 
  the trial court erred in allowing it into evidence, the error was harmless.Â  
  â€œError is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of 
  the trial.â€Â  Adams, 354 S.C. at 380, 580 S.E.2d at 795; State v. Burton, 
  326 S.C. 605, 610, 486 S.E.2d 762, 764 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Appellate courts will 
  not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.Â  
  State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991); State 
  v. Livingston, 282 S.C. 1, 6, 317 S.E.2d 129, 132 (1984).Â  â€œAn insubstantial 
  error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where â€˜guilt has been 
  conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion 
  can be reached.â€™â€Â  Adams, 354 S.C. at 380, 580 S.E.2d at 795 (quoting 
  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989)).
Notwithstanding the admission of the bullet, the 
  State presented abundant evidence proving Seichâ€™s guilt.Â  For example, Deann 
  testified she saw Seich shoot her mother.Â  Â Janice also testified Seich 
  said he was sorry he shot her mother.Â  Officers Soukup and Carper testified 
  they did not begin firing until they saw Parris fall.Â Â  
In addition, the pathologistâ€™s testimony regarding 
  the gunshot wounds provides evidence of Seichâ€™s guilt.Â  He testified the fatal 
  wound to Parrisâ€™s chest was approximately .41 inches by .60 inches in diameter.Â  
  The diameter of a 9mm bullet is .354 inches, whereas the diameter of a .44 caliber 
  bullet is .44 inches.Â  Based on the size of Parrisâ€™s wound, the pathologist 
  determined it was more likely caused by the larger .44 caliber bullet.Â  Â Because 
  Seich was using a .44 caliber weapon and the officers were using 9mm weapons, 
  the pathologistâ€™s testimony is strong evidence proving Seichâ€™s guilt.
CONCLUSION
Based on the above evidence of Seichâ€™s guilt, we find 
  any error committed by the trial court in admitting the .44 caliber bullet into 
  evidence was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  Allowing the bullet into evidence 
  did not result in any prejudice to Seich.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the 
  trial judge is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

v.

Kristina Michelle Anderson, of Aiken; for Guardian Ad

PER CURIAM:Â  Willie Fortner (Father) and 
  Leann Ledford (Mother) are the parents of the minor child, Miranda.Â  Mother 
  is also the mother of the minor children, Stephen and Bethany.Â  The South Carolina 
  Department of Social Services (SCDSS) filed an action to terminate the parental 
  rights of both Mother and Father to all three minor children.Â  The family court 
  judge subsequently terminated the parental rights of both parties.Â  Mother and 
  Father have each appealed this ruling. 
  [1] 
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), 
  SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2003) 
  (finding termination of parental rights statutes â€œmust be liberally construed 
  in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from 
  the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationshipâ€); 
  Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 769-70, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 1403, 71 L. 
  Ed. 2d 599, 617 (1982) (holding the grounds for termination of parental rights 
  must be proven by clear and convincing evidence); South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003) 
  (â€œUpon review, the appellate court may make its own finding from the record 
  as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination.â€); Hooper 
  v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999) (finding this 
  court is not required â€œto ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and 
  heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility 
  and assign comparative weight to their testimonyâ€).Â  
Motherâ€™s appeal:Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2) (Supp. 2003) (A court may terminate parental rights 
  if a child â€œhas been out of the home for a period of six months following the 
  adoption of a placement plan . . . and the parent has not remedied the conditions 
  which caused the removal.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2003) (A court 
  can also terminate parental rights if a child â€œhas lived outside the home of 
  either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has 
  willfully failed to support the childâ€ by failing to make a â€œmaterial contributionâ€ 
  to the childâ€™s care.); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2003) (Parental 
  rights may be terminated if a child was in foster care â€œfor fifteen of the most 
  recent twenty-two months.â€); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 
  307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992) (â€œConduct of the parent which evinces 
  a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€˜willfulâ€™ 
  because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to 
  receive support and consortium from the parent.â€); Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 
  353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œ[O]nce a child has 
  been in foster care for fifteen months, whether those months are consecutive 
  or within the last twenty-two months, the parental rights of that childâ€™s parents 
  may be terminated upon a showing that termination is in the childâ€™s best interests.â€); 
  Boyer v. Boyer, 291 S.C. 183, 186, 352 S.E.2d 514, 516 (Ct. App. 1987) 
  (finding a request for support need not assume a particular form to satisfy 
  the requirements of section 1572(4)).Â  
Fatherâ€™s appeal:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(7) 
  (Supp. 2003) (parental rights can be terminated if the family court finds the 
  child has been abandoned); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2003) (parental 
  rights may be terminated if a child was in foster care â€œfor fifteen of the most 
  recent twenty-two months.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2003) (â€œThe interests 
  of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€); 
  Hamby v. Hamby, 264 S.C. 614, 618, 216 S.E.2d 536, 538 (1975) (affirming 
  a finding of abandonment where Father voluntarily pursued a course of lawlessness 
  resulting in his imprisonment and inability to perform parental duties); Doe 
  v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (â€œ[O]nce a child has been in foster care for fifteen months, whether those months 
  are consecutive or within the last twenty-two months, the parental rights of 
  that childâ€™s parents may be terminated upon a showing that termination is in 
  the childâ€™s best interests.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, CJ., ANDERSON, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.
