THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Irene Oakley,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Estate of Arthur Oliver Sedano and John P.
Bacot, Jr., as Personal Representative for the Estate of Arthur Oliver Sedano,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-194
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  22, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
James L. Hills, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
Ronald R. Norton, of Conway, for Respondents.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Irene Oakley filed 
  a creditorâ€™s claim against the Estate of Arthur Oliver Sedano (â€œthe Estateâ€) 
  to collect past due child support accruing during Sedanoâ€™s lifetime.Â  The Estate 
  denied Oakleyâ€™s claim.Â  Thereafter, Oakley sued the Estate to enforce the New 
  York child support order.Â  The Estate answered the complaint, asserting:Â  1) 
  Oakleyâ€™s claim was barred by the statute of limitations; and 2) Oakleyâ€™s claim 
  was barred by laches.Â  During trial, the Estate also asserted Oakley was required 
  to file her judgment pursuant to South Carolina Code Annotated section 20-7-1130, 
  et seq., (1985 & Supp. 2002), prior to enforcing the New York support 
  order in the South Carolina courts.Â  The probate court concluded none of the 
  Estateâ€™s defenses applied.Â  The court ruled in favor of Oakley, awarding her 
  the child support arrearage and interest.Â  The Estate appealed to the circuit 
  court, and the circuit court reversed, ruling Oakleyâ€™s claim was barred:Â  1) 
  by the statute of limitations; 2) by laches; and 3) because she failed to file 
  her judgment pursuant to section 20-7-1130, et seq.Â  Oakley appeals.Â  
  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Oakley and Sedano were divorced in New 
  York on June 7, 1945.Â  Pursuant to their divorce decree, Sedano was required 
  to pay fifteen dollars per week in child support.Â  Sedano never made any child 
  support payments.Â  
In 1998, Sedano died in Surfside Beach, South Carolina.Â  
  Thereafter, in 1999, Oakley filed a creditorâ€™s claim for past due child support 
  against the Estate.Â  As stated earlier, the Estate denied the claim, and Oakley 
  sued the Estate in probate court, attempting to enforce the New York child support 
  order.Â Â  The Estate answered the complaint, arguing:Â  1) Oakleyâ€™s claim was 
  barred by the statute of limitations; and 2) Oakleyâ€™s claim was barred by laches.Â  
  Additionally, during the trial, the Estate asserted Oakley was required to file 
  her judgment pursuant to section 20-7-1130, et seq., prior to enforcing 
  it in the South Carolina courts.Â  The probate court ruled none of the Estateâ€™s 
  defenses applied, found in favor of Oakley, and awarded her $73,800.85, plus 
  attorney fees and costs.Â  Subsequently, the Estate appealed to the circuit court, 
  and the circuit court reversed, ruling Oakleyâ€™s claim is barred:Â  1) by the 
  statute of limitations; 2) by laches; and 3) because she failed to file her 
  judgment pursuant to section 20-7-1130, et seq.Â  Oakley appeals to this 
  Court, arguing the circuit court erred by ruling Oakleyâ€™s claim is barred:Â  
  1) by the statute of limitations; 2) by the doctrine of laches; and 3) because 
  she failed to file her judgment pursuant to section 20-7-1130, et seq.Â  
  We conclude laches bars Oakleyâ€™s claim, and thus, we need not address her remaining 
  issues.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The standard of review applicable to cases originating 
  in the probate court is controlled by whether the underlying cause of action 
  is at law or in equity.Â  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 568, 544 S.E.2d 
  854, 856 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An action to enforce a child support decree is an 
  action in equity.Â  See Bentrim v. Bentrim, 282 S.C. 333, 335, 
  318 S.E.2d 131, 132-33 (Ct. App. 1984); see also Johnson v. Johnson, 
  194 S.C. 115, 122, 8 S.E.2d 351, 354 (1940) (holding the nature of an alimony 
  award is not altered by attempting to enforce it in a foreign jurisdiction, 
  and thus, it remains an action in equity).Â  â€œIn an appeal in equity cases . 
  . . [an appellate] [c]ourt has jurisdiction to find the facts in accord with 
  its view of the preponderance of the evidence and may reverse findings of fact 
  by the trial court when the appellant satisfies . . . [the appellate] [c]ourt 
  that such findings are without evidentiary support or are against the clear 
  preponderance of the evidence.â€ Vereen v. Bell, 256 S.C. 249, 252-53, 
  182 S.E.2d 296, 297 (1971).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Oakley argues the circuit court erred 
  by applying the doctrine of laches.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
â€œUnder the doctrine of laches, if a party, 
  knowing its rights, does not seasonably assert them, but by unreasonable delay 
  suffers its adversary to detrimentally change its position, then the courts 
  will ordinarily refuse to enforce these rights.â€Â  Provident Life & Acc. 
  Ins. Co. v. Driver, 317 S.C. 471, 478, 451 S.E.2d 924, 929 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  
  â€œDelay alone in the assertion of a right does not constitute laches.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œ[L]aches arises upon the failure to assert a known right under circumstances 
  indicating that the lached party has abandoned or surrendered the right.â€Â  Id., 
  at 479, 451 S.E.2d at 929.Â  â€œThe lached party must have had actual knowledge 
  or inquiry notice of the facts forming the basis of its claim, and its failure 
  to assert its right is irrelevant until there is a reason or situation that 
  demands assertion.â€Â  Id.Â  
The evidence in the record indicates that following 
  the divorce in 1945, Oakley was awarded fifteen dollars a month in child support.Â  
  Sedano did not pay any of the child support payments.Â  The record also indicates 
  Oakley attempted to find Sedano following the child support award.Â  However, 
  Oakleyâ€™s attempts to find Sedano were solely manifested by asking other family 
  members where he was.Â  By her own admission, she never used any other method 
  to attempt to locate Sedano.Â  Furthermore, according to Oakleyâ€™s own testimony, 
  Oakley ceased looking for Sedano in 1951 or 1952 when she remarried.Â  
Viewing this evidence, we conclude Oakleyâ€™s delay 
  in asserting her rights was unreasonable, as she did not attempt to enforce 
  the decree until fifty-five years after its issue, and, by her own admission, 
  she ceased her attempts to find Sedano after either 1951 or 1952. [1] Â  Thus, our only remaining inquiry 
  is whether the Estate has been prejudiced by Oakleyâ€™s unreasonable delay.
The child support decree required Sedano to pay 
  Oakley fifteen dollars per week.Â  Oakleyâ€™s complaint alleged Sedanoâ€™s arrearage 
  totaled $12,060.00 in principal.Â  Furthermore, with interest, Oakleyâ€™s complaint 
  alleged Sedanoâ€™s arrearage totaled $406,000.00.Â  The probate court awarded Oakley 
  $73,800.85 in arrearages against the Estate, due in a lump sum.
Based on this evidence, we conclude the Estate 
  has been prejudiced by Oakleyâ€™s delay in initiating this action, as interest 
  has been accruing on the arrearage for approximately fifty-five years.
Having concluded Oakley failed to seasonably initiate 
  this action and the Estate was prejudiced by her inaction, we hold the circuit 
  court properly applied the doctrine of laches to this case.Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the above, the decision of the 
  circuit court is 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concurring.

 
   
    [1] Oakley argues her delay was reasonable because she was a waitress 
    in New York City, lacking the ability to hire a private investigator or the 
    knowledge to find Sedano herself.Â  However, Oakley did not present any evidence 
    outside her own testimony indicating her financial position during the fifty-five 
    years prior to filing this action.Â  Furthermore, her testimony indicates her 
    financial position improved following her remarriage in 1951, the same time 
    she ceased her efforts to find Sedano.Â

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Betty L. S. Judy,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Marion S. Howell and Ronnie L. Elrod, Defendants,
Of Whom Marion S. Howell is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dorchester County
Patrick R. Watts, Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-199
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Grady Jordan, of Easley, for Appellant. 
Gene W. Dukes, of St. George, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Betty Judy sued Marion Howell 
  and Ronnie Elrod alleging a trespass on her property and seeking an injunction 
  and damages.Â  Howell appeals the trial courtâ€™s ruling in Judyâ€™s favor.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] Â  
FACTS
Howell and Judy are owners of adjoining 
  properties fronting Interstate 95 in Dorchester County.Â  In 1979, Howellâ€™s husband 
  erected and began leasing a roadside advertising sign near a disputed common 
  boundary between the two properties.Â  Following a survey of her property in 
  January 1996, Judy discovered Howellâ€™s sign was located on her property. Â Consequently, 
  she brought an action against Howell for trespass and sought an easement across 
  both Howellâ€™s and Elrodâ€™s property to reach a portion of her property landlocked 
  by I-95.Â  The trial court dismissed Judyâ€™s easement cause of action and granted 
  summary judgment in favor of Howell on the trespass claim based on res judicata, 
  citing a 1993 easement action previously brought by her late husband that was 
  dismissed. Â On appeal, this court reversed the dismissal of Judyâ€™s trespass 
  action, finding the issue did not accrue until the final resolution of the prior 
  1993 claim. [2] Â  Following a 
  trial on the merits of Judyâ€™s trespass claim, the master concluded Judy held 
  title to the plot of land where Howell erected the sign and ordered Howell to 
  pay the amount of money Howell earned from the lease since January 1, 1996.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
An action brought to determine title to a disputed 
  parcel of land is a trespass action to try title, which is an action at law.Â  
  Watson v. Suggs, 313 S.C. 291, 293, 437 S.E.2d 172, 173 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
  Accordingly, our scope of review is limited to correction of errors of law, 
  and we will not disturb the master's factual findings that have some evidentiary 
  support.Â  Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85, 
  221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  
  I.                  
  Location of Boundary Line
Howell argues the master erred by determining the advertising sign was located 
  on Judyâ€™s property without first ruling upon the exact location of the common 
  boundary line between the properties.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Neither Judy nor Howell asked the master to make a determination on the location 
  of the common boundary line between their properties.Â  As such, this issue was 
  not properly presented to the lower court and is not preserved for our review.Â  
  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 
  (2000) (holding it is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first 
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court 
  to be preserved for appellate review.).Â  
  II.               
  Title to the Plot Where the Sign is Located
Howell argues the master erred in finding that 
  Judy had title to the plot where the sign is located.Â  We disagree.
As the party bringing the trespass action, Judy 
  carried the burden of proof that she held title to the plot at the time of Howellâ€™s 
  trespass. Cummings v. Varn, 307 S.C. 37, 41, 413 S.E.2d 829, 831 (1992) 
  (holding in an action of trespass to try title, a defendant in actual possession, 
  not obtained by a tortuous eviction, is regarded as the rightful owner until 
  the plaintiff proves perfect title.).Â  
Ben Coker, Jr., Judyâ€™s surveyor, testified he relied 
  upon his own personal measurements made in the field, an old unrecorded plat, 
  and State Highway Department drawings of I-95 to prepare the 1996 plat showing 
  the location of Howellâ€™s sign on Judyâ€™s property.Â  Coker additionally testified 
  â€œthat sign, based on our calculations and measurements, is on the property owned 
  by Miss Judy.â€Â  In light of the plat description and the surveyorâ€™s testimony, 
  we find there was evidence from which the master could conclude Judy met her 
  burden of proof to assert title to the plot.Â  
Howell complains the trial court improperly 
  overruled the objections to Cokerâ€™s testimony and the admission of the 1996 
  plat because Coker was not a licensed surveyor and therefore was not qualified 
  to testify to the findings recorded on the plat.Â  While Howellâ€™s challenges 
  may raise questions about Cokerâ€™s credibility or the weight to be given Cokerâ€™s 
  findings, they do not render his testimony and plat inadmissible.Â  Accordingly, 
  we reject Howellâ€™s challenges to Coker and his testimony.Â  Bodiford v. Spanish 
  Oak Farms, 317 S.C. 539, 544-545, 455 S.E.2d 194, 197 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding 
  an appellate court cannot judge the weight or credibility of testimony on appeal 
  in a law case.).Â  
  III.           Damages
Howell contends the master erred in awarding damages 
  to Judy in an unspecified sum.Â  We disagree.Â  
The masterâ€™s order required Howell to pay Judy 
  a sum equal to all monies Howell received from her lease of the sign from January 
  1, 1996â€”the month in which Judy confirmed the trespass on her property.Â  Only 
  one party had leased the sign during that period of time.Â  Thus, the amount 
  is easily determined and is the equivalent of a sum certain as required by Rule 
  58(a)(1), SCRCP.
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  See Judy v. Howell, Op. No. 2001-UP-423 (S.C. 
    Ct. App. filed Oct. 8, 2001) (finding the record sub judice failed to 
    support a finding the trespass action was ripe in 1993).Â

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Peter R. Krenn, Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate 
        of Erik P. Krenn (deceased),        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-200
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 24, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Larry Dale Dove, of Rock Hill, for Appellant. 
Timothy A. Domin and Ronnie F. Craig, both
of Charleston, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The personal representative 
  of the Estate of Erik Krenn appeals the grant of summary judgment to State Farm 
  Mutual Automobile Insurance Company.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Sixteen-year-old Erik Krenn was driving 
  a BMW owned by his father when he pulled into a driveway to turn around.Â  Krenn 
  and his friend, Christopher Diaz, were the only occupants of the car.Â  An uninsured 
  Chevrolet with four occupants pulled up on the street behind the Krenn vehicle, 
  blocking it in the driveway.Â  At least one of the Chevroletâ€™s passengers, Antonio 
  Gordon, exited the vehicle and approached the BMW on the driverâ€™s side.Â  In 
  both his statement and affidavit, Diaz stated Gordon demanded money and asked 
  if Krenn wanted some marijuana. [1] 
  Â  After Krenn declined the offer, the Chevrolet moved slightly forward, 
  allowing the BMW to back out of the driveway. Â Krenn backed the BMW out 
  of the driveway and around the Chevrolet until the two vehicles were roughly 
  parallel in the street. Â At that point, Gordonâ€”still standing near the 
  BMWâ€”pointed a gun at Krenn and threatened to shoot him.Â  Diaz stated Gordon 
  reached into the BMW and briefly grabbed the steering wheel.Â  After Krenn put 
  the BMW into gear and started to drive away, Gordon shot him.Â  Krenn ultimately 
  died as a result of this gunshot wound.Â  
 Krennâ€™s father insured the BMW and six 
  additional vehicles with State Farm.Â  Each of the seven vehicles had liability 
  limits of $25,000, and it was agreed that if coverage existed, the policies 
  would be stackable and the estate would be able to collect $175,000. Â State 
  Farm moved for summary judgment, arguing there was no genuine issue of material 
  fact and it was entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  The trial court granted 
  the motion, finding the estate â€œfailed to establish that the facts in this case 
  meet the requirements under South Carolina law to establish coverage.â€Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is proper when it is 
  clear there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party 
  is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  West v. Gladney, 341 S.C. 
  127, 132, 533 S.E.2d 334, 336 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œSummary judgment can be granted 
  when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds 
  cannot differ.â€Â  Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 445, 415 S.E.2d 796, 
  799 (1992).
â€œIn reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, 
  this Court applies the same standard which governs the trial court . . . .â€Â  
  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  â€œIn determining 
  whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  
  Id.Â  â€œOn appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate 
  court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and 
  from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.â€Â  
  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
 The estate argues the master erred in granting State 
  Farmâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Specifically, the estate argues the Chevrolet 
  was used as an active accessory to the attempted carjacking and Krennâ€™s subsequent 
  death.Â  We do not agree.
An insured is legally entitled to recover 
  damages arising out of the â€œownership, maintenance, or useâ€ of an uninsured 
  vehicle.Â  State Farm Fire & Cas. Co. v. Aytes, 332 S.C. 30, 33, 503 
  S.E.2d 744, 745 (1998) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-140 (1989)).Â  In order 
  to determine if an individualâ€™s injuries are covered by an automobile insurance 
  policy, the insured must prove the following:Â  (1) there exists a causal connection 
  between the vehicle and the injury; (2) no act of independent significance breaks 
  the causal link; and (3) the vehicle was being used for transportation at the 
  time of the assault.Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Bookert, 337 
  S.C. 291, 293, 523 S.E.2d 181, 182 (1999) (citation omitted).Â  
Furthermore, the â€œcausal connectionâ€ aspect of 
  this three-part test means (1) the vehicle was an â€œactive accessoryâ€ to the 
  assault; (2) something less than proximate cause but more than mere site of 
  the injury; and (3) that the â€œinjury must be foreseeably identifiable with the 
  normal use of the automobile.â€Â  Id.  
The first prong of the Bookert 
  test mandates that, in order to recover damages, the estate must prove there 
  was a causal connection between the Chevrolet and Krennâ€™s death.Â  The trial 
  court held there was no causal connection in this case, and we agree.Â  The Chevrolet 
  was not an active accessory to Krennâ€™s assault because Gordon had exited the 
  Chevrolet and was standing beside the BMW when he shot Krenn.Â  Further, while 
  the Chevrolet had originally blocked the BMW in the driveway, at the time of 
  the shooting the Chevrolet had moved in order to allow the BMW to proceed.Â  
  Assessing these facts, it is apparent that not only was the uninsured vehicle 
  not an active accessory to the assault, it was not even the actual site of the 
  injury, as the vehicle itself was neither part of the assault nor was the assailant 
  inside the vehicle at the time Krenn was shot.Â  Additionally, Krennâ€™s shooting 
  was not â€œforeseeably identifiableâ€ with the normal use of the uninsured vehicle.Â  
  Accordingly, we find the causal connection prong of the Bookert test 
  is not satisfied in this case.Â  
Assuming the facts before us support the causal 
  connection element, the second element of the Bookert test is not met 
  in this case.Â  When Gordon exited the Chevrolet before shooting Krenn, this 
  was an â€œact of independent significanceâ€ that served to break the causal link 
  of the Chevroletâ€™s involvement in Krennâ€™s assault.Â  In a similar situation, 
  the supreme court has held that any causal connection is broken when the assailant 
  exits the vehicle.Â  Aytes, 332 S.C. at 35, 503 S.E.2d at 746.Â  
Notwithstanding the outcome of the Bookert 
  test, the estate argues that in Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C. 
  362, 529 S.E.2d 280 (2000), the supreme court held injuries resulting from a 
  carjacking were covered by the uninsured motorist statute.Â  However, in Schmidt, 
  the court considered whether coverage was allowed when the vehicle considered 
  uninsured is the carjacked vehicle.Â  This scenario does not apply in the instant 
  case, as Krennâ€™s BMW was an insured vehicle and the assailantâ€™s Chevrolet was 
  uninsured.Â  Even though the evidence indicates that Gordon briefly grabbed the 
  steering wheel of the Krenn vehicle, there is no evidence that he exercised 
  any control over it to such an extent that it would rise to the level of a non-permissive 
  use of the vehicle as was the situation in Schmidt.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We note the statements of the four individuals in the Chevrolet, 
    including Antonio Gordonâ€™s statement, are substantially the same as Diazâ€™s 
    statement and affidavit.Â

  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Theodore L. Brown, III,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-201
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed March 24, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Steven Smith McKenzie, of Manning, for Appellant. 
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Cecil Kelley Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Theodore L. Brown, III was 
  convicted of possession of marijuana with intent to distribute after police 
  discovered the drugs during a traffic stop.Â  Brown appeals, contending the drugs 
  were found after the completion of the original stop and thus pursuant to an 
  illegal detention under State v. Williams, 351 S.C. 591, 571 S.E.2d 703 
  (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied (June 27, 2003).Â  We affirm.Â  
BACKGROUND
Lance Corporal Richard Ray of the South Carolina 
  Highway Patrol stopped a van traveling south on Interstate 95 for weaving.Â  
  As Officer Ray approached the van, he noticed Brown asleep or reclining in the 
  rear of the vehicle.Â  After exiting the van at Rayâ€™s request, the vanâ€™s driver, 
  Milton Butler, explained he had been driving for twenty hours and was tired.Â  
  The officer issued the driver a warning citation for weaving.Â  
As Butler turned to leave, the officer asked if 
  he could ask a few more questions.Â  He asked if there was anything illegal in 
  the vehicle, and Brown said no.Â  Ray continued to ask the driver questions, 
  telling him that â€œhe was not being accused of having any illegal items, but 
  if he did have anything illegal, such as alcohol or any marijuana, less than 
  an ounce, he could be given a ticket and released if he was honest.â€Â  
After some discussion, Butler admitted there were 
  drugs in the van.Â  Ray then read Butler his Miranda 
  [1]  rights and Butler stated there was maybe a quarter of an ounce of marijuana 
  in the van.Â  Ray then called Lance Corporal King to the scene.Â  Butler again 
  admitted there was marijuana in the van.Â  Another officer arrived and Brown 
  was asked to exit the vehicle.Â  
When King arrived, he circled the vehicle with 
  a drug dog several times.Â  He then entered the van with the dog and discovered 
  1.57 pounds of marijuana under bedding in the rear of the van.Â  
Brown was found guilty of possession of marijuana 
  with intent to distribute following a jury trial.Â  
DISCUSSION
Brown argues he and the driver 
  were unlawfully detained when the officer continued to ask questions after issuing 
  the warning citation.Â  Thus he argues the marijuana was discovered during an 
  unlawful seizure of his person and the court should have suppressed it.Â  This 
  issue is not preserved.
Although Brown moved to suppress the drugs 
  prior to the swearing of the jury, a motion the court denied after a hearing, 
  he failed to contemporaneously object when the marijuana or drug analysis were 
  admitted into evidence.Â  Because this evidence was admitted during the testimony 
  of the Stateâ€™s second and third witnesses, his failure to renew his motion precludes 
  appellate review of the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 
  149-50, 561 S.E.2d 640, 643-44 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding an in limine motion 
  to suppress drugs must be renewed at the time the drugs are admitted into evidence 
  where the courtâ€™s ruling was not obtained immediately prior to the admission); 
  see also State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642, 541 S.E.2d 837, 
  840 (2001) (holding ordinarily an evidentiary ruling in limine is not final 
  and an objection contemporaneous with the evidenceâ€™s admission is required to 
  preserve the issue for appeal).
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and
CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).

THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Stanford Kosover,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Audrey H. Stenger and The Metro Wine Room, Inc.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-202
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
O. W. Bannister, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
Randall Scott Hiller, of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Stanford Kosover appeals from 
  the dismissal of his complaint for an accounting and in quantum meruit.Â  
  We affirm.
    FACTS
Soon after Kosover was released from prison
for a breach of trust charge, he decided to open a business for the purpose of
buying, roasting, and selling coffee to local businesses. 
He contacted attorney Bobby Mann, a personal friend, who assisted Kosover
in incorporating the business as Metro Coffee House, Inc. 
The business was organized with Mann as the sole stockholder, and he
owned the building in which it was located. 
Kosover paid rent to Mann and handled all the operations and finances of
the business. 
Several
years after opening the Metro Coffee House, Kosover decided to slowly expand the
premises to include retail sales and a wine bar. 
Approximately one to two years later, Kosover became romantically
involved with Stenger, who assisted in expanding the shop. 
In order to finance the expansion, Kosover borrowed money from several
individuals, and Stenger supplied personal funds and took out a bank loan.  Stenger then entered into a lease with Mann for the building
space and incorporated the new business as the Metro Wine Room, Inc. Stenger was
the sole stockholder of the Metro Wine Room.  A little over two years later, Kosover and Stenger ended
their personal relationship, and Kosover sent Stenger a letter outlining their
options with respect to dividing Metro Wine Roomâ€™s assets. 
Stenger replied that Kosover could acquire the property from her, if he
desired.  Stenger then changed the
locks on the property, acquired new business partners, changed the name of the
wine bar, and continued business in the location.  
    Kosover filed a complaint against 
      Stenger and Metro Wine Room seeking damages based on quantum meruit 
      and alleging he was entitled to an accounting of the partiesâ€™ joint venture.Â  
      Stenger and the Metro Wine Room filed an answer denying Kosoverâ€™s allegations.Â  
      In addition, Stenger counterclaimed that she was entitled to reimbursement 
      for certain rents and labors she performed.Â  At trial, Kosover admitted 
      on cross-examination that the lease had to be in Stengerâ€™s name because 
      a beer and wine permit eventually would be required.Â  Kosover explained 
      that his â€œprior criminal historyâ€ meant that he would be unable to apply 
      for such a permit.Â  After a bench trial, the trial court issued an order 
      dismissing both Kosoverâ€™s complaint and Stengerâ€™s counterclaim.Â  The court 
      found that Kosover was barred as a matter of law from obtaining a beer and 
      wine permit due to his prior incarceration. The judge further found that, 
      even if the enterprise were legal, Kosoverâ€™s testimony was not credible 
      and there was a â€œcomplete lack of credible evidence as to any damages.â€Â  
      Kosover appeals.
    STANDARD
    OF REVIEW
    In equity actions tried by a trial judge alone, 
      this courtâ€™s scope of review extends to the findings of fact which may be 
      recast in this courtâ€™s own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes 
      Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 
      775 (1976).Â  â€œHowever, this broad scope of review does not require an appellate 
      court to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial 
      judge is in the better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  
      Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).
    ISSUES

    I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding Kosover was barred as a matter of 
      law from obtaining a beer and wine permit?
    II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding Kosover was engaged in an illegal 
      enterprise?
    III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding there was no evidence of damages?


  LAW/ANALYSIS

I. 
Beer and Wine Permit
        Kosover argues the trial court erred 
          in finding he was barred as a matter of law from obtaining a beer and 
          wine permit or from having an interest in a business that required such 
          a permit.Â  We do not agree.
        Kosover admitted on cross-examination 
          that he was barred from receiving a beer and wine permit.Â  Kosover also 
          testified he personally completed the application for the beer and wine 
          permit on Stengerâ€™s behalf and neglected to provide any information 
          about his status as a partner in Metro Wine Room.Â  In so doing, Kosover 
          knowingly violated at least three statutory sections. 
        Section 61-4-520 states a beer and wine 
          permit may not be issued unless â€œ[t]he applicant, any partner or co-shareholder 
          of the applicant . . . to be employed on the licensed premises are of 
          good moral character.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-520(1) (Supp. 2003) 
          (emphasis added).Â  It is clear Kosover and Stenger planned to operate 
          Metro Wine Room as a joint venture.Â  It is also clear that because Kosover 
          had a recent conviction for breach of trust he could not be considered 
          â€œof good moral characterâ€ for purposes of obtaining the permit. [1] Â  
        Section 61-2-90 of the South Carolina Code 
          (Supp. 2003) states each person seeking a beer and wine permit must 
          file an application containing a sworn statement with the South Carolina 
          Department of Revenue.Â  Among other things, this section requires the 
          applicant to include in this statement â€œinformation required by the 
          department to determine if the application meets all statutory requirements 
          for the license or permit and to determine the true owners of the business 
          seeking the license or permit.â€Â  Id. Kosover admitted on cross-examination 
          that he prepared the application for the beer and wine permit.Â  As such, 
          Kosover knew, as a partner in Metro Wine Room, that he must disclose 
          both his interest in the business and his prior criminal history, pursuant 
          to section 61-4-520(1).Â Â Â  
        Section 61-2-100 states that beer and wine 
          permits may only be issued to persons who own the qualifying business.Â  
          S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-2-100(A) (Supp. 2003).Â  This section further states 
          that a permit may not be issued to any applying person â€œunless the person 
          and all principals are of good moral character.â€Â  Id. at Â§ 61-2-100(D).Â  
          Principals are defined to include all persons who own at least twenty-five 
          percent of the value of the business, which would, by his own testimony, 
          include Kosover.Â  Id. at Â§ 61-2-100(H)(2)(g).Â  Similar to sections 
          61-4-520(1) and 61-2-90(6), Kosover would thus be excluded under section 
          61-2-100 from obtaining a beer and wine permit because his conviction 
          for breach of trust prevents him from being of good moral character.
        The cumulative application of these three 
          statutory sections supports the conclusion that Kosover was prohibited 
          from obtaining a beer and wine permit.Â  Further, Kosover was aware that 
          his participation in the Metro Wine Room venture was unlawful.Â  Accordingly, 
          the trial court did not err in finding Kosover was barred as a matter 
          of law from obtaining a beer and wine permit.
        II.     
        Illegal Enterprise
        Kosover argues the trial court erred 
          in finding he was engaged in an illegal enterprise.Â  We disagree.
        The trial court found â€œthe contract 
          to enter into a partnership or joint venture was for an illegal purpose 
          and as such may not and will not be enforced by this Court.â€Â  When Kosover 
          and Stenger entered into their joint venture to form and operate Metro 
          Wine Room, the ultimate goal was to receive a beer and wine permit in 
          order to open a wine bar.Â  To that end, Kosover persuaded Stenger to 
          put all leases, documents, and filings in her name only, though he was 
          an equal partner in the Metro Wine Room enterprise.Â  As discussed above, 
          Kosover was barred from obtaining a beer or wine permit because he had 
          been imprisoned for breach of trust.Â  Because Kosover was prohibited 
          by law from obtaining this permit, which was integral to the ultimate 
          purpose of the venture, the eventual acquisition of this permit and 
          operation of the Metro Wine Room venture was an illegal enterprise.Â  
          See W & N Constr. Co. v. Williams, 322 S.C. 448, 450, 
          472 S.E.2d 622, 623 (1996) (â€œIt is a well-founded policy of law that 
          no person be permitted to acquire a right of action from their own unlawful 
          act and one who participates in an unlawful act cannot recover damages 
          for the consequence of that act.â€) (quoting Jackson v. Bi-Lo Stores, 
          Inc., 313 S.C. 272, 276, 437 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1993)).
        Accordingly, the trial court did not err in 
          finding Kosover was engaged in an illegal enterprise.
        III.Â Â Â  Evidence of Damages
        Kosover argues the trial court erred 
          in finding there was no evidence of damages.Â  We do not agree.
        Kosover had neither a leasehold 
          interest in the business space nor any ownership interest in Metro Wine 
          Room.Â  Both interests were solely in Stengerâ€™s name because Kosover 
          testified that his criminal record would have prevented his association 
          with any business applying for a beer and wine permit.Â  Kosover did 
          not present any evidence at trial that the loan money he was seeking 
          to recoup was actually invested in Metro Wine Room.Â  Although the record 
          contains notes executed between various individuals and Kosover, none 
          of these notes either mentioned Metro Wine Room or listed the business 
          as a party to the notes.Â  Further, Stenger testified she was not aware 
          of certain loans Kosover claimed were to be used for the business and, 
          with respect to the loans she was aware of, she did not know if they 
          were actually used in furtherance of the business.Â  The trial court 
          found Kosoverâ€™s testimony was not credible and that there was â€œno credible 
          evidence (beyond speculation) to establish [Kosover]â€™s alleged loss.â€Â  
          As the trial court was in a better position to determine Kosoverâ€™s credibility, 
          we accept his assessment of Kosoverâ€™s testimony.Â  See Pinckney 
          v. Warren, 344 S.C. at 387, 544 S.E.2d at 623.Â  
        Accordingly, the trial court did not err 
          in finding Kosover failed to provide any evidence of damages.
        CONCLUSION
        Based upon the foregoing, the trial 
          courtâ€™s order dismissing Kosoverâ€™s complaint is
         AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and 
          BEATTY, JJ., concur.

       
         
          [1]  Criminal breach of trust requires a fraudulent act.Â  S.C. Code 
          Ann. Â§ 16-13-230 (2003).Â  Our supreme court has further held that â€œ[a]n 
          act in which fraud is an ingredient involves moral turpitude.â€Â  See 
          State v. Horton, 271 S.C. 413, 414, 248 S.E.2d 263, 263 (1978).Â Â Â Â Â

Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary,Â  S.C. Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Sean Maddox (Appellant) pled 
  guilty to second-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor and pointing 
  and presenting a firearm.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent prison terms of ten 
  years for the CSC offense and three years for the firearm offense.
On appeal, counsel for Appellant has filed a final 
  brief along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Appellant has not filed 
  a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant 
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we found the transcript of the plea proceedings 
  indicated Appellant had orally waived presentment of the indictments to a grand 
  jury, but the indictments in the record were left blank in the section for waiving 
  presentment.Â  There were no written waivers of presentment elsewhere in the 
  record.Â  See State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 639, 545 S.E.2d 511, 
  513 (2001) (â€œA circuit court has subject matter jurisdiction if:Â  (1) there 
  has been an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; (2) there has 
  been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is a lesser included charge of 
  the crime charged in the indictment.â€); In re Matthews, 345 S.C. 638, 
  643 n.4, 550 S.E.2d 311, 313 n.4 (2001) (â€œLack of subject matter jurisdiction 
  can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can 
  be raised sua sponte by the court.â€ (citation omitted)), cert. 
  denied, 535 U.S. 1062 (2002).
As part of its Anders review, the Court 
  obtained the sentencing sheets on the two charges.Â  There is a written waiver 
  of presentment on the sentencing sheet for the charge of pointing and presenting 
  a firearm.Â Â  Accordingly, the appeal as to this charge is dismissed.Â  As to 
  the charge of second-degree CSC with a minor, the sentencing sheet does not 
  contain a written waiver of presentment.Â  Consequently, we vacate the conviction 
  on the CSC charge as the circuit court did not have subject matter jurisdiction 
  to accept Appellantâ€™s plea.Â  See Odom v. State, 350 S.C. 300, 
  566 S.E.2d 528 (2002) (holding section 17-23-140 of the South Carolina Code 
  requires a waiver of presentment to be in writing and a defendantâ€™s oral waiver 
  is insufficient to bestow subject matter jurisdiction). 
Counselâ€™s petition to be relieved from further 
  representation is denied.
DISMISSED IN PART, VACATED IN PART. [1] 
GOOSLBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  This case is decided without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Worley Lee Brown,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-197
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  25, 2004.

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H.W. Pat Paschal, Jr., of Greenville and L. Patrick Mulligan, 
  of Dayton, Ohio, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Druanne Dykes White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Worley Lee Brown was indicted 
  on one count of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and one count 
  of committing or attempting a lewd act upon a child under the age of sixteen.Â  
  He was convicted on the second charge and sentenced to fifteen years incarceration, 
  suspended upon service of ten years and five years probation.Â  He raises several 
  issues on appeal.Â  We affirm. [1] 
  Â  
FACTS
Victim, a ten-year-old female, was spending the 
  night at the home of Worley Lee Brown and his wife, Annie Brown. Â Victim 
  wanted to play a computer game, and Brown agreed to help her.Â  Annie walked 
  up to them while they were playing the game and saw Brownâ€™s hand on Victimâ€™s 
  genital area.Â  Upon seeing this, Annie became upset and told Brown to leave 
  the house. Â 
The incident was reported to Rusty Garrett, 
  an investigator with the Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  With Investigator 
  Jami Brothers, Garrett interviewed Victim at her school.Â  Brown was indicted 
  following the investigation.Â  
Brown voluntarily submitted to a polygraph examination.Â  
  During an interview before the examination, Brown stated Victim had put his 
  hand down her panties immediately before Annie walked up, and admitted there 
  was a possibility that his finger penetrated Victimâ€™s vagina.Â  
At trial, Victim testified Brown had touched 
  her breasts and her vagina.Â  
The State then called Dr. Horace Smith, a pediatrician 
  and expert in child sexual assault who had examined Victim.Â  When the State 
  asked Dr. Smith what Victim had given him as far as background or history, Brown 
  objected.Â  Outside the juryâ€™s presence, Brownâ€™s attorney argued:Â  

Your Honor, according to the State v. Dawkins and 
  Jolly v. State, my objection is, number one, itâ€™s hearsay; and, number 
  two, itâ€™s corroboration or bolstering of her witness.Â  And they â€“ she can introduce 
  evidence that this person indicated there was an assault, but itâ€™s limited.Â  
  The details and the particulars are not admissible, but so much of the complaint 
  as identifies a time and a place may be shown.

The court overruled Brownâ€™s objection, and Dr. Smith 
  testified Victim told him someone had touched her on her genital area on more 
  than one occasion, and that it sometimes hurt.Â  He also testified Victim told 
  him she was touched repeatedly on the breasts. Â 
During the Stateâ€™s direct examination 
  of Annie, Brown objected to a leading question and was overruled.Â  After Brown 
  cross-examined Annie, the court indicated that Brownâ€™s objection was overruled 
  pursuant to Rule 611(c), SCRE, because Annie was â€œvery well identifiedâ€ with 
  Brown because she had been married to him for twenty years.Â  Accordingly, the 
  trial court allowed the State to ask Annie leading questions on re-direct examination.Â  

During the cross-examination of Mary 
  Lesley, one of Brownâ€™s neighbors, Brown asked if Annie had ever told her that 
  Victim had accused her grandfather of molesting her.Â  The court sustained the 
  Stateâ€™s objection to the question.Â  At the conclusion of her testimony, and 
  outside the juryâ€™s presence, Lesley stated that she was unaware of any allegations 
  about Victimâ€™s grandfather. Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Other Bad Acts
Brown contends the trial court erred in permitting 
  evidence that Brown had touched Victimâ€™s breasts at least ten times.Â  He argues 
  this evidence, provided through Victimâ€™s testimony and Dr. Smithâ€™s testimony, 
  constituted impermissible bad acts evidence.Â  This issue is not preserved.
To be preserved for appellate review, an issue 
  must have been raised to and ruled on by the trial judge.Â  Brown did not object 
  to Victimâ€™s testimony regarding these acts.Â  Thus this issue is not preserved 
  as to her testimony.Â  See State v. Perez, 334 S.C. 563, 565-66, 
  514 S.E.2d 754, 755 (1999) (issues not raised to and ruled upon by the trial 
  court will not be considered on appeal).Â  Further, although Brown did object 
  to Dr. Smithâ€™s testimony regarding these acts, his only objection to this testimony 
  was that it constituted hearsay and improper corroboration.Â  Because his argument 
  on appeal differs from the one asserted at trial, it is also not preserved for 
  our review.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) 
  (holding a party cannot argue grounds on appeal different than those argued 
  to the trial judge).
II.Â  Rape Shield Law
Brown argues the trial court improperly 
  excluded under the rape shield statute evidence of unpursued sexual abuse accusations 
  Victim made against her grandfather.Â  We find no error.
During cross-examination of Brownâ€™s neighbor 
  Mary Lesley, Brown asked if Annie told her Victim had initially accused her 
  grandfather of the sexual abuse in question. Â When the State objected, 
  the trial court held a bench conference and sustained the objection.Â  Neither 
  the grounds for the objection nor the courtâ€™s rationale in sustaining it appear 
  in the record.
Although the record does not reflect 
  the courtâ€™s reasoning, we find the objection was properly sustained because 
  the testimony would have been impermissible hearsay.Â  Repeating whether Annie 
  had told her about an accusation made by Victim would have been offered for 
  the truth of the matter assertedâ€”that Victim accused her grandfather of sexual 
  abuseâ€”and does not fall within any of the exceptions to the rule against hearsay.Â  
  Rule 801, SCRE (hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered in court to prove 
  the truth of the matter asserted); 802, SCRE (hearsay is inadmissible except 
  as provided in statute or court rule); 803, SCRE (hearsay exceptions â€“ availability 
  of declarant immaterial).Â  Thus the trial court properly excluded the testimony.Â  
  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418-21, 
  526 S.E.2d 716, 721-25 (2000) (holding an appellate court can affirm for any 
  reason appearing in the record).Â  Additionally, at the conclusion of Lesleyâ€™s 
  testimony, she testified outside the juryâ€™s presence she was not aware of any 
  allegations against Victimâ€™s grandfather. Â Thus, Brown could not have 
  been prejudiced by the exclusion of Lesleyâ€™s testimony on the matter.Â  
III.Â  Bolstering Hearsay
Brown asserts the trial court erred in 
  allowing corroborative testimony from Dr. Smith, Inspector Garrett, and Inspector 
  Brothers.Â  He contends their testimony improperly bolstered Victimâ€™s testimony.Â  
  Additionally, he argues the prosecutor personally bolstered Victimâ€™s testimony 
  by asking her about prior conversations she had with the prosecutor and Dr. 
  Smith.Â  We find no error.
Initially we note Brown did not object 
  to any corroborative testimony offered by Inspectors Garrett and Brothers.Â  
  Thus this issue is not preserved as to these grounds.Â  
Brown did object to Dr. Smithâ€™s testimony, but 
  the same was permitted under the well-recognized medical diagnosis and treatment 
  exception to the hearsay rule.Â  Dr. Smith testified the child reported she was 
  repeatedly touched on the breasts, touched on her vagina, and that sometimes 
  the vaginal contact hurt.Â  Because this information was necessary for Dr. Smith 
  to better assess any mental and physical injury, the testimony was admissible 
  under the hearsay exception for statements made for purposes of medical diagnosis 
  or treatment.Â  Rule 803(4), SCRE.
IV.Â  Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
Brown contends his conviction should be 
  reversed because his trial counsel was ineffective for allowing him to submit 
  to a polygraph examination and for failing to accompany him during the examination.
This court is an appellate court for the correction 
  of errors of law committed at the trial level.Â  We do not consider claims of 
  ineffective assistance of counsel on direct appeal from convictions.Â  Instead, 
  such claims should be brought in a proceeding for post-conviction relief.Â  State 
  v. Felder, 290 S.C. 521, 522, 351 S.E.2d 852, 852 (1986) (â€œWithout addressing 
  the merits of appellantâ€™s claim, we hold that post-conviction relief rather 
  than a direct appeal is the proper avenue of relief in this case.â€).Â  
V.Â  Redirect Examination of Annie Brown
Brown asserts the trial court erred in 
  allowing the State to ask Annie leading questions on redirect.Â  We disagree.
Ordinarily, leading questions should not 
  be used on direct examination except as necessary to develop the witnessâ€™ testimony.Â  
  Rule 611(c), SCRE.Â  However, â€œ[w]hen a party calls a hostile witness, an adverse 
  party, or a witness identified with an adverse party, interrogation may be by 
  leading questions.â€Â  Id.Â  Contrary to Brownâ€™s contention that the trial 
  court declared Annie a hostile witness, the court clearly indicated it was allowing 
  leading questions under Rule 611(c), SCRE because Annie was identified with 
  Brown.Â  At the time she testified at trial, Annie had been married to Brown 
  for almost twenty years.Â  Given that she was testifying for the State while 
  married to the defendant, we find no error in the courtâ€™s conclusion that she 
  â€œidentified with an adverse party.â€Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, the trial court 
  acted well within its discretion under Rule 611 in allowing the State to elicit 
  Annieâ€™s testimony through leading questions.
VI.Â  Cumulative Errors
Having concluded each of Brownâ€™s issues lack merit, 
  we find application of the cumulative error doctrine inappropriate in this case.
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

  Judge

Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  25, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all 
  of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant was convicted of 
  trafficking in methamphetamine and unlawful carrying of a pistol, and he was 
  sentenced.Â  On appeal, Appellant argues that the trial court erred in sentencing 
  him for second offense trafficking under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1) when 
  his prior drug conviction was for possession of a controlled substance.Â  We 
  affirm.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  I.                 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY 
   
On December 28, 2001, Appellant, a commercial truck 
  driver, was stopped at a weigh station on Interstate 20 in Aiken County, South 
  Carolina.Â  Appellant told one of the officers that there was a gun in the cab 
  of his truck.Â Â  In addition to a 9 millimeter pistol, the officer discovered 
  .11 grams of cocaine and 21.99 grams of methamphetamine in the truck.Â Â  
Appellant was indicted for trafficking in methamphetamine, 
  possession of cocaine, and unlawful carrying of a pistol.Â  He was tried on April 
  29, 2003 before the Honorable James C. Williams and a jury.Â  
Appellant was convicted of trafficking in methamphetamine 
  and unlawful carrying of a pistol and was sentenced.Â  His drug related conviction 
  was treated as a â€œsecond offenseâ€ for sentencing purposes, since Appellant had 
  a prior conviction from Nevada for possession of a controlled substance.Â  The 
  circuit court determined that the conviction would constitute a â€œsecond offenseâ€ 
  as defined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-470, thus rejecting Appellantâ€™s argument 
  that the prior conviction had to be a trafficking offense in order to trigger 
  the â€œsecond offenseâ€ sentence pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1)(b).Â  
  This appeal follows.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  II.              
LAW/ANALYSIS 
   
On appeal, Appellant argues the circuit court erred 
  in sentencing him for second offense trafficking under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1) 
  when his prior drug offense was for possession of a controlled substance.Â  Thus, 
  the issue raised on appeal is the characterization of the trafficking conviction 
  as a â€œsecond offense.â€Â Â Â  
Â South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(C) (2003) provides 
  that any â€œperson who knowingly sells, manufactures, delivers, purchases, or 
  brings into this StateÂ  . . . ten grams or more of ice, crank, or crack cocaine 
  . . . is guilty of a felony.â€Â  If the amount is ten grams or more, but less 
  than twenty-eight grams, and the conviction is a â€œsecond offenseâ€ as defined 
  by statute, the defendant must be sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 
  five years nor more than thirty years, and a $50,000 fine.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  44-53-375(C)(1)(b).Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-470, an offense is considered 
  a second offense if the defendant has a prior conviction under Title 44, Article 
  53 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, or under â€œany State or Federal statute 
  relating to narcotic drugs, marihuana, depressant, stimulant, or hallucinogenic 
  drugs.â€Â  
Appellant argues that S.C. Code Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1)(b) 
  only applies when the defendantâ€™s prior conviction is a â€œtrafficking offense.â€Â  
  Our court recently rejected this exact argument in State v. Dupree, 354 
  S.C. 676, 583 S.E.2d 437 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In Dupree, the court noted 
  that the language in Â§ 44-53-375(C) â€œmerely delineates offensesâ€ and that there 
  is no conflict between Sections 44-53-375(C)(1)(b) and 44-53-470.Â  Id.Â  
  The court concluded by holding that Â§ 44-53-470 applies to Â§ 44-53-375(C).Â  
  Id.Â  
Likewise, inÂ  Thomas v. State, 319 S.C. 
  471, 465 S.E.2d 350 (1995), the court held that the marijuana trafficking statute 
  and the statute defining â€œsecond or subsequent offenseâ€ as any drug offense 
  were part of the same general law and could be read together without conflict.Â  
  The court further noted that â€œ[t]he legislature could not have intended second 
  or subsequent offenses under [Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1)] to include only . . . trafficking 
  when there is a specific statute which defines second or subsequent offenses 
  as any drug offense.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â Â Â  
Thus, pursuant to the holdings in Dupree 
  and Thomas, and based on Appellantâ€™s prior conviction for possession 
  of a controlled substance, the circuit court properly sentenced him as a second 
  time offender under Â§ 44-53-375(C)(1)(b).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â

PER CURIAM:Â  John M. Anderson was convicted 
  in his absence in magistrateâ€™s court for a traffic violation.Â  The circuit court 
  affirmed the conviction.Â  We affirm.Â  
Appellant received a traffic ticket on June 14, 2001 
  for speeding.Â  He failed to appear at his scheduled hearing, and was tried in 
  his absence and found guilty.Â  He received notice of the conviction by mail 
  on April 15, 2002.Â Â Â On April 24, 2002, Appellant wrote a letter to the 
  traffic court requesting to reopen the case.Â  Although the motion for a new 
  trial was untimely, the magistrate scheduled a hearing on Appellantâ€™s motion 
  for May 30, 2002.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-1000 (Supp. 2003) (â€œNo motion for a 
  new trial may be heard unless made within five days from the rendering of the 
  judgmentâ€).Â  Appellant failed to appear for the May 30 hearing, and the motion 
  was denied. 
The essence of the appeal to the circuit 
  court and this court is Appellantâ€™s desire for â€œan opportunity to stand in front 
  of a judge based on the charges brought against [him].â€Â  While we appreciate 
  Appellantâ€™s desire, there is simply no legal basis to afford him relief.Â  The 
  record establishes that the magistrateâ€™s office provided proper notice of the 
  motion for new trial to Appellant at his correct address. 
  [1] Â  Assuming Appellantâ€™s receipt of notice of his conviction on April 
  15, 2002 may be liberally construed as the date of â€œrendering of the judgment,â€ 
  his new trial motion would nevertheless be untimely pursuant to Section 22-3-1000.Â  
  We additionally note that Appellantâ€™s conclusory brief falls short of the appellate 
  court rules.Â  Rule 208 (b)(1)(D), SCACR; see also Fields v. 
  Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106, 439 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1993) 
  (stating that an issue is deemed abandoned on appeal and, therefore, not presented

  authority).Â Â

GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN 
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Janet Elgin Arthurs, Personal Representative of the Estate of Betty B. 
        Stephens, Deceased,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sue H. Brown,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-216
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 3004

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
James Daniel Bailey, of Aiken and Richard Edwin Miley, of 
  N. Augusta, for Appellant.
Phillip E. Reeves and Jennifer D. Eubanks, both of Greenville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Janet Elgin Arthurs, as the 
  personal representative of the estate of her deceased mother, Betty B. Stephens, 
  appeals from the denial of her post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict (JNOV), new trial, and to alter or amend the judgment in these actions 
  for wrongful death and survival against Sue. H. Brown.Â  We find this court lacks 
  subject matter jurisdiction to review the case because the notice of appeal 
  was untimely.
FACTS
At the center of this case is 
  a fatal car accident that occurred on Thanksgiving Day in 1998.Â  Stephens was 
  traveling in the northbound lane of Highway 19 in Aiken County.Â  Brown was traveling 
  on the same road in the southbound lane.Â  As the two vehicles approached each 
  other, the car driven by Brown crossed the centerline of the two-lane road and 
  collided with Stephensâ€™s car.Â  Stephens died at the scene of the accident.Â  
  Brown survived. 
Stephensâ€™s daughter brought this 
  action against Brown, claiming Brownâ€™s negligence in the operation of her vehicle 
  was the proximate cause of her motherâ€™s death.Â  At the conclusion of the trial 
  on August 7, 2001, the jury rendered verdicts in favor of Brown.Â  Arthurs then 
  made oral motions for JNOV and a new trial.Â  Specifically, she argued there 
  was no evidence to support the juryâ€™s conclusions on the issue of negligence 
  and that the trial judge erred in instructing the jury on the law of â€œunavoidable 
  accidentâ€ as a defense to negligence charges.Â  The circuit court entered an 
  order denying these motions on November 19, 2001, which was subsequently received 
  by Arthurs on November 27, 2001.Â  Arthurs then filed a motion, dated November 
  30, 2001, to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  In 
  the motion, Arthurs merely restated the arguments she made orally and in memoranda 
  filed with her first post-trial motions and requested the trial court provide 
  a â€œfactual or legal basis for denying the Plaintiffâ€™s Motion for Judgment Notwithstanding 
  the Verdict and New Trial.â€Â  This motion was denied by the trial court on February 
  7, 2002. Â Arthurs served her notice of appeal on March 11, 2002.
LAW/ANALYSIS
As an initial consideration, 
  this court is obligated to evaluate our jurisdiction to hear this matter even 
  though neither party raised it as an issue on appeal.Â  See Ness v. 
  Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 402, 566 S.E.2d 193, 195 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We 
  conclude that the appeal to this court is untimely and, as a result, we lack 
  jurisdiction to consider the merits of the case.
According to Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR, the notice of appeal 
  from a civil action â€œshall be served on all respondents within thirty days (30) 
  after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.â€Â  Timely 
  motions for JNOV, to alter or amend the judgment, or for a new trial stay the 
  time for appeal until receipt of written notice of entry of the order granting 
  or denying the motions.Â  Id.Â  However, a subsequent motion for JNOV, 
  to alter or amend, or new trial does not expand the time for appeal when, as 
  in the present case, it merely restates the arguments made in previous motions.
This court recently considered successive 
  post-trial motions in Collins Music Co. v. IGT, 353 S.C. 559, 579 S.E.2d 
  524 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied, 124 S. Ct. 303 (2003).Â  In Collins, 
  the jury returned a verdict for Collins, and IGT made timely motions for JNOV, 
  new trial, and new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Id. at 560, 579 S.E.2d 
  at 524.Â  The court denied all of IGTâ€™s motions and IGT received a copy of the 
  order on September 5, 2001.Â  Id.  
On September 12, 2001, IGT served a motion 
  to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, and the motion merely restated 
  the arguments made in the post-trial motions.Â  Collins at 561, 579 S.E.2d 
  at 524.Â  IGT received written notice of the entry of the order denying its motion 
  to alter or amend on November 5, 2001, and served its notice of appeal on November 
  21, 2001.Â  Id.Â Â Â  
This court held that because IGTâ€™s Rule 
  59(e) motion did not raise new issues, but rather restated the arguments made 
  in earlier motions, it was not a proper Rule 59(e) motion and thus, did not 
  toll the time to serve notice of appeal.Â  Collins, 353 S.C. at 566, 579 
  S.E.2d at 527, (citing Coward Hund Constr. Co. v. Ball Corp., 336 S.C. 
  1, 518 S.E.2d 56 (Ct. App. 1999) and Quality Trailer Products, Inc. v. CSL 
  Equip. Co., 349 S.C. 216, 562 S.E.2d 615 (2002)).Â  Therefore, because the 
  issues raised in IGTâ€™s subsequent motions were ripe for appellate review after 
  the courtâ€™s first post-trial ruling, the time to appeal lapsed while IGT awaited 
  a ruling on its subsequent Rule 59(e) motion.Â  Id. Â 
 The facts of the present 
  case warrant the same result.Â  Arthurs moved for JNOV and new trial immediately 
  following the juryâ€™s verdict on the grounds the evidence did not support the 
  juryâ€™s conclusion on the issue of negligence and that the trial court should 
  not have instructed the jury on the law regarding the defense of unavoidable 
  accident.Â  The trial court denied these motions.Â  Arthurs received a written 
  copy of the trial courtâ€™s order denying these motions on November 27, 2001, 
  and then moved to alter or amend the judgment under Rule 59(e) on the same groundsâ€”that 
  the evidence did not support the juryâ€™s ruling on negligence and that the trial 
  court improperly instructed the jury on unavoidable accident.Â  The trial court 
  opined that it had â€œagain carefully considered all of Plaintiffâ€™s argumentsâ€ 
  and denied the motion. 
The issues raised by 
  Arthursâ€™ initial post-trial motions for JNOV and new trial were preserved and 
  ripe for appellate review when they were denied by the trial court in November 
  2001.Â  Because Arthursâ€™ subsequent Rule 59(e) motion merely restated the arguments 
  made in her initial post-trial motions, it did not stay the time to file notice 
  of appeal.Â  Therefore, because Arthurs did not file her notice of appeal until 
  March 11, 2002, we find the appeal is untimely.
Accordingly, for the 
  reasons stated above, the present appeal is
 DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, 
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

  239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

v.

  
    
      
Raymond Robert Berggrum,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-218
Submitted February 9, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Raymond Robert Berggrum was 
  convicted of second-degree burglary and sentenced to ten years imprisonment.Â  
  Berggrum appeals, arguing the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a 
  directed verdict.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Officer Steve Stewart responded to a 
  call that a liquor store had been burglarized in the middle of the night.Â  When 
  Stewart arrived, he discovered glass on the inside of the door, blood on the 
  door, and two broken bottles of Wild Turkey.Â  A second officer, Greg Turner, 
  arrived at the scene and noted a Wild Turkey cup â€“ similar to the ones in the 
  liquor storeâ€™s display â€“ was on the ground outside the store and had blood on 
  it.Â Â Â  
After canvassing the area around the store, Stewart 
  and Turner went to the Days Inn hotel across the street from the store.Â  They 
  questioned the hotelâ€™s night clerk to see if he had noticed anything suspicious.Â  
  After speaking with the clerk, the officers went to Room 109, where they noticed 
  blood on the outside of the door.Â  Berggrum answered the door and allowed the 
  officers to enter.Â  After the officers noticed a bottle of Wild Turkey on the 
  floor, they obtained consent to search the rest of the room.Â  The officers subsequently 
  found a second bottle of Wild Turkey and another Wild Turkey cup. [1] Â  They also noticed that Berggrum had two fresh 
  scratches on his arm and there was blood on the bedding.Â  
Berggrum gave a statement to Stewart and Turner 
  after he was advised of his Miranda 
  [2]  rights.Â  The statement contained three different versions of events.Â  
  Initially, Berggrum stated two men came to his hotel room and gave him two bottles 
  of Wild Turkey, after which they pointed a gun to his head and told him he owed 
  them $2000. Â Then Berggrum stated the liquor store owner gave him the liquor 
  with the understanding that he would pay later.Â  Finally, Berggrum said he bought 
  the liquor.
At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, defense counsel 
  moved for a directed verdict, arguing there was no substantial circumstantial 
  evidence from which â€œa jury may fairly and logically find or render a verdict.â€Â  
  The trial judge denied the motion, and Berggrum was subsequently found guilty 
  of second-degree burglary.Â  However, after rendering the verdict, the jury foreman 
  stated, â€œ[w]e were very dissatisfied with the evidence even though we did return 
  with a guilty verdict.Â  We would let it be known.â€Â  Based in large part upon 
  the foremanâ€™s comment, Berggrum moved for a new trial, which was denied.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Berggrum argues the trial judge erred 
  in denying his motions for directed verdict and a new trial because there was 
  insufficient evidence of guilt.Â  We do not agree.
On a motion for a directed verdict 
  in a criminal case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or non-existence 
  of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Morgan, 282 S.C. 409, 411, 319 
  S.E.2d 335, 336 (1984).Â  In reviewing a refusal to grant a directed verdict, 
  the appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the 
  State and determine whether there is any direct or substantial circumstantial 
  evidence that reasonably tends to prove the defendant's guilt or from which 
  his guilt may be logically deduced. Â State v. Pinckney, 339 S.C. 346, 
  349, 529 S.E.2d 526, 527 (2000).Â Â  If the State presents any evidence which 
  reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, or from which the defendantâ€™s 
  guilt could be fairly and logically deduced, the case must go to the jury.Â  
  State v. Poindexter, 314 S.C. 490, 493, 431 S.E.2d 254, 255-56 (1993).
At trial, the State presented substantial 
  circumstantial evidence to support the guilty verdict.Â  Berggrumâ€™s hotel room 
  was located across the street from the burglarized liquor store.Â  Four bottles 
  of Wild Turkey were stolen from the liquor store and police found a total of 
  four bottles of Wild Turkey between the liquor store and Berggrumâ€™s hotel room.Â  
  Police also found a Wild Turkey promotional cup â€“ similar to those in the Wild 
  Turkey display at the liquor store â€“ in Berggrumâ€™s hotel room.Â  Further, there 
  was blood at the liquor store, blood on Berggrumâ€™s hotel room door, blood on 
  his hotel bedding, and two fresh scratches on his arm.Â  In addition to this 
  circumstantial evidence, Officer Turner testified as to the statement Berggrum 
  made after his arrest.Â  After Berggrum was read his Miranda rights, he 
  gave three conflicting statements to police about how he came to have two bottles 
  of Wild Turkey and a Wild Turkey cup in his hotel room.Â  Viewing the Stateâ€™s 
  evidence as a whole, we find the State presented substantial circumstantial 
  evidence of Berggrumâ€™s guilt.Â  
CONCLUSION
We find the trial judge did not err in denying 
  Berggrumâ€™s motion for a directed verdict and submitting the case to the jury.Â  
  See, e.g., State v. McGowan, 347 S.C. 618, 622, 557 S.E.2d 
  657, 659 (2001) (holding that if there is any direct evidence or any substantial 
  circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, 
  this court must find the case was properly submitted to the jury).Â  Accordingly, 
  Berggrumâ€™s conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J.,Â  and ANDERSON, J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The liquor storeowner subsequently verified that four bottles of 
    Wild Turkey were missing from the store. 

 
   
    [2]  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 86 S. Ct. 1602, 16 L. Ed. 
    2d 694 (1966).
