THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE,Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED 
  OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Johnny Brewer, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-219
  Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
          Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Johnny Brewer was convicted of murder, second-degree arson, and larceny.Â  He was sentenced 
  to life imprisonment for murder, twenty-five years imprisonment for second-degree 
  arson, and ten years imprisonment for larceny, with the sentences to run consecutively.Â  
  Brewer appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by: 1) determining evidence 
  regarding correspondence between Starnes and an inmate who used the defense 
  of panic was relevant; and 2) failing to instruct the jury that the State had 
  the burden of disproving accident beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Brewer was indicted for murder, 
  second-degree arson, and larceny.Â  At trial, Brewer represented himself.Â  During 
  Brewerâ€™s testimony, he admitted he strangled the victim to death, robbed her 
  house, and then set her house on fire. 
The State presented evidence Brewer killed the 
  victim because she interrupted him while he was searching her house for money 
  to pay drug debts.Â  Brewerâ€™s explanation for the crimes was that he had staged 
  a robbery and set the victimâ€™s house on fire because he panicked after accidentally 
  killing the victim.Â  In response to Brewerâ€™s explanation that his actions were 
  motivated by panic, the State asked Brewer about correspondence he had with 
  another inmate who had used panic as a defense in a murder trial.Â  Brewer objected 
  to this question.Â  The circuit court overruled the objection. 
After the close of the evidence, Brewer 
  requested the circuit court charge the jury on accident and instruct them that 
  the State had the burden to disprove his accident defense.Â  The circuit court 
  charged the jury on accident but did not instruct them on which party had the 
  burden for establishing accident. 
Brewer was convicted of murder, second-degree 
  arson, and larceny.Â  He was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder, twenty-five 
  years imprisonment for second-degree arson, and ten years imprisonment for larceny, 
  with the sentences to run consecutively.Â  Brewer appeals.
DISCUSSION
I.Â Relevant Evidence
Brewer argues the circuit court erred by determining 
  evidence regarding correspondence between Brewer and an inmate who used the 
  defense of panic was relevant.Â  We disagree.
Relevant evidence is defined as â€œevidence having 
  any tendency to make, the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the 
  determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be 
  without the evidence.â€ Rule 401, SCRE; see Rule 402, SCRE (â€œAll relevant 
  evidence is admissible, except as otherwise provided by the Constitution of 
  the United States, the Constitution of the State of South Carolina, statutes, 
  these rules [of evidence], or by other rules promulgated by the Supreme Court 
  of South Carolina.â€); Rule 403, SCRE (stating relevant evidence may be excluded 
  if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice).Â Â  
A ruling by a circuit court concerning the relevance 
  of evidence will be disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 184, 577 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2003).
During direct examination, Brewer admitted strangling 
  the victim but stated he did not mean to kill her.Â  He testified that, after 
  he killed the victim, he made the scene appear to be a robbery before he set 
  the house on fire.Â  On cross, Brewer stated he had covered up the killing because 
  he had panicked.Â  He explained he had panicked in the past when faced with a 
  situation where someone had died. 
In response to Brewerâ€™s claim that he had panicked 
  in this situation as he had done in the past, the State conducted the following 
  cross-examination:
STATE: In fact, Mr. Brewer, since youâ€™ve been acting as your 
  own attorney, youâ€™ve been having some correspondence, havenâ€™t you? Youâ€™ve received 
  some correspondence, havenâ€™t you?
. . .
STATE: In fact, some of that mail has come from the law offices 
  of Norman Starnes and B.J. Quattlebaum, hasnâ€™t it?
DEFENDANT: I have received a letter from a couple of guys 
  that was in the jail who have been convicted.Â  They wrote me a letter back, 
  yes.
STATE: In fact, one of them, Norman Starnes, used the defense 
  of: I panicked when I killedÂ  these two guys and buried them out in a field 
  and put lime on top of them. Didnâ€™t he? He himself used that defense, didnâ€™t 
  he?
Brewer objected, arguing the 
  information relating to Starnes was not relevant. The circuit court overruled 
  the objection. 
The State sought to introduce the evidence of correspondence 
  between Brewer and Starnes to demonstrate that Brewer had recently fabricated 
  the defense of accident and panic.Â  Because the testimony regarding the correspondence 
  had the tendency to affect the credibility of Brewerâ€™s explanation of why he 
  committed the crimes, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion by admitting 
  the evidence. See Shuler, 353 S.C. at 184, 577 S.E.2d at 442.
Starnes further contends the State presented no 
  evidence suggesting Brewer and Starnes colluded to fabricate Brewerâ€™s defense.Â  
  Relying on State v. Bailey, 279 S.C. 437, 308 S.E.2d 795 (1983), Brewer 
  argues a baseless allegation is irrelevant and grounds for reversal.
In Bailey, the defendantâ€™s father and brother 
  plotted to procure perjured testimony on the defendantâ€™s behalf. Id. at 440, 308 S.E.2d at 797.Â  Because the defendant had no knowledge of the plan, 
  the circuit court ruled the evidence irrelevant because it â€œdid not go to any 
  material issue at trial.â€ Id.
Here, Brewer admitted to corresponding with Starnes 
  and to knowing about the defenses Starnes used at trial.Â  Unlike Bailey, 
  the State was questioning Brewer concerning correspondences in which he was 
  involved.Â  Further, the issue involved was a material issue in Brewerâ€™s trial.Â  
  Thus, Bailey is inapplicable to the facts of this case. [1] 
II. Jury Charge on Accident
Brewer argues the circuit court erred by failing 
  to instruct the jury that the State had the burden of disproving accident beyond 
  a reasonable doubt.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe law to be charged to the jury is determined 
  by the evidence presented at trial.â€ State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 
  380 S.E.2d 834, 835 (1989).Â  â€œThe trial judge should charge only the law applicable 
  to the case [because] . . . . [p]roviding instructions to the jury which do 
  not fit the facts of the case may tend to confuse the jury.â€ Id. at 364, 
  380 S.E.2d at 836 (internal citations omitted).Â  However, â€œa trial court commits 
  reversible error if it fails to give a requested charge on an issue raised by 
  the evidence.â€ State v. Hill, 315 S.C. 260, 262, 433 S.E.2d 848, 849 
  (1993).
Brewer appeals because, although the circuit court 
  gave a charge on accident, it did not instruct the jury regarding which party 
  had the burden of establishing accident.Â  We affirm because we hold the evidence 
  did not support a charge on accident, and therefore, the sufficiency of the 
  accident charge is immaterial.
Brewer requested the following jury charge: â€œ[T]he 
  State bears the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the death of 
  [the victim] was not the result of an accident.â€ 
Brewer claimed his explanation of how the killing 
  occurred supported a charge on accident.Â  At trial, Brewer testified:
It happened quick.Â  She was pulling, pulling, and I wouldnâ€™t 
  stop.Â  I grabbed the phone.Â  [The victim] at that time couldnâ€™t stop me.Â  She 
  grabbed the teapot.Â  She swung it at me and I donâ€™t know even where it hit me 
  or if it hit me at all.Â  I mean, it was just quick.Â  After that, you know, she 
  kept â€“ she kept struggling, you know, swinging at me.Â  As far as the scratches, 
  that happened some time during the incident.Â  That was not while I was â€“ I was 
  not â€“ I was not on top of her choking her out or nothing like that.
We struggled and I just held 
  her down.Â  I held her down.Â  I had her â€“ I had her neck in my arms.Â  She was 
  scratching and clawing.Â  I canâ€™t tell you exactly how it went down as far as 
  the fighting on the floor.Â  There was a struggle; it happened quick.Â  Before 
  I know it she was â€“ she was dead . . . 
â€œFor a homicide to be excusable on the ground of 
  accident, it must be shown that the killing was unintentional, that the defendant 
  was acting lawfully, and that due care was exercised [in the use of force].â€ State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).
Because Brewer presented no evidence from which 
  the jury could have found the victimâ€™s death occurred by accident, a jury charge 
  on accident was not warranted. [2] Â  See Lee, 298 S.C. at 364, 380 
  S.E.2d at 835 (â€œThe law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence 
  presented at trial.â€); see also Goodson, 312 S.C. at 280-81, 440 
  S.E.2d at 372 (holding â€œ[h]omicide is excusable on the ground of accident when 
  it appears that the defendant was acting lawfully in self defenseâ€ and the victim 
  was killed unintentionally).Â  Therefore, we decline to rule on the sufficiency 
  of the accident charge.Â  State v. Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 36, 538 S.E.2d 
  248, 256 (2000) (holding an appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing 
  in the record).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Brewerâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD, KITTREDGE, and CURETON, JJ., concurring.

 [1]  Brewer also argues the Stateâ€™s cross-examination of Brewer concerning 
  the correspondence with Starnes penalized Brewer for exercising his right 
  to self-representation.Â  To support this claim, Brewer relies on State 
    v. Brown, 289 S.C. 581, 590, 347 S.E.2d 882, 887 (1986) (â€œIt is impermissible 
  for the State to argue in favor ofÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  guilt . . . based upon the accusedâ€™s 
  assertion of a constitutional right.â€).Â  Because this issue was not raised 
  to or ruled upon by the circuit court, it is not preserved for appellate review. See Humbert v. State, 345 S.C. 332, 338, 548 S.E.2d 862, 
  866 (2001).Â  
 [2]  Brewer did not request a jury charge on self-defense.Â  Further, the 
  evidence did not establish Brewer believed he was â€œin imminent danger of losing 
  his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or he actually was in such imminent 
  dangerâ€ when he killed the victim. Â See Goodson, 312 S.C. at 
  280, 440 S.E.2d at 372 (holding for a jury charge of self-defense to be warranted 
  â€œthe defendant must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing 
  his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or he actually was in such imminent 
  dangerâ€).Â  Additionally, Brewer was in the victimâ€™s home at the time of the 
  killing. See State v. Chambers, 310 S.C. 43, 44, 425 S.E.2d 
  45, 46 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding even a lawful guest has a duty to retreat 
  if possible, meaning the guest cannot assert self-defense unless he establishes 
  this duty was fulfilled).

  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Joseph N. Grate,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Helen Bone,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
John  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-221
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph N. Grate, for Appellant.
Arrigo Paul Carotti, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Joseph Grate filed a complaint against Helen Bone, a court 
  reporter, concerning a transcript for a hearing.Â  Grate appeals from the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order dismissing his complaint. We affirm. 
  [1] 
  
FACTS

Grate sued Bone for failing to deliver a transcript 
  to him, alleging Bone obstructed his access to due process, deprived him of 
  speedy access to justice, obstructed justice, and concealed evidence.Â  
Bone moved to dismiss the complaint on the grounds 
  that the complaint failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of 
  action in that the complaint failed to allege that Grate paid Bone for the transcript.Â  
  The court granted Boneâ€™s motion. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn deciding whether the circuit court properly granted the 
  motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, this court must consider whether 
  the complaint, when viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff, states 
  any valid claim for relief.â€ Slack v. James, 356 S.C. 479, 482, 589 S.E.2d 
  772, 773 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The circuit court should not grant a motion to dismiss 
  if â€œfacts alleged and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle 
  the plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.â€ Gentry v. Yonce, 
  337 S.C. 1, 5, 522 S.E.2d 137, 139 (1999) (quoting Stiles v. Onorato, 
  318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995)).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Grate argues the circuit court erred in granting 
  Boneâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  We disagree. 
Grateâ€™s complaint simply alleges that Grate requested 
  a transcript from Bone and Bone failed to deliver the transcript to him.Â  Her 
  failure to provide a transcript when there has been no allegation of payment 
  for the transcript does not entitle Grate to relief on any theory of the case. 
  [2] Â  Because Grate has failed to state facts sufficient to constitute any 
  legally cognizable cause of action against Bone, the circuit court properly 
  granted Boneâ€™s motion to dismiss.
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  â€œWhere a transcript of the proceeding must be 
    prepared by the court reporter, appellant shall, within the time provided 
    for ordering the transcript, make satisfactory arrangements (including agreement 
    regarding payment for the transcript), in writing with the court reporter 
    for furnishing the transcript.â€ Rule 207 SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED 
  OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
SCACR.
Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Stoney Burrows,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-222
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Deputy Chief Attorney Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Special Assistant Attorney Amie L. Clifford, all of 
  Columbia; and Solicitor C. Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:  Stoney Burrows 
  was indicted for assault and battery with intent to kill (â€œABWIKâ€).Â  He was 
  convicted of the lesser-included offense of assault and battery of a high and 
  aggravated nature (â€œABHANâ€).Â  Burrows was sentenced to ten years imprisonment, 
  suspended on the service of six years imprisonment and three years probation.Â  
  Burrows appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by admitting his prior conviction 
  for ABWIK.Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Burrows was indicted for ABWIK. Â At trial, the 
  Stateâ€™s case consisted of the testimony of one witness, Steven Hemingway.Â  Hemingway 
  testified that on the night of the altercation, Burrows instigated the fight 
  inside the bar.Â  Hemingway testified that once he was outside the bar Burrows 
  ran into him with a vehicle before hitting him repeatedly with a two-by-four 
  board. 
Hemingway admitted that he had been drinking the 
  night the altercation took place.Â  He also testified he had been displeased 
  with Burrows over an incident that happened at his house two weeks prior to 
  the altercation. 
On cross-examination, Burrows elicited testimony 
  that Hemingway was the larger of the two men, weighing at least fifty pounds 
  more than Burrows. 
Prior to Burrows taking the stand, the State sought 
  to admit several of Burrowsâ€™ prior convictions for impeachment purposes.Â  Burrows 
  objected to the admission of his conviction for ABWIK.Â  The circuit court allowed 
  the conviction into evidence for impeachment purposes, stating that because 
  Burrows was physically smaller than the victim in the prior conviction it was 
  probative of the issue of relative size raised in this case. 
Burrows testified Hemingway began the altercation 
  inside the bar, hitting Burrows across the face with the board.Â  Burrows explained 
  he attempted to leave in his vehicle but Hemingway swung the board through his 
  window and broke his mirror.Â  Burrows testified he did not start the vehicle 
  during the altercation so he could not have hit Hemingway with the vehicle. 

During cross-examination, the State established 
  that Burrows had been convicted of ABWIK on a previous occasion and that he 
  had been smaller than the victim in that case. 
Burrows was convicted of the lesser-included offense 
  of ABHAN.Â  Burrows was sentenced to ten years imprisonment, suspended on the 
  service of six years imprisonment and three years probation.Â  Burrows appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Admission of evidence falls within the 
  circuit courtâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent abuse 
  of that discretion. State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 184, 577 S.E.2d 438, 
  442 (2003).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is 
  based on an error of law.â€ State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 621, 582 S.E.2d 
  426, 429 (2003).
DISCUSSION
Burrows argues the circuit court erred by admitting 
  his prior conviction of ABWIK for impeachment purposes because the circuit court 
  failed to correctly apply the factors in State v. Colf, 337 S.C. 622, 
  525 S.E.2d 246 (2000).Â  We agree.
Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE, requires the circuit court 
  to balance the probative value of the evidence for impeachment purposes against 
  the prejudice to the accused.
In determining whether the probative value of a 
  prior conviction outweighs its prejudicial effect, a circuit court should consider 
  the following factors: â€œ1. [t]he impeachment value of the prior crime; 2. [t]he 
  point in time of the conviction and the witnessâ€™s subsequent history; 3. [t]he 
  similarity between the past crime and the charged crime; 4. [t]he importance 
  of the defendantâ€™s testimony; 5. [t]he centrality of the credibility issue.â€ 
  Colf, 337 S.C. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248; State v. Martin, 347 
  S.C. 522, 530, 556 S.E.2d 706, 710 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œ[T]his court has implicitly 
  recognized the value of these [Colf] factors in making such a determination 
  under Rule 609(a)(1).â€).
The State sought to admit Burrowsâ€™ prior conviction 
  for ABWIK, arguing â€œit would indicate to the jury that this defendant is not 
  only capable but willing . . . [to commit] a crime of this nature . . . [and 
  it] would clearly indicate to the jury that [the disparity in] size isnâ€™t necessarily 
  a factor here given that the defendant is predisposed to such crimes.â€Â  Burrows 
  argued that the reasons given by the State were the precise reasons the conviction 
  should not be admitted.Â  The circuit court found the conviction was admissible 
  because the conviction was for an assault of a person of larger stature than 
  Burrows, and the disparity in size between Burrows and Hemingway had been raised 
  in this case. 
â€œ[W]hen the prior offense is similar to the offense 
  for which the defendant is on trial, the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant 
  from impeachment by that prior offense weighs against its admission.â€Â  State 
  v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 542, 579 S.E.2d 318, 320 (2003).Â  A prior conviction 
  is inadmissible to show the defendant â€œacted in conformity with his prior convictions.â€ 
  Â State v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 108-09, 561 S.E.2d 618, 622 
  (Ct. App. 2002). 
In making its determination, the circuit court failed 
  to correctly apply the Colf factors.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s ruling was 
  based on one of the Colf factors, â€œ[t]he similarity between the past 
  crime and the crime charged.â€ Colf, 337 S.C. at 627, 525 S.E.2d at 248.Â  
  However, instead of displaying concern about the similarity between the prior 
  conviction and the alleged crime, the circuit court made this similarity the 
  basis for its decision.Â  Specifically, the circuit court found the conviction 
  was admissible for the purpose of establishing Burrowsâ€™ propensity to attack 
  victims larger than himself. We hold this was error. Id. at 628, 525 
  S.E.2d at 249 (â€œThe trial judge here erred in treating the prior crimes as if 
  their similarity heightened their probative value when it actually increased 
  their prejudicial effect.â€).
Further, the error was not harmless because the competent 
  evidence put forth to convict Burrows did not conclusively prove his guilt.Â  
  State v. Livingstone, 282 S.C. 1, 6, 317 S.E.2d 129, 132 (1984) (â€œ[W]here 
  guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence and no rational conclusion 
  can be reached other than the accused is guilty, a conviction will not be set 
  aside because of insubstantial errors not affecting the result.â€).Â  Hemingway 
  was the only witness to testify for the State.Â  He admitted to having two or 
  three beers on the night of the altercation and to being displeased with Burrows 
  over an incident that happened at Hemingwayâ€™s house two weeks prior to the altercation.Â  
  Hemingway testified Burrows instigated the fight inside the bar.Â  He testified 
  that once he was outside the bar Burrows ran into him with a vehicle and hit 
  him with the board. Â However, Burrows testified Hemingway began the fight.Â  
  Burrows testified he did not drive into Hemingway with his vehicle and he only 
  hit Hemingway in response to Hemingwayâ€™s physically aggressive behavior.Â  The 
  State did not call the owner of the bar, a person who could have testified as 
  to who started the altercation.Â  The State also chose not to call an individual 
  who helped break up the fight, a person who could have testified as to whether 
  Hemingway had been hit by a vehicle.
Under these circumstances, we cannot hold beyond a 
  reasonable doubt that the affirmative answer to the Stateâ€™s question regarding 
  Burrowsâ€™ prior conviction for ABWIK, the same crime for which he was accused 
  in this trial, did not irreparably damage Burrowsâ€™ credibility in each jurorâ€™s 
  mind. Because the circuit court erred by allowing the prior conviction for ABWIK 
  to be use for impeachment purposes, and Burrows was prejudiced by that error, 
  we reverse. State v. Harvey, 275 S.C. 225, 227, 268 S.E.2d 587, 588 (1980) 
  (holding prejudicial error is grounds for reversal).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Burrowsâ€™ conviction is
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE,
JJ., concurring.

THIS OPINION HAS 
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

v.

  
    
      
Keith B. Bruce,       
Appellant.

Alexander S. Macauley, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

REMANDED 


  
    
      
E. Delane Rosemond, of Seneca, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Druanne D. White, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM: Â Keith B. Bruce was 
  convicted of distribution of marijuana and distribution of marijuana within 
  the proximity of school.Â  Subsequently, the circuit court sentenced him to ten 
  years imprisonment for distribution of marijuana and fifteen years imprisonment 
  for distribution of marijuana within the proximity of a school, the sentences 
  to run concurrently.Â  Bruce appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by denying 
  his motion for directed verdict.Â  We remand with instructions.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Bruce was indicted for distribution of marijuana 
  and distribution of marijuana within the proximity of a school.Â  Subsequently, 
  a jury convicted him on both charges, and the circuit court sentenced him to 
  ten years imprisonment for distribution of marijuana and fifteen years imprisonment 
  for distribution of marijuana within the proximity of a school, the sentences 
  to run concurrently.Â  Bruce appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bruce argues the circuit court erred by denying 
  his motion for directed verdict.Â  We do not reach this issue, as we remand this 
  case for a determination of whether the grand jury true billed his indictments.
The jurisdiction of a court over the subject matter 
  of a proceeding is fundamental.Â  Brown v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 346, 540 
  S.E.2d 846, 848 (2001).Â  Thus, the lack of subject matter jurisdiction can be 
  raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised 
  sua sponte by the court.Â  State v. Brown, 351 S.C. 522, 525-26, 570 S.E.2d 
  559, 560 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
The circuit court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to convict 
  a defendant of an offense unless: 1) there has been an indictment that sufficiently 
  states the offense; 2) the defendant has waived presentment of the indictment; 
  or 3) the offense is a lesser-included offense of the crime charged in the indictment.Â  
  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 579, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002).Â Â  
When the action of the grand jury is not written on the indictment, 
  and evidence does not exist within the record to indicate the action of the 
  grand jury, an appellate court must remand the case to the circuit court for 
  a determination of whether the indictment was true billed.Â  See State 
  v. Grim, 341 S.C. 63, 67, 533 S.E.2d 329, 330 (2000) (holding where grand 
  jury foreman signed and dated the indictment but failed to state the action 
  of the grand jury, the appropriate remedy was to remand the case to the circuit 
  court for a determination of whether the grand jury true billed the indictment); 
  Anderson v. State, 338 S.C. 629, 633, 527 S.E.2d 398, 400 (Ct. App. 2000) 
  (same).Â  Furthermore, upon remand, the State bears the burden of proving subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  See Id.  
In the present case, the grand jury foreman signed and dated 
  both indictments.Â  However, no action of the grand jury is stamped or written 
  on either indictment.Â  Furthermore, no evidence exists within the record indicating 
  the action of the grand jury.Â  Thus, we remand the case for a hearing on whether 
  the circuit court was properly vested with subject matter jurisdiction during 
  Bruceâ€™s trial. At the hearing, the State shall bear the burden of proving subject 
  matter jurisdiction.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, this case is REMANDED to 
  the circuit court, and the appeal is stayed pending resolution of this 
  matter.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Albert Scruggs,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-226
Submitted January 29, 2004 â€“ Filed March 
  30, 2004

REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all 
  of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Albert Scruggs was 
  convicted of second-degree burglary, kidnapping, and assault with intent to 
  commit first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  The circuit court sentenced him 
  to fifteen years imprisonment for second-degree burglary, life imprisonment 
  without parole for kidnapping, and life imprisonment without parole for assault 
  with intent to commit first-degree criminal sexual conduct, the sentences to 
  run concurrently.Â  Scruggs appeals, arguing the circuit court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction because the Stateâ€™s indictment against him for assault with 
  intent to commit first-degree criminal sexual conduct was jurisdictionally defective.Â  
  We remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
A grand jury indicted Scruggs for second-degree burglary, 
  kidnapping, and assault with intent to commit first-degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  
  During the trial, the State moved to amend the indictment for assault with intent 
  to commit criminal sexual conduct, and the circuit court granted the motion.Â  
  Subsequently, Scruggs was convicted on all the charges.Â  Scruggs appeals.
DISCUSSION
Scruggs argues the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  over his charge for assault with intent to commit first-degree criminal sexual 
  conduct because the Stateâ€™s indictment was jurisdictionally defective.Â  
â€œIssues related to subject matter jurisdiction Search 
  Term Begin Search Term End may be raised at any time.â€Â  Carter v. State, 
  329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d 773, 777 (1998). A circuit court has subject matter 
  jurisdiction if: â€œ(1) there has been an indictment which sufficiently states 
  the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is 
  a lesser included offense of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
  â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether it could be 
  made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary elements 
  of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant 
  of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 
  368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).Â  
A circuit court lacks subject matter jurisdiction if the 
  indictment fails to allege an essential element of the offense charged.Â  Mathis 
  v. State, 355 S.C. 87, 92, 584 S.E.2d 366, 368-69 (2003) (holding where 
  Stateâ€™s indictment for first-degree burglary failed to allege an aggravating 
  circumstance, the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction).
South Carolina Code Annotated section 16-3-652 
  (2003) states a person is guilty of criminal sexual conduct in the first degree 
  if:

the actor engages in sexual battery with the victim and if 
  any one or more of the following circumstances are proven: (a) The actor uses 
  aggravated force to accomplish sexual battery. (b) The victim submits to sexual 
  battery by the actor under circumstances where the victim is also the victim 
  of forcible confinement, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, burglary, housebreaking, 
  or any other similar offense or act.Â  (c) The actor causes the victim, without 
  the victimâ€™s consent, to become mentally incapacitated or physically helpless 
  by administering, distributing, dispensing, delivering, or causing to be administered, 
  distributed, dispensed, or delivered a controlled substance, a controlled substance 
  analogue, or any intoxicating substance.

The caption for the indictment for assault with intent to 
  commit first-degree criminal sexual conduct stated, â€œASSAULT WITH INTENT 
  TO COMMIT CRIMINAL SEXUAL CONDUCT, 1ST SC Code:Â  16-3-656, 652(2)[,]â€ 
  and the body alleged, â€œTHAT ALBERT SCRUGGS DID IN RICHLAND COUNTY ON OR ABOUT 
  JUNE 6, 2002, WILFILLY, UNLAWFULLY, AND FELONIOUSLY ATTEMPT TO COMMIT A SEXUAL 
  BATTERY UPON AND WITH THE BODY OF MARGARET LEWIS.â€Â  (emphasis as in original).Â  

During the trial, the State amended the indictment, adding 
  the following to its body, 

WITHOUT HER CONSENT.Â  SUCH SEXUAL BATTERY WAS ACCOMPLISHED 
  BY THE USE OF AGGRAVATED FORCE TO WIT:Â  THE INTENT TO COMMIT A FELONY AND/OR 
  DESPARITY [SIC] BETWEEN THE PHYSICAL CONDITIONS OF THE PARTIES AND/OR A DIFFERENCE 
  IN SEXES AND/OR INDECENT LIBERTIES OR FAMILIARITIES WITH A FEMALE.Â  AND/OR IS 
  ALSO THE VICTIM OF FORCEABLE CONFINEMENT, KIDNAPPING, BURGLARY, OR OTHER SIMILAR 
  OFFENSE.Â  ALL IN VIOLATION OF SC CODE OF LAWS 16-3-656. AND SC CODE OF LAWS 
  16-3-652. 

(emphasis as in original).Â  
The Stateâ€™s original indictment for assault with intent to 
  commit criminal sexual conduct does not state an aggravating circumstance listed 
  in section 16-3-652.Â  Thus, the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  on the original indictment.Â  See Mathis, 355 S.C. at 92, 584 S.E.2d 
  atÂ  368-69 (holding where Stateâ€™s indictment for first-degree burglary failed 
  to allege an aggravating circumstance, the circuit court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction).Â  Consequently, we must determine if the Stateâ€™s amendment was 
  an action by the grand jury, for if it was not, the State could not amend the 
  indictment, adding the substantive elements, to vest the circuit court with 
  subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See State v. Ervin, 333 S.C. 351, 
  356, 510 S.E.2d 220, 223 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding the circuit court may not 
  acquire subject matter jurisdiction by permitting the State to amend an otherwise 
  jurisdictionally-defective indictment); see also Stirone v. United 
  States, 361 U.S. 212, 218 (1960) (â€œThe very purpose of the requirement that 
  a man be indicted by grand jury is to limit his jeopardy to offenses charged 
  by a group of his fellow citizens acting independently of either prosecuting 
  attorney or judge.â€); United States v. McGrath, 558 F.2d 1102, 1105 n. 
  3 (2nd Cir. 1977) (â€œThe principal justification for barring amendment by the 
  court or prosecutor is the possibility that the Grand Jury might have voted 
  no bill on the amended facts. When the amendment is made by the Grand Jury, 
  this danger does not exist.â€); 41 Am Jur. 2d Indictments and Informations 
  Â§ 173 (1995) (stating an indictment may not be amended except by resubmission 
  to the grand jury, unless the change is merely a matter of form). 
The State amended the body of the indictment to allege aggravating 
  circumstances.Â  Adjacent to the amended language are the initials, â€œWSSâ€ and 
  then the statement â€œAS AMENDED,â€ with a signature, from someone other than the 
  person who initialed the amendment, and the date.Â  No evidence exists within 
  the record indicating who either initialed or signed the indictmentâ€™s amendment.Â  
  However, neither of the signatures are that of the presiding circuit court judge.Â  
  Furthermore, the State, in its respondentâ€™s brief, contends the amendment could 
  have been the foreperson of the grand jury.Â  
Given the record before us, we cannot determine whether the 
  grand jury approved the amended language of the indictment.Â  Thus, we remand 
  this matter to the circuit court for a factual determination as to whether the 
  amendment was submitted to the grand jury.Â  See State v. Grim, 
  341 S.C. 63, 67, 533 S.E.2d 329, 330 (2000) (holding where indictment did not 
  disclose if it was true-billed, the appropriate remedy was to remand the case 
  to the circuit court).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, this appeal is REMANDED 
  to the circuit court.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concurring.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        Outpatient Surgical Clinic, LLC,

Appeal From Richland County
Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-228
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed March 30, 2004 

REVERSED AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
David B. Summer, Jr., Faye A. Flowers, both of Columbia. 
  for Appellants.
E. Katherine Wells, of Columbia; Michael A. Molony and Stephen 
  L. Brown, both of Charleston; Douglas Jennings, Jr., of Bennettsville, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Marlboro Park Hospital and 
  Chesterfield General Hospital (Hospitals) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s decision 
  affirming the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control 
  Boardâ€™s (the DHEC Board) grant of a certificate of need to Doctorâ€™s Outpatient 
  Surgical Clinic (DOSC), which reversed the decision of a South Carolina Administrative 
  Law Judge (ALJ) denying the certificate.Â  On appeal, the Hospitals argue the 
  circuit court erred in (1) affirming the DHEC Boardâ€™s de novo review 
  of the ALJâ€™s decision; and (2) finding that the ALJ improperly considered evidence 
  not presented at a preceding Staff Review Hearing conducted by the South Carolina 
  Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  We agree and reverse, 
  finding the DHEC Board erred in using a de novo standard of review rather 
  than one requiring substantial evidence.Â  Additionally, we find that substantial 
  evidence supports the decision of the ALJ. We further find that the ALJ properly 
  considered evidence not presented to DHEC in a preceding Staff Review Hearing 
  because the evidence was related to issues presented during that hearing.Â  Accordingly, 
  we reverse and remand to the circuit court to reinstate the decision of the 
  ALJ.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
DOSC filed its application for a certificate of 
  need with DHEC in 1988, seeking to construct an ambulatory surgery center in 
  Bennettsville.Â  The Hospitals opposed the application.Â  
DHEC conducted a Staff Review Hearing on the application 
  during which both parties presented information supporting their respective 
  positions.Â  In particular, the Hospitals argued that the proposed outpatient 
  surgery center would adversely impact the Hospitals and need for the center 
  was insufficient.Â  DHEC recommended approval of the application for the certificate 
  of need.
The Hospitals requested a contested case hearing 
  before the ALJ.Â  The ALJ conducted a hearing over a seven-day period, during 
  which both sides presented evidence and testimony from eighteen witnesses.Â  
  After making findings of fact, the ALJ concluded the application did not meet 
  the legal criteria for approval of the certificate of need.Â  The ALJâ€™s decision 
  was based in part on the lack of need of a facility and in part on the negative 
  impact the facility would have on the Hospitals.
DOSC appealed this decision to the Board.Â  
  In a hearing lasting a little over one hour, the DHEC Board heard oral arguments 
  from both parties.Â  It subsequently issued its order reversing the order of 
  the ALJ and granting the certificate of need.Â  The Board set forth its own findings 
  of fact that contradicted many of the ALJâ€™s findings.
The Hospitals appealed to the circuit 
  court, which affirmed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  The Hospitals subsequently filed 
  a motion for reconsideration, which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.      
The Boardâ€™s Standard of Review
The Hospitals argue the Board improperly 
  found facts according to its own view of the evidence utilizing a de novo 
  standard.Â  We agree.
The ALJ presides over all hearings of contested 
  DHEC permitting cases.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (Supp. 2002).Â  
  In such cases, the ALJ serves as the finder of fact.Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t 
  of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 512, 560 S.E.2d 410, 413 (2002).Â  
  On appeal of such a contested case, a reviewing tribunal â€œmust affirm the ALJ 
  if the findings are supported by substantial evidence, not based on the [Boardâ€™s] 
  on view of the evidence.â€Â  Dorman v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  350 S.C. 159, 166, 565 S.E.2d 119, 123 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Here, DHECâ€™s Board 
  undisputedly sat in an appellate capacity when reviewing the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  
  We find that the DHEC board erred by applying a de novo standard of review 
  rather than a â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard. 
  [1] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  ALJâ€™s Consideration of New Evidence
The Hospitals further assign error to 
  the DHEC Boardâ€™s determination, with which the circuit court concurred, that 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) confines contested hearings before 
  the ALJ to the exact evidence considered during the preceding Staff Review Hearing.Â  
  We agree with this assignment of error.
 The DHEC Board held that the ALJ erred 
  in considering evidence not presented during the Staff Review Hearing, all of 
  which undisputedly related to core issues addressed during that hearing. [2] Â  Relying on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E), the 
  Board stated that â€œparties are not allowed to submit new or additional facts 
  for consideration at the contested case hearing which were not part of the administrative 
  record at the time of the [DHEC Staff Review Hearing.]â€ 
  [3] Â  We find the DHEC Boardâ€™s interpretation of Section 44-7-210(E) erroneous.
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is 
  to ascertain and effectuate the legislative intent whenever possible.â€Â  Strother 
  v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 
  121 (1998).Â  â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient to the one 
  that the legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered 
  in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the 
  intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, 
  Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994).Â  The words of the statute 
  must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or 
  forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Hitatchi 
  Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  

Here, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) states â€œ[t]he 
  issues considered at the contested case hearings are limited to those 
  presented or considered during the staff review and decision process.â€Â  (emphasis 
  added).Â  However, DHECâ€™s Board expansively interpreted the statute to preclude 
  the ALJ in contested hearings from receiving any evidence not presented 
  to DHEC during a Staff Review Hearing.Â  We reject this interpretation, finding 
  it conflicts with the plain language of the statute and the ordinary meaning 
  of the word â€œissuesâ€ as used in this context.
Additionally, the interpretation advanced 
  by the DHEC Board and circuit court is inconsistent with applicable case law 
  providing a de novo review for ALJ hearings conducted in a posture similar 
  to that in the case at bar.Â Â  See Brown, 348 S.C. at 512, 560 
  S.E.2d at 413 (noting that when reviewing a contested case on appeal, the ALJ 
  conducts a de novo hearing with the presentation of evidence and testimony.).Â  
  A trial de novo is one in which â€œthe whole case is tried as if no trial 
  whatsoever had been had in the first instance.â€Â  Blizzard v. Miller, 
  306 S.C. 373, 375, 412 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1991).Â Â  Moreover, when reviewing a 
  contested case on appeal, â€œ[t]he ALJ, as the fact-finder, must make sufficiently 
  detailed findings supporting the denial [or grant] of a permit application.â€Â  
  Converse Power Corp. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 
  S.C. 39, 46, 564 S.E.2d 341, 345 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œDetailed findings enable 
  [an appellate court] to determine whether such findings are supported by the 
  evidence . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  Here, because the ALJ was conducting a de 
  novo hearing, we find that he properly considered the evidence presented 
  in his pursuit to make â€œsufficiently detailed findingsâ€ of fact for subsequent 
  review.Â  
Based on our interpretation of the unambiguous 
  language in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) and case law providing 
  the ALJ a de novo review in contested hearings arising from a DHECâ€™s 
  Staff Review Hearing, we conclude that the DHEC Board erred in expanding the 
  term â€œissuesâ€ to include â€œevidence.â€Â  In light of the DHEC Board error, we consequently 
  find that the circuit court erred in its acquiescence to the DHECâ€™s Board position.
III.Â Â Â  Substantial Evidence
The Hospitals contend there was substantial 
  evidence to support the ALJâ€™s finding that the certificate of need should be 
  denied.Â  In particular, they maintain substantial evidence was presented to 
  show the proposed facility would adversely impact the two existing facilities 
  and the need for a new facility was insufficient.Â  Consequently, based upon 
  the credible evidence as determined by the ALJ, the application 
  would not comply with the State Health Plan, thus requiring a denial of the 
  permit by DHEC.Â  We agree.
Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(C) (2002), DHEC must 
  deny a Certificate of Need if an application does not comply with the State 
  Health Plan.Â  Under the applicable State Health Plan, approval of an ambulatory 
  surgical facility requires that six certain criteria must be met.Â  These criteria 
  include proof of a documented need for the facility and a discussion on the 
  impact on existing facilities.Â  The State Health Plan also ranked nine criteria 
  to be considered while reviewing DOSCâ€™s application.Â  The nine criteria in order 
  of importance to DHEC are need, community need documentation, distribution (accessibility), 
  acceptability, efficiency, adverse effect on other facilities, record of the 
  Applicant, ability to complete the project, and financial feasibility. [4] 
As previously discussed, review of the ALJâ€™s factual 
  determinations is measured by the substantial evidence standard.Â  Substantial 
  evidence is not merely a scintilla of evidence, nor is it evidence viewed blindly 
  from one side.Â  Leventis v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 
  340 S.C. 118, 130, 530 S.E.2d 643, 650 (2000)Â Â  Instead, substantial evidence 
  is evidence that, in light of the whole record, allows reasonable minds to reach 
  the reviewing tribunalâ€™s conclusion.Â  Id.Â  Here, the Hospitals, as the 
  moving parties, bore the burden of proving that DOSCâ€™s requested certificate 
  of need should be denied.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-7-210(E) (Supp. 2000) 
  (â€œThe burden of proof in a reconsideration or contested case hearing must be 
  upon the moving party.â€).Â  
The ALJ found the Hospitals adequately demonstrated 
  that the proposed facility would have a significant adverse impact on the two 
  Hospitals and that there was not sufficient need demonstrated to justify the 
  new facility.Â  Given evidence presented at the ALJ hearing regarding the lack 
  of full utilization of the Hospitalsâ€™ current facilities, the probability that 
  the new facility will not be able to recapture enough patients to meet its projections, 
  and the result that patients would be taken from the Hospitals, we find substantial 
  evidence existed in the record before the ALJ to support the ALJâ€™s decision 
  denying the certificate of need.Â  We do recognize the evidence to the contrary.Â  
  But, as noted, the appropriate standard of review precludes a de novo 
  review on appeal.Â  Where, as here, reasonable minds could reach the same decision 
  as the ALJ, that decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the decision 
  of the circuit court is reversed, and the matter is remanded to the circuit 
  court to reinstate the decision of the ALJ. 
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We are well aware that the DHEC Boardâ€™s brazen attitude 
    and utter disregard for the proper standard of review created the procedural 
    chaos that followed.Â  The parties, in their respective filings with the Board, 
    conceded that the substantial evidence standard governed the review of the 
    ALJâ€™s factual determinations.Â  In defiance of the partiesâ€™ concession and 
    applicable law, the DHEC Board made its own findings of fact, and unapologetically 
    refused to consider the entire record developed in the contested hearing before 
    the ALJ. 

 
   
    [2] Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Two core issues addressed in DHECâ€™s Staff Review Hearing 
    addressed (1) whether there was sufficient need for the proposed facility, 
    and (2) the extent to which, if any, the proposed facility would have an adverse 
    impact on the Hospitals.Â Â  The ALJ considered evidence related to these issues, 
    including the following evidence not presented during the preceding Staff 
    Review Hearing:Â  (1) expert testimony regarding need and adverse impact of 
    the center because the experts were hired subsequent to the hearing; (2) the 
    Hospitalsâ€™ Joint Annual Reports;Â  (3) 1997 outmigration data compiled by the 
    Budget and Control Board; and (4) information on the impact of the federal 
    1997 Balanced Budget Actâ€™s reduction in payments to health care providers.Â  
    This evidence dealt squarely with the issues before the ALJ.

 
   
    [3]  The circuit court did not specifically address this issue in oral 
    arguments, its subsequent written order, or in response to the Hospitalsâ€™ 
    motion for reconsideration.

 
   [4]  
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The State Health Plan also adds:Â  â€œ[DHEC] will continue to evaluate 
    applications for ambulatory surgery centers on their individual merit.Â  However, 
    it is the determination of [DHEC] that the benefits of improved accessibility 
    will not outweigh the adverse affects caused by the duplication of existing 
    services or equipment.â€

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Andre D. Skanes,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-236
Heard December 11, 2003 â€“ Filed March 
  31, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Arthur Brown, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson; 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph 
  Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Andre D. Skanes was 
  convicted of first-degree burglary and armed robbery and sentenced to eighteen 
  years imprisonment on each charge, the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Skanes 
  appeals, arguing the circuit court erred by admitting evidence in violation 
  of the hearsay rule.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On the night of June 4, 2000, two individuals forced 
  their way into the home of Oscar Lopez and Odis Javier Reyes.Â  Upon entry, the 
  intruders demanded money from the two victims at gunpoint.Â  
The following day, Sharon Bryan Evans was arrested in connection 
  with the crimes.Â  During questioning, Evans identified Skanes as an accomplice.Â  
  As a result, Skanes was arrested and indicted for first-degree burglary and 
  armed robbery.Â Â Â  
At trial, the State called Evans to the stand, and 
  Evans identified Skanes as a participant in the robbery.Â  Subsequently, the 
  State called Officer Samuel Roser, who testified he had interviewed Evans following 
  her arrest.Â  Roser further testified that as a result of the interview, Skanes 
  was identified as Evansâ€™ co-defendant.Â  Skanes did not object to this testimony. 

Thereafter, the State asked Roser if Evans identified 
  Skanes during the interview.Â  Skanes objected, arguing the testimony was hearsay.Â  
  The circuit court overruled the objection and allowed the testimony. 
The State also presented the testimony of Reyes, 
  one of the two victims.Â  Lopez, the other victim, was unavailable for trial.Â  
  Reyes testified in general about the events that took place the night of the 
  robbery.Â  During cross-examination of Reyes, Skanes admitted the police photographic 
  lineup into evidence in which his picture appeared with photographs of similar-looking 
  people.Â  Reyesâ€™ signature appeared on the back of a picture of another person 
  in the lineup, indicating Reyes had identified someone other than Skanes as 
  the perpetrator.Â  Reyesâ€™ misidentification was brought out through Skanesâ€™ 
  examination of Reyes and Officer Roser, who presented the lineup to Reyes.Â  
  However, Lopezâ€™s signature also appeared on the back of the photographic lineup, 
  but was on the photo of Skanes. 
The State called Officer Robert Arbello, the police 
  officer who had presented the photographs to Lopez, to explain Lopezâ€™s signature 
  on the back of the lineup.Â  Skanes objected, arguing the testimony would be 
  hearsay.Â  Â The State countered Skanes had opened the door to the explanation 
  of Lopezâ€™s signature by admitting the photograph containing the signature into 
  evidence and publishing it to the jury.Â  The circuit court agreed and admitted 
  the testimony.Â  Arbello then testified that when he presented the lineup to 
  Lopez, Lopez identified Skanes as the perpetrator, thus explaining Lopezâ€™s signature 
  on the back of Skanesâ€™ photograph.
The jury found Skanes guilty of both charges, and 
  the circuit court sentenced Skanes to eighteen years imprisonment on each charge, 
  the sentences to run concurrently.Â  Skanes appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Pre-Trial Identification
Skanes argues the circuit court committed reversible 
  error by admitting Roserâ€™s testimony, indicating Evans identified Skanes as 
  her accomplice following her arrest.Â  Skanes contends the trial court committed 
  reversible error by admitting this hearsay testimony in violation of Rule 802, 
  South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is within 
  the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of that discretion.â€ State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 620-21, 
  582 S.E.2d 426, 429 (2003). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the circuit 
  courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  Id.
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made 
  by the declarant, while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence 
  to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE; see State 
  v. Townsend, 321 S.C. 55, 59, 467 S.E.2d 138, 141 (Ct. App. 1996) (holding 
  hearsay is defined as an out of court statement offered to prove the truth of 
  the matter asserted). Furthermore, â€œ[h]earsay is not admissible except as provided 
  by these rules or by other rules prescribed by the Supreme Court of this State 
  or by statute.â€Â  Rule 802, SCRE.
However, error in the admission of evidence, without more, 
  is insufficient to reverse a jury verdict, unless the additional element of 
  prejudice is demonstrated.Â  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 
  S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  Whether improperly admitted evidence is prejudicial 
  must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  Id.Â  Thus, 
  improperly admitted hearsay evidence is not prejudicial where it is merely cumulative 
  to other evidence.Â  State v. Blackburn, 271 S.C. 324, 329, 247 S.E.2d 
  334, 337 (1978); cf. State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 124, 
  551 S.E.2d 240, 246 (2001) (â€œErroneously admitted corroboration testimony is 
  not harmless merely because it is cumulative. On the contrary, â€˜it is precisely 
  this cumulative effect which enhances the devastating impact of improper corroboration.â€™â€) 
  (internal citations omitted).
At trial, Evans identified Skanes as her accomplice in committing 
  the robbery.Â  Skanes did not object to her in-court identification.Â  Subsequently, 
  the State called Roser to the stand.Â  Roser testified he interviewed Evans, 
  and as a result of that interview, Skanes was identified as Evansâ€™ co-defendant.Â Â  
  Skanes did not object to this testimony.Â  
Thereafter, the State asked Roser if, during his interview 
  with Evans, she identified her accomplice in committing the robbery.Â  Skanes 
  objected, arguing the testimony would be hearsay, and the circuit court overruled 
  the objection.
Even assuming the evidence was hearsay, we conclude the evidence 
  was cumulative and thus not prejudical because the substance of Roserâ€™s testimony 
  was already presented without objection through both his and Evansâ€™ previous 
  testimony.Â  See State v. Crawley, 349 S.C. 459, 466, 562 S.E.2d 
  683, 687 (Ct. App. 2002) (holding the circuit court did not commit reversible 
  error by permitting alleged hearsay testimony, where substance of alleged hearsay 
  testimony was previously admitted without objection).Â  Thus, we hold the circuit 
  court did not commit reversible error.Â Â  
II.      Photographic 
  Lineup
Skanes argues the circuit court erred by permitting 
  the State to introduce testimony explaining Lopezâ€™s signature on the back of 
  the lineup, especially where, as here, Lopez was unavailable and could not be 
  cross-examined.Â  Skanes contends this testimony was hearsay in violation of 
  Rule 802, South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[W]hen a party introduces evidence about a particular 
  matter, the other party is entitled to explain it or rebut it, even if the latter 
  evidence would have been incompetent or irrelevant had it been offered initially.â€Â  
  State v. Beam, 336 S.C. 45, 52, 518 S.E. 2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  Furthermore, â€œ[a] party cannot complain of prejudice from the admission of evidence 
  if he opened the door to its admission.â€Â  State v. Dunlop, 346 S.C. 312, 
  325-26, 550 S.E.2d 889, 897 (Ct. App. 2001); Beam, 336 S.C. at 53, 518 
  S.E.2d at 301 (â€œA party may not complain of error caused by his own conduct.â€). 
  
  
 During Skanesâ€™ cross-examination of Reyes, Skanes 
  admitted the photographic lineup into evidence, with Lopezâ€™s signature on the 
  back.Â  The lineup was then published to the jury.Â  No evidence exists within 
  the record indicating Skanes attempted to redact Lopezâ€™s name from the lineup 
  prior to its admission into evidence and publication to the jury.Â 

Subsequently, the State moved to reopen its case to explain 
  the presence of Lopezâ€™s signature on the back of the admitted lineup.Â  Skanes 
  objected, arguing the testimony would be hearsay.Â  The circuit court overruled 
  his objection and admitted the testimony.Â  Thereafter, Arbello testified when 
  he showed the lineup to Lopez, Lopez identified Skanes as the perpetrator and 
  signed the back of the lineup. 
We conclude the circuit court did not err by admitting Arbelloâ€™s 
  testimony.Â  Once Skanes admitted the lineup with Lopezâ€™s signature on the back 
  into evidence, the door was opened allowing testimony to explain the signatureâ€™s 
  presence.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, Skanesâ€™ convictions 
  are
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
